title: New FFA Alumni Association supports future farmers
author: Doug Bishop; dbishop@kibaytimes.com
content:
New FFA Alumni Association supports future farmers

 August 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Bishop; dbishop@kibaytimes.com | Page: A4 | Section: News 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE - A new Queen Anne's County High School FFA Alumni Association has been formed to add greater support to the school's FFA chapter, offering financial support for future FFA members at the school to be able to attend conferences around the country.Class of 1978 alumni Jeff Moore made the announcement at the beginning of the annual end of school year banquet. "We formed the FFA Alumni Association about four months ago," he said, "There are already about 20 FFA alumni associations in the state of Maryland." Following a buffet dinner provided by numerous sponsors of the QACHS FFA, outgoing student FFA President Emily Crossley, introduced Assistant Secretary of the Maryland Department of Agriculture Hans Schmidt, who is a lifelong resident and farmer of Queen Anne's County, as the evening's guest speaker. Schmidt spoke briefly, but took time to praise the QACHS FFA Chapter for continuing the good work it has been doing over many years, representing not only the school, but the strong farming community of Queen Anne's County.Schmidt challenged the FFA members to farm with the goal of protecting the Chesapeake Bay, going forward."Queen Anne's County is home to 530 farms that cover a total 150,000 acres.There are 414 miles of shoreline in the county," he said."It's important to develop smart farming practices that allow the industry to grow while be respecting the environment in which we live.Part of my job is being tasked with meeting Bay cleanup goals, and Resource Conservation." Numerous awards were presented to FFA members for their outstanding work during the past school year. Among them, the Star Farmer Award went to Emily Crossley. The Star Placement Award went to Dylan Dean. The Agronomy Individual recognition went to Trevor Dean. The Star Greenhand Award went to Michael Carroll. There were more than 10 FFA members who were recognized for their outstanding participation and placings in the Maryland FFA Public Speaking competition.QACHS FFA supporters who were present were recognized and each presented plaques. Among them, Nick Hall of Chesapeake Family Flooring, Jeff Moore of the newly formed QA FFA Alumni Association, Karen Dean of Queenstown Bank, Mark Sultenfuss of Nagel Farm Service, Jennifer Gannon of Maryland Grain Producers UB, Mike Dean of Chestertown Atlantic Tractor, FFA Floriculture Coach Melinda Rhodes, QACHS administrator Billie Brice and Queen Anne's County Public Schools Assistant Superintendent Marcia Sprankle.The graduating FFA senior members for the 2022-2023 school year are Emily Crossley, Christopher Deitzel, Matthew Deitzel, Harley Martin, Kailee Reed, and Reagan Riggs.Crossley, Martin and Reed, all outgoing officers, were invited to give retiring addresses. Crossley spoke first. She said, "Being chosen to be Chapter president was one of greatest days of my life." She added, "I want to thank our FFA Advisor, Mr. Stokes, for making our agricultural pathway a place where we could have fun learning about agriculture I will miss my high school FFA chapter; my home away from home." Martin, and Reed, who both plan to pursue higher education majoring in nursing, reminisced about struggling with the "COVID twoweek break in March 13, 2020" and coming together to keep the FFA progressing through Google Meets meetings for a year and half before school reopened as normal.Reed's final message to her underclassmen was "just remember to be respectful, courteous, and grateful, and cherish every minute you are in FFA." The final portion of the program was to install the new officers for the upcoming 2023-2024 
 
 Caption: Pictured with their FFA Advisor Brian Stokes, from the left, the school's 2023-2024 FFA Leadership Team: Communication Committee Chair Caroline Kimball, Service Projects Committee Chair Keira Corcoran, Agriculture Ambassador/Alumni Liaison Megan Mansfield and Junior Advisor Giles Stanton. They were installed to their positions at the FFA banquet at the end of the school year
 
DOUG BISHOP
 
DOUG BISHOP
 
Graduating are recognized during the annual FFA banquet. From left FFA Advisor Brian Stokes and seniors Emily Crossley, Christopher Deitzel, Matthew Deitzel, Harley Martin, Kailee Reed, and Reagan Riggs.
 
DOUG BISHOP
 
The Queen Anne's County High School Floriculture Team for the 2022-23 school year is recognized during the annual banquet for the Chapter. From left, FFA members Elyssa Crossley, Emily Crossley, FFA Floriculture Coach Melinda Rhodes, FFA members Madison Branham, Lily Dean, and QACHS FFA alumni Leslie Moore
 
DOUG BISHOP
 
Denise Crossley (center) is recognized and pictured with her two daughters, left, Emily Crossley, and Elyssa Crossley, at the recent Chapter FFA banquet. Many FFA parents are involved in supporting the program during the school year.

title: State dairy princess contest set for Friday
content:
State dairy princess contest set for Friday

 August 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A4 | Section: News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Four outstanding young ladies will compete for the Maryland Dairy Princess title during the 61st annual event at 7 p.m. Friday, Sept. 1, in the Cow Palace at the Maryland State Fairgrounds in Timonium."We are excited to spotlight our regional dairy spokespersons at a venue with thousands of fairgoers to showcase Maryland's dairy industry and allow consumers to learn more about milk, dairy products and our hard-working farmers," said Susan Summers, president of the Maryland Dairy Princess Association.Reigning Maryland Dairy Princess Morgan Osborn-Wotthlie will crown her successor after a two-day competition filled with interviews, presentations, and promotions. Regional Dairy Princesses competing are Darby Skinner of Millington, Eastern Shore Dairy Princess; Sophia Brusco of Middletown, Frederick County Dairy Princess; Layla Shepard of Damascus, South Central Dairy Princess; and Katie Jones of Forest Hill, Upper Chesapeake Dairy Princess.Darby Skinner - Eastern Shore Dairy Princess: A Queen Anne's County High School senior, Darby is an honor roll student who is active in her FFA chapter, is editor-in-chief of the yearbook, and is the varsity volleyball manager. She is vice president of her 4-H club and serves as a club ambassador. Darby's passion is showing her dairy cattle, especially at the county fair where she has captured several honors for her animals and in showmanship.She participates in many community service projects, including local food drives and class fundraisers. She works for SlyFox Farms as a dog kennel caretaker and offers pet sitting to clients as well.Sophia Brusco - Frederick County Dairy Princess: A graduate of Middletown High School and Frederick Community College, Sophia is currently finishing a degree in marketing and management at Shippensburg University.She has worked on her family's South Mountain Creamery since 2016, fulfilling roles as a farm worker, managing the retail store, and most recently as the wholesale sales assistant, presenting products to grocery stores, food service and professional sports venues and working on special social media projects and promotion evaluations. Sophia is an officer for Beta Gamma Sigma, an honorary society for business students.Layla Shepard - South Central Dairy Princess: Layla is an honor roll student and cheerleader at Damascus High School.She is a Brown Swiss dairy enthusiast, exhibiting her cattle and other livestock at the Damascus Community Fair and Montgomery County Agricultural Fair.Layla was the 2022 Montgomery County Agricultural Fair Queen and is a member and officer of several county 4-H clubs, including beef, poultry, and sheep & swine. The Damascus FFA Chapter member is also a member of the Damascus Livestock Club.Layla works as an animal caretaker for a local farmer.Katie Jones - Upper Chesapeake Dairy Princess: Katie is a junior enrolled in the North Harford High School Agriculture Program, caring for the program's cows, pigs, horses, sheep, and alpaca. The honor student was a regional Robotics and Engineering winner, took top honors in the orchestra and is on the varsity soccer and lacrosse teams. Living on her family's dairy farm, she is responsible for feeding, herding, grazing, field work and more.Katie is an active member of the Girl Scouts of Central Maryland, participating in many community service projects, and is an active member of Trinity Episcopal Church.The new state princess, alternate state princess and team of regional princesses will work together to promote Maryland's official beverage - milk. They will visit fairs, schools, grocery stores, special events and more, sharing their dairy stories about milk, dairy products and the dairy industry.The Maryland Dairy Princess Association sponsors a Dairy Maid program that prepares future princesses and provides promotional opportunities for younger dairy enthusiasts between the ages of 9 and 16 years old.For more information on the Maryland Dairy Princess Program, contact Hope Cencula at mddairyprincess@gmail.com. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a state dairy princess contest that highlights dairy farming, 4-H/FFA involvement, and promotion of the milk industry, making agriculture the primary focus.

title: Maryland dairy princess crowned at fairgrounds
content:
Maryland dairy princess crowned at fairgrounds

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Harford County's Katie Jones captured the Maryland dairy princess title during the 61st annual event on Sept. 1 in the Cow Palace at the Maryland State Fairgrounds in Timonium.Representing the Upper Chesapeake Region, which includes Harford, Baltimore and Cecil counties, Jones will now represent the state's dairy farmers and promote Maryland's official beverage during the coming year at fairs, schools, grocery stores, special events and more, sharing the dairy story about milk, dairy products and the dairy industry.Layla Shepard of the South Central Region will be her partner in promotion as the alternate Maryland dairy princess. Layla hales from Damascus in Montgomery County."Maryland's dairy industry is lucky to have this dynamic team to promote their product and way of life," said Susan Summers, president of the Maryland Dairy Princess Association. "They are trained, professional spokespersons serving as ambassadors throughout the state and will work with our excellent team of younger promoters, Dairy Maids, to celebrate our hard-working dairy farmers and the nutritional products they supply for us all." The 2022-23 Maryland Dairy Princess Morgan Osborn-Wotthlie crowned her successor after a two-day competition filled with interviews, presentations and promotions.Jones received the Best Milk Toast honor and Shepard was awarded the Best Presentation and Scholarship awards.The new State Princess is a 16-year-old junior enrolled in the North Harford High School Agriculture Program, caring for the program's cows, pigs, horses, sheep, and alpaca. The honor student was a regional Robotics and Engineering winner, took top honors in the orchestra and is on the varsity soccer and lacrosse teams. Living on her family's dairy farm, Katie is responsible for feeding, herding, grazing, field work and more. She is an active member of the Girl Scouts of Central Maryland, participating in many community service projects, and is an active member of Trinity Episcopal Church.She is the daughter of Meg and Steve Jones.The new state alternate is an honor roll student and cheerleader at Damascus High School. She is a Brown Swiss dairy enthusiast, exhibiting her cattle and other livestock at the Damascus Community Fair and Montgomery County Agricultural Fair. Layla was the 2022 Montgomery County Agricultural Fair Queen and is a member and officer of several county 4-H clubs, including beef, poultry, and sheep & amp; swine.The Damascus FFA Chapter member is also a member of the Damascus Livestock Club. Layla works as an animal caretaker for a local farmer. She is the daughter of Cathy and James Shepard.Judging the annual contest was Linda Foreman of Durham, North Carolina; Jean Kummer of Evans City, Pennsylvania; and Kirk Sattazahn of Womelsdorf, Pennsylvania. Denny Remsburg of Jefferson served as master of ceremonies.The Dairy Maid program prepares future princesses and provides promotional opportunities for younger dairy enthusiasts between the ages of 9 and 16 years old.Holding those titles are Atley Shafer, Carly Garver and Ella Fell of Frederick County; Annettee Clougherty, Emma Hutchison and Caroline Kimball of the Eastern Shore region; Selah Honkofsky of the South Central region; and Virginia Brooks, Georgia Clisham, Britol Ehrhardt, Harper Rutledge, Abigail Stewart, Madelyn Thomas and Miranda Underwood of the Upper Chesapeake region.The contest can be viewed on the Maryland Dairy Princess Association Facebook page. For more information on the Maryland Dairy Princess Program, contact Hope Cencula at mddairyprincess@gmail.com.

Maryland Dairy Princess Katie Jones, left, representing the Upper Chesapeake region, raises a glass of milk to toast the state's hard-working dairy farmers and Maryland's official beverage, milk, during the Maryland State Fair. Joining her is Alternate Maryland Dairy Princess Layla Shepard, representing the South Central region.

title: Herb growers can learn how to save seeds
content:
Herb growers can learn how to save seeds

 September 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 20 | Section: News 
 
 115
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRINCESS ANNE - Herb growers can get ready for fall by attending a free hands-on class to learn seed saving techniques and what to plant before winter on Saturday, Oct. 7, at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore's Research, Extension and Teaching Farm.The half-day workshop (9:30 a.m. noon) focuses on the use of seed saving screens, how to remove seeds from plants and cleaning methods for seed storage. Led by Henriette den Ouden, a specialty herbs consultant with UMES Extension's Small Farm Program, the class will cover why you should save seeds from herbs and the differences between them and vegetable seeds. Den Ouden has more than 18 years of experience growing and processing herbs.

title: Signups underway for February gardening class
content:
Signups underway for February gardening class

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 412
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As we patiently await crisp fall days, the Upper Shore Master Gardener Programs are preparing for their annual basic training course, which starts on Wednesday, Feb. 7.This program is intended to train volunteer representatives as Master Gardeners for the University of Maryland Extension to extend our services and programs to the public. Classes will be held virtually on Wednesdays from 6 to 9 p.m. and will run through May 8.In-person classes will be held in person every other Friday at Eastern Shore Higher Education Center on the Chesapeake College Campus in Queenstown and are held in conjunction with the University of Maryland Extension in Dorchester, Talbot, and Queen Anne's counties.This well-rounded 40-plus hour course includes classes on: ecology, botany, soils, plant diseases, insects - both pests and beneficial, weeds, and much more. This program emphasizes community involvement and outreach as well as environmental stewardship. A $185 fee is charged to cover all costs including the Maryland Master Gardener Handbook.All Master Gardener interns are required to undergo a University of Maryland background check prior to taking the class. The deadline for registration is Dec. 1. If you need a reasonable accommodation to participate in any event or activity, please contact your local University of Maryland Extension Office by Nov. 17.The University of Maryland Master Gardener vision is a healthier world through environmental stewardship. In keeping with this vision, University of Maryland Extension Master Gardeners volunteers work on a variety of projects in cooperation with local schools, help maintain various public gardens, volunteer at local Senior Centers and assisted living facilities working with therapeutic gardens and hands-on gardening programs, provide community education through free workshops and classes open to local residents and visit home and public gardens as part of our Bay-Wise certification program.For more information about the program, please visit: facebook.com/talbotcountymastergardeners.We are looking forward to working with a new, energetic class of horticulture enthusiasts. To sign up, contact:▪ For Talbot County: Mikaela Boley, Master Gardener Coordinator 410-822-1244 or by email at mboley@umd.edu.▪ For Queen Anne's County contact: Rachel J. Rhodes, Master Gardener Coordinator at 410-758-0166 or by email at rjrhodes@umd.edu.▪ For Dorchester County: Emily Zobel, Master Gardener Coordinator 410-228-8800 or by email at ezobel@umd.edu. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
Master Gardener Volunteers started the Talbot County Free Seed Library to provide access to a source for free seeds, as well as workshops and horticulture support to residents.

title: Queen Anne's Ag Awareness Day lauds essay winners
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's Ag Awareness Day lauds essay winners

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 412
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Students learning the value of local agriculture were recognized for their essays during the Queen Anne's County Public School Board of Education meeting June 5 as the Agricultural Awareness Committee recently hosted its annual Agriculture Awareness Day and essay contest.Seventh grade students were invited to participate in hands-on educational experiences to learn about Maryland's crucial homegrown farming industry as the Agricultural Awareness Committee hosted its seventh annual Agriculture Awareness Day April 9 and 10 at the Queen Anne's County 4-H Park, in Centreville, according to Michael Page, curriculum supervisor.
Understanding where food comes from is a fundamental aspect of the world and a coalition of agricultural educators and professionals joined together to host an invaluable educational experience for all seventh grade students across the county, Page said. The days were filled with numerous agriculture topics and allowed the students to have many hands-on experiences at learning stations lead by industry experts including aquaculture, grain, farm animals, food safety and pollination, he said,
This year in particular focused on the variety of career opportunities available within local agriculture, according to Page.
"Even if it's in ag, you might not be a farmer," said Jenell Eck McHenry of Thompson Ag Consulting Programs.
"Our whole premise of the day is to start to get students to really realize what is agriculture, how does it affect their lives, and so on," he said.
After the two-day event, seventh-grade students penned essays to showcase what they discovered and answer the question, "How did your experience change the way you view agriculture?"
The Agricultural Awareness Committee reviewed the essays and selected the most impactful responses as winners.
The overall winner of the essay contest was Ellamae Athey of Centreville Middle School.
For Centreville Middle School, first place was awarded to Sara Klakring, second place was a tie between Teyauna Johnson and Wyatt Stephens and third place was a tie between Lucas Henderson and JP Tyler.
For Matapeake Middle School, first place was awarded to Delaney Grace Pugh, second place to Vivian Dorsey and third place to Jessica Lynn Busch.
For Stevensville Middle School, first place was presented to Conner Paterno.
Constantly growing, this year's event saw over 100 volunteers dedicating their time and resources including animals to showcase ag awareness to the community seventh graders, said Lee Bridgman University of Maryland Extension Program Assistant Agriculture and Horticulture.
The partnership between the Queen Anne's County schools and the agricultural community continues to make an educating and exciting program and is already looking forward to next year, Page said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on an Agricultural Awareness Day and essay contest for students, highlighting agricultural education and community involvement, making Agriculture the most fitting category.

title: Talbot County Fair opens Thursday
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County Fair opens Thursday

 July 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County fair is back for its 41st year, and residents can come support local organizations and 4-H youth while enjoying the county's rural offerings.The fair will also include games, inflatables, food, vendors and exhibits for attendees to enjoy. Fair committee co-chair Amanda Clougherty said it's a "way for families to connect with each other."
"We're an opportunity for families to make memories and have some fun while supporting a lot of local organizations," Clougherty said. "There's games — our kids' activities area is going to have a lot of things to play with. … It's just a fun evening out."
The fair is held at 10659 Hiners Lane in Easton, home to the Talbot County Agriculture & Education Center. It is open Thursday and Friday from 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. and Saturday from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m.
While there is no fee for entry, Clougherty says they are asking for a $5 parking donation per car.
Cloughtery said Thursday's opening ceremony at 4 p.m. will include a ribbon cutting to begin the weekend fun. A fashion show will help kick things off at 5:30 p.m.
On Friday, the Salisbury Zoo will be at the fair from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m. Clougherty said there will be bingo Friday from 6:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m.
A silent auction for baked goods will also be held Friday. The baked goods will be from 4-H members, and proceeds will benefit the 4-H program.
"It helps to pay for 4-H kids to go to camp, for 4-H supplies and that kind of thing," Clougherty said.
Saturday will include the Chesapeake Classic Car Club's car show beginning at 9 a.m., the Eastern Shore Jousting Association at noon and a watermelon eating contest at 2 p.m.
The fair wraps up with the livestock auction at 7 p.m. on Saturday. Each day of the fair, there are livestock shows open to the public.
The Phillips Wharf Environmental Center's Fishmobile will also be at the fair all three days. It has tanks with animals that live in and around the Chesapeake Bay.
Additionally, the fair and Ag Center will have dinners prepared by different local organizations each night. On Thursday, there will be a pork barbecue dinner by the Talbot County Young Farmers; on Friday, there will be a pork barbecue dinner by the Talbot County 4-H shooting sports program; and on Saturday, there will be a chicken barbecue dinner by Easton High School FFA.
Clougherty sees the fair as a way for county residents to support local organizations and youth while having a fun time.
"I love hearing about people who say we're not going to miss it," Clougherty said.
The fair's full schedule can be found at talbotcountyfair.org/schedule. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the Talbot County Fair held at the Agriculture & Education Center, featuring livestock shows, 4-H youth programs, and other farm‑related activities, making Agriculture the most fitting primary topic.

title: Talbot County Ag Center turns 60
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County Ag Center turns 60

 July 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 522
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On July 23, 1964, Donald Spies, Thomas Meredith and John Mulder signed on as founders of the Talbot County Agriculture & Education Center on Hiners Lane.With decades of 4-H showcases and county fairs under its belt, the Agriculture and Education Center is turning 60.
In partnership with member organizations Easton FFA, Easton Lions Club, Talbot County 4-H, Talbot County Farm Bureau, and Tri-County Ruritan, the Ag Center aims to strengthen rural Talbot County culture and provide agricultural education experiences.
Amanda Clougherty, president of the Ag Center, says it's a team effort to prepare for large events like the fair.
"What makes us unique here is we are independently-owned," Clougherty said. "We are a nonprofit organization. All of our neighboring county fair facilities are all owned by county governments. So we have a lot of things to worry about. We have to worry about facility maintenance, repairs, operations."
As co-chair of Ag Center's fair committee, Clougherty says that the fair has maintained that unique distinction.
"We know who we are," she said. "We're a small, old-time, family-fun outing."
While the center is hosting its 41st county fair this week, it serves the community year-round, not just during fair weekend. It hosts events such as weddings, birthday parties, meetings and workshops.
With no full-time paid staff members, the Ag Center relies on volunteers through community organizations. It makes for a truly unique and personable experience during any event, Clougherty said.
"It's a labor of love and service," she said.
NEW PARTNERSHIPSClougherty says the Ag Center is always open to new relationships throughout the county. For instance, the Rotary Club of Easton recently held its first event at the center to initiate new officers.
Another new partnership is coming this fall, as four soccer fields at the property will house Chapel District Sports' first year of soccer practices and games while Chapel District Elementary School is under construction.
"I just think it's a really good way to expose people to what we do here and build that community connectedness," Clougherty said.
She believes that partnership and similar ones will allow "kids and families to come together." She also mentioned an "ag-accurate book trail" will be on the grounds of the center by this fall, which will feature readings and activities at multiple stations.
IMPROVEMENTSAs the Ag Center grows in its community reach, so has the need for facility improvements. Clougherty pinpointed recent upgrades, including up-to-date electric and a new sound system.
Facility improvements would be completely different without assistance from Maryland 4-H youth, Clougherty said. Through Maryland 4-H's Diamond Clover Award Program, which requires service hours, local youth have transformed the Ag Center.
She said 4-H members have been responsible for rebuilding the outdoor stage, barns, installing fans in the buildings and making benches and the sidewalk accessible.
"We wouldn't be as far as we are today if it hadn't been for several outstanding youth throughout the years," Clougherty said.
It's just one example of how the community gives back to the Ag Center that has long served county residents, particularly youth.
"It's a special gold star for the kids who see the need and work hard to contribute," Clougherty said. "Because they know they've benefitted from being out here." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Talbot County Agriculture & Education Center, its history, agricultural events, 4‑H programs, and community farming activities, making Agriculture the most relevant category.

title: Best in show: 4-H kids work hard to raise, ready animals for fair
author: Lilly Howard Special to the Whig
content:
Best in show: 4-H kids work hard to raise, ready animals for fair

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard Special to the Whig | Section: News 
 
 747
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FAIR HILL — In the months leading up to the Cecil County Fair, 4-H members can be found working hard, raising and training their animals to get them ready for the fair.At the fair, the animals are one of the main attractions, housed in the fairgrounds' barns in between the various competitions and showings that take place throughout fair week.
Tails and Trails 4-H club worked together this year to try something new: raising and showing 100 meat chickens.
"They eat and drink a whole lot more than you would ever imagine at this point. We bought a bag of feed yesterday and we are almost out of it," 4-H member Katilyn Carter said.
Carter, 16, is showing meat goats, meat chickens, and doing herdsmen with her pony. Herdsmen entails keeping your animal at the fair all week, ensuring they are fed, watered, healthy and clean, with a corresponding informational board to educate the public and judges about your animal.
To prepare her meat chickens, Carter washes them two to three days before the show to ensure they have a natural oily shine. This paid off, as her chickens won first and second place ribbons at the fair over the weekend.
"It's going to sound really funny, but you actually blow dry them. You want them to be really fluffy…You just want them to look like little chunk balls of fluff and meat," said Carter about preparing her chickens for show day.
In showmanship competitions, you must be very knowledgeable about your animal in order to show the judges that you put in the work to be successful, according to Carter. The 4-H member must present their animal to the best of their ability, demonstrating cleanliness and knowledge on what they eat, their parts, their breed and more, said former 4-H member and long-time judge Carolyn Lawrence.
For meat goats, who are bred and raised to become a meal on someone's plate, the 4-H members start working with them once they are born in January or March. A few weeks later, once they're weaned from their mothers they start training them to walk with a halter and lead line, taking them on mile long walks several times a week, according to Libby Kondracki, Tails and Trails leader.
When it comes to show day at the fair, Carter washes her goat in the morning and covers him to ensure he stays clean white. Since they're raised for meat, she then blow dries the animals to get them looking as fluffy as possible. According to county fair regulations, no baby powder, artificial coloring, or adhesives like hairspray can be used on the animals.
"The power in fitting your animal, and knowing how to fit your animal and showing your animal to make it to where you know you're showing this animal the best you can to its fullest potential. You really have to work with your goat," Carter said.
Before the fair, members get together at least twice a week and meet up as a show team and prepare together. Many of the 4-H parent leaders were 4-H members themselves when they were growing up. And many current members plan to stay involved after they age out at 18 years old to continue to give back to the community that helped shape them.
"I really love teaching them," said Carter about helping teach younger 4-H'ers. "Because they're going to be, you know, when I'm done in two more years, they're going to be the ones that are taking over. So you really want them to be the mentor you kids that you were to them."
Although many 4-H members compete against each other at the Cecil County Fair, they are all a team at the end of the day.
"When one wins, we all win," said Carter.
In addition to the camaraderie 4-H supplies, it also helps educate the public about the livestock they often consume.
Thanks to being involved in the Rising Sun 4-H Club for the past four years, Mason Gentry enjoys educating the public about his animals and their purposes. For example, he explained the importance of knowing that a Heifer is a female cow who has not been bred yet, a cow is a female cow who has been bred and had a calf, and a Steer is a male cow that's been castrated and is meant for beef.
"The goal of the fair is to educate the public about agriculture, give them an opportunity to see where the food comes from," said Mark Barczewki, 4-H Barn Stompers club leader. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on 4-H youth raising livestock and showcasing them at a county fair, emphasizing farming practices, animal husbandry, and public education about food sources, which aligns most closely with the Agriculture topic.

title: The Caroline/Dorechester fair: a fair too big for one county
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
The Caroline/Dorechester fair: a fair too big for one county

 August 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline/Dorchester County Fair is coming to the Shore. This upcoming week, residents of the two counties and travelers far and wide will come together to experience the fair's many events, including fun games, live music, animal shows and more.Commonly known as "the fair too big for one county," this annual event will be hosted at the Caroline County 4-H Park from Wednesday, Aug. 7, to Saturday, Aug. 10.
The event is put on by 4-H, a youth development organization, and Agricultural FFA Education, a youth agricultural education program.
John "Mitchell" Conneely, president of fair board, said this fair is a generational event. As a kid he would come to this fair and now he sees his children going to the same fair he grew up loving.
Conneely said he enjoys working with 4-H and the effort they put into hosting events for young people.
"Myself and the board members have some connections with 4-H, whether its children or grandchildren in 4-H," Conneely said. "We all try to make the fair bigger and better and with more enjoyment for the community."
Featured entertainment will include Jones Boys, Amish Outlaws and The Reagan Years. The fair will have a mechanical bull, a children's day program, a video game trailer and horse trick riding.
Included events are the Royal Pageant — Fair Little, Princess and Queen; the 4-H Cake Auction; the Youth Alpaca Fun Show; the Dress a Goat Contest; the Greased Pig Contest; a kids pedal tractor; baby contests; a youth pet show and the Livestock auction of 4-H and FFA livestock projects. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Giving to the community — teaching the next generation
author: Staff Writer
content:
Giving to the community — teaching the next generation

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 937
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Henry and Beth Covington have a long history in Queen Anne's County. Both of their families arrived in the United States in the 1700's. Eventually, the Covingtons' settled in Queen Anne's County. Beth's ancestors landed on the Eastern Shore of Virginia and migrated to Mississippi.Henry's great-grandfather, also called Henry, was a Methodist minister at three local churches, Burrisville, Starr, and Salem near Church Hill. His son (Henry's grandfather), Edward, was a preacher and tenant farmer. Henry's dad, Henry Sr., preached for a while, but then began a career with New York Life Insurance.
In 1979, Henry Sr. and his wife Kathryn, bought the Peace and Plenty Farm from the Wright family and started farming. Henry Sr. always said there were two things his father approved of during the year other than work and going to church; attending the 4-H fair and riding to Rehoboth Beach for the day! To get there, all nine kids piled in the back of a 6-wheel truck filled with straw! Henry's mother, Kathryn, was raised on the Richard family farm near Templeville, along with her 12 siblings.
Beth was born in Mississippi where her maternal grandparents, the Dilworths, farmed. She moved to Kent Island at the age of 4, when her dad began working for Maryland DNR. Beth's family also had their faith, it was a big part of growing up and they attended church regularly. After graduating from Chesapeake College, Beth attended the University of Maryland Dental School, earning her degree in dental hygiene.
Henry graduated from the University of Delaware with a degree in Plant Science. Spring of his junior year, he attended a semester at Chesapeake College and met Beth. Henry was recruited by some high school friends at Chesapeake to play baseball. At one baseball practice, Henry noticed one of the softball players. She was wearing red shorts and Henry asked one of his teammates "who is that girl in the red shorts?". Henry was told it was Beth, his friend Earl's little sister. Beth mentioned "since she was a couple years younger than her brother, no one noticed her until college!". After the chance meeting at baseball and softball practice, they dated and were married in 1982.
In 1980, Henry started working at Agrico and Crop Production Services, selling fertilizer and Pioneer seed. Henry had his first opportunity to rent a farm on his own from Gladys Cahall. His grandmother was Cahall's Sunday school teacher so she knew Henry's family very well.
Henry enjoyed farming with his dad for many years. After 10 years, Henry became a full time Pioneer sales rep while also farming over 1300 acres. Henry and Beth dreamed of owning their own farm, and in 2001 that dream came true. They bought a farm near Centreville, and named it Broadland. After 30 years, Henry retired from the seed business in 2021. A good friend, Anton Roe now continues the business as a local Pioneer sales rep. Henry and Beth continue to farm.
Henry and Beth have three children; Will, Ben, and Sarah. Will graduated from Washington and Lee University and is now working as a systems engineer for Communications Electronics Systems Integrated. Ben graduated from Iowa State University. He works for the University and John Deere as an agricultural and biosystems engineer. Sarah graduated from the University of Richmond with a degree in Biology. Sarah teaches biology at Queen Anne's County High School.
Beth had worked off the farm as a part-time dental hygienist for 38 years. This allowed her to take care of the kids and help on the farm. Their three kids were actively involved in 4-H, showing pigs, steers, and rabbits, and entering indoor exhibits. Henry was recruited by Paul Gunther to help with the open farm crops at the fair and to assist the Godfreys with open vegetables. Henry and Beth gladly did this for over 30 years.
After the kids had all left home and Beth retired as a dental hygienist, she had time to work on one of her hobbies, quilting. She said, "My grandmother sewed and taught me to sew. I started out making doll clothes and then made clothes for myself, and later, my kids. After the kids left home, I started to quilt". Beth has been generous in her quilting talents, giving quilts as gifts and donating them to people in need.
About the same time Henry started collecting old tractors. His first was a 1958 John Deere 730. The 730 was one of his favorite childhood toys and 1958 was the year in which he was born. At some point Beth mentioned she would like to have a Farmall cub, like the one she remembered Mr. Ernest Porter owning. Henry found a 1960 cub right away (the same year she was born!) Mr. Ernest Porter was a wonderful Christian man who was very dear to both Henry and Beth. Mr. Ernest Porter was a big influence in Henry's life. "He never seemed to get upset" Henry said. He was also a faithful member of Beth's church on Kent Island.
Henry and Beth consider themselves so very blessed to have had all the experiences that come with living in our farming community. They have thoroughly enjoyed supporting and serving others through their church, 4-H, and school activities. Henry said with a smile "people are generally good and giving back to your community keeps our community close". He said "my father never missed a 4-H Fair up until his passing and I feel the same way. The fair is a good way to stay involved and see people…Everyone should give some of their time to their community. That's how we teach the next generation." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a farming family, their farm operations, involvement in 4‑H, and community service related to agriculture, making Agriculture the most fitting category.

title: County Fair animals teach responsibility to students
author: Tom McCall
content:
County Fair animals teach responsibility to students

 August 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Hundreds attended the family-friendly Caroline/Dorchester County Fair last week, where aimals, corn on the cob, and country music filled the Caroline County 4-H Park.There was a small city of inflatables that was filled with delighted children. For older kids, there was a mechanical bull.
The Reger Pavilion had live music. Everything from the old-timey country sound of the Jone's Brothers to the foot stomping Amish Outlaws and '80s-inflected The Reagan Years.
There were lots of competitions to show younger community members' efforts to raise dairy cows, goats, swines, horses, rabbits and beef.
Jody Neal, Caroline County FFA Advisor and ag teacher at Caroline Career and Technology Center had lots of students participating in fair contests.
"I have nine kids showing animals today. I have kids showing sheep, swine, market goats and breed goats," Neal said.
The students raise their animals for a year leading up to the fair. After all that effort, the animals ended up at the livestock auction on Saturday night. This sale funds the students' project for next year. The pork can go back into the school system and is served in the lunch line.
Skyler Blunt, a participant in the swine competition, said it was rewarding to show a year's worth of work.
"I have two Hereford barrows and one Yorkshire gilt," Blunt said. "The best part is the accomplishment that the fair brings you and getting to show people your project for the year."
Emma Boyle, 18, who had just graduated from high school, said, "I am showing two crossbred pigs. I have been doing this since I was five. I love it. This is my last year. My pigs are named Buzz and Woody."
Barbara Carrow, who was announcing the swine show, is co-leader of Pure Country 4-H Club. She has 62 kids in her Caroline County chapter. They showed at least 50 swine at the contest.
"I love working with young people, and I love animals. It teaches them responsibility and how to interact with adults other people. It gives them confidence," Carrow said.
Wandering in the crowd was a princess — the Dairy Princess.
Caroline Kimball of Queen Anne's County High School wears a sash and a tiara.
"I am the Eastern Shore Dairy Princess because I represent the dairy industry. I like educating people about the dairy industry. You can add a dairy product to all three meals of the day. I like chocolate milk after practice. I want to major in animal science," Kimball said.
The judge, Gabe Zepp of Carroll County, picked first, second and third place winners. With every participant, win or lose, he offered instruction on how to improve.
"I want to see these hogs with their heads up at all times. Head placement. I want to see that they are comfortable with a whip. Nice and in control of the hog," Zepp said.
Navonne Owen, 4-H Educator for Caroline County, said, "They have all worked so hard on their projects and this is the time to shine. They are all doing an excellent job. They are resilient and flexible and they are learning so many life skills from the project. It will help them in the future." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a county fair where students raise livestock through 4‑H and FFA programs, highlighting agricultural activities, animal husbandry, and related education, making Agriculture the most fitting category.

title: Homegrown School Lunch Week celebrates local agriculture
author: CAROLINE COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS
content:
Homegrown School Lunch Week celebrates local agriculture

 October 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAROLINE COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Colonel Richardson Middle School hosted this year's Homegrown School Lunch Week, a statewide initiative that showcases local farms and produce, along with dishes prepared by culinary school students at Caroline Career and Technology.Students, staff and guests tasted samples of everything from farm-to-tray pork to fresh applesauce, all made locally.
Farm to School tastings, facilitated by Caroline County Future Farmers of America students, CCTC Culinary students, and Food Services staff, included:
Zucchini bread made by Shore Gourmet using zucchini from Bartenfelder Farms. Bartenfelder Farms staff also assisted during the events.Maryland crab soup made by the Chesapeake Culinary Center using crab meat from JM Clayton Seafood in Cambridge.Watermelon slushie made by CCTC culinary students using watermelons from Bartenfelder Farms and Little Wagon Produce.Scrapple made by CCTC culinary students. Pigs were raised by CCTC Agriculture students and processed by Sudlersville Meat Market.Applesauce made by CCTC culinary students with apples from Blades Orchard.Cheddar cheese from Chapel Cheese.
Date Caramel dip made by Choptank Community Health served with Redemption Farms apples. Choptank Community Health attended the event as well.
Sliced cucumbers with ranch dip from Clayton Farms.Apple cider from Redemption Rarms.Hydroponics herbs from Red Acres. They also attended with a display showing how hydroponics are grown.Raspberry Yogurt from Nice Farms.
Students, staff and guests also enjoyed a farm-to-table lunch prepared by the Colonel Richardson Middle School Food Services team, which included cherry tomatoes, cucumbers and corn on the cob from Clayton Farms, apples from Blades Orchard, lettuce from Red Acres, bison burgers from Bow Tie Farms and catfish cakes from Tilghman Island Seafood. This menu was also served in all school cafeterias this week.
Simmons said, "Our Food Services staff have always understood the value of serving homegrown, fresh food that supports the health of our students and also supports our farming community. We are are privileged to benefit from our rich agricultural history and the thriving industry that exists today."
Guests at the event included Board of Education Members Chrissy Bartz, Troy Plutschak and Michele Wayman; Superintendent Derek Simmons; Cassie Shirk and Karen Fedor from the Maryland Department of Agriculture; Julie Fletcher from the Maryland State Department of Education Office of School and Community Nutrition Program; Megan D'Arcy from the Rural Maryland Council; and Madison Bryce, intergovernmental affairs liaison with Gov. Wes Moore's office.

title: Touch-a-truck excites as helicopter touches down
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Touch-a-truck excites as helicopter touches down

 October 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TOLCHESTER — Families gathered at the Kent Ag Center, Tolchester, on Saturday for the fourth annual Touch a Truck/ Ag Fest event.Operators of heavy vehicles, trucks, tractors, bucket machinery and fire engines lend their time to help kids experience what it's like behind the wheel of the rigs.
Children got to sound off airhorns and pretend to drive front-end loaders, thrilled with the experience.
"Children love this stuff," Steve Green said, standing beside his 2008 custom made tanker. As owner of Green's Septic, he and his employee of six years Pete Padley enjoy educating kids on the vehicles each year.
Other than the big trucks, local and state emergency personnel were on site giving demonstrations.
Chief Logan Quinn from the Kent County Office of Emergency Services had lifesaving items on display: cardiac heart equipment, CPR devices and a pediatric response bag.
Chestertown Police Chief Ron Dixon presented some everyday tools they use to assist the public: bolt cutters, pry bars and jumper cables.
"When people see these items, we hope they see we're there for the community," Dixon said.
With a generous crowd scattered throughout the large grounds, it was calm, a good environment to learn, talking to equipment operators.
That calm was momentarily shattered at around 11:30 a.m. when a helicopter from the Maryland State Police was spotted hovering over the grounds. As soon as the chopper touched grass, kids and adults made a beeline to it, excited to get a tour.
"It's an impressive bird," said airline pilot of 25 years John Strigle. As a civilian volunteer he had a wealth of knowledge he shared along with the state police operators.
They answered questions, letting kids sit in the Agusta Westland AW139, creating lots of memories and providing parents with photo opportunities.
Other than vehicles, the various Kent County 4-H clubs manned stations running activities for the public to enjoy. The Kent Fuzzy Tails & Shiny Scales group allowed a chance to pet the rabbits, talk to their owners and participate in a prize-winning activity.
Principal Agent Associate, 4-H Youth Development Kent County, Beth Hill, behind an inventive bike/blender making pumpkin smoothies, said these kinds of events help generate new members.
In addition kids participated in a hay bale toss and Tic Tac Toe with pumpkins, while Matt Jones gave hayrides and various organizations like Rock Hall Dental fielded questions at tables.
Co-organizer Cindy Moore said Touch-a-truck came about to show appreciation to the 4-H clubs who maintained the place year-round.
She thanked everyone for showing up that day.
"We all work together on this," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community Touch‑a‑Truck/Ag Fest held at the Kent Ag Center, featuring tractors, farm equipment, 4‑H clubs, and agricultural activities, making Agriculture the most fitting category.

title: Kent Island Community Garden relocates
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Kent Island Community Garden relocates

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A local garden will now find a fresh home in the community as the Queen Anne's County Commissioners approved a lease agreement with Kent Island Community Garden, Inc. for relocation to 210 White Pine Lane in Stevensville Oct. 8.The community garden formerly located in the Harbor View section of Chester used the land next to Galilee Lutheran Church for about ten years, group representative John McKnight said. Following the land sale from the church, the garden had to look for a new home and McKnight reached out to the County Commissioners over the summer for assistance.
Formed in 2015 as the Galilee Community Garden, the Kent Island Community Garden serves the need for a community garden in the Harbor View area of Chester and has since blossomed to include church volunteers, local Master Gardeners, Boy Scout Troop 495 and neighbors of all sorts ready to get their thumbs green.
The community garden also partners with the University of Maryland Extension Master Gardeners Program for educational opportunities.
The garden offers many beds of vegetables, flowers, and a separate herb garden with an irrigation system and compost area.
The Maryland Food Bank cites that one in three Marylanders face hunger. "With several of our gardeners in independent living facilities and one handicapped gardener, we realize how critical it is to establish a new space for our community garden," McKnight said.
Voicing their appreciation for the garden, the county Commissioners approved a $1,500 grant to help the garden blossom at its new location.
The new location's property next to the offices of the Fire Marshal is an ideal location to offer sufficient land for growth along with the necessary utilities as well as close proximity to the Cross-Island Trail, local schools, and the public library.
"It's going to be a great resource for the county," McKnight said.
The Kent Island Community Garden is always looking for new gardeners and civic minded groups to help build garden beds, according to McKnight.
The all inclusive garden stakes claim in having the only handicapped-accessible garden beds in the county, he said.
"We are a diverse and unique group of twenty gardeners and are the only community garden in Queen Anne's County that is open to all, " McKnight said.
Looking ahead, the garden hopes to build a few garden beds before winter sets in and In the spring seeks funds to install a deer fence around the perimeter, he said.
More information about Kent Island Community Garden can be found by contacting McKnight at McKnightJohn143@gmail.com or 202-257-3754. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community garden relocation, detailing planting, horticulture, and food production, which aligns most closely with the Agriculture topic, while also touching on environmental benefits, local government involvement, and educational partnerships.

title: Farming, new administration main topics of Eastern Shore Delegation meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Farming, new administration main topics of Eastern Shore Delegation meeting

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 671
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — On Friday morning, the Eastern Shore Delegation met over Zoom to discuss budgets, the new presidential administration and agriculture on the Eastern Shore.U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) spoke to the state legislators on his excitement for the Trump administration that was sworn in on Monday and the changes that will be made to government spending now that Tesla CEO Elon Musk will co-lead the newly created Department of Government Efficiency.
"I do believe that we have to operate more, and the federal government has to operate more like the private sector does," Harris said. "...Elon Musk is going to do in terms of promoting government efficiency because in the end we cannot continue trillion dollar deficits into the future. We have to control federal spending. We are cursed with without a balanced budget amendment."
Several Republican delegation members at the meeting echoed these sentiments.
Many spoke on the state of Maryland and the amount of federal employees it has, some saying the state is too heavily dependent on federal employment.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said recent actions of some state officials in response to actions taken by the Trump administration do not align with Maryland's needs. He said the state is "trying to find $3 billion" and yet is involved in lawsuits against the federal government.
"The (Maryland) attorney general seems to have plenty of money to want to sue the federal government," Hutchinson said. "Well, at the same time, the state has their hand out to the federal government saying, 'I need money for the Key Bridge. I need more Medicaid money.'"
PRIORITIES FOR FARMERSThroughout the meeting, several representatives and supporters of farmers and agriculture policy spoke, including Tyler Hough, director of government relations for the Maryland Farm Bureau, who shared priorities for the organization for the next fiscal year.
Hough said the bureau has three policy priorities, including private property rights and eminent domain, solar energy, and agriculture education. In his presentation, he focused on the importance of education for the state.
"The opportunity to educate the youth, even get into the middle school areas, the opportunity to have education in the high schools and the FFA (agriculture education) programs and the value that FFA brings along with the 4-H programs that already exist, is just fantastic for these students," Hough said.
Later on the agenda, a presentation was made by members of the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology, an organization centering scientific research, policy analysis and outreach and education efforts.
Kate Everts, executive director of the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology, led the in-depth presentation, in which she highlighted the Maryland Climate-Smart Agriculture Project and the extensive outreach to Eastern Shore farmers that the center has done.
Everts said the farm-centered project seeks to find what agriculture needs to be adaptable and profitable for a future dictated by climate change.
"We're seeing changes in weather across the country, but here in Maryland," Everts said, "how is it impacting our farms and our forests? And again, we want to make sure that they are in a good position to stay economically viable going forward. So we're all about making sure their businesses are successful."
Everts said the research team evaluated potential impacts on local agriculture and conducted outreach with farmers and service providers.
Toward the end of the presentation, Harris shared his appreciation for the work that the Harry R. Hughes Center for Agro-Ecology does for farmers and the importance of keeping them in the forefront of policy and work done for the state.
"It's very good to hear this presentation today because so often what happens in Annapolis is we go up with a lot of emotion, a lot of heart to represent and protect the interests of Agriculture, and what you're talking about, along with other institutions, is bringing science to bear with the lens of the Eastern Shore and certainly throughout the state. The point is through the lens of agriculture, which is so important," Harris said.
The next meeting of the Eastern Shore Delegation will be held on Jan. 31 via Zoom. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on farming, agricultural policy, climate‑smart agriculture projects, and ag education, making Agriculture the most fitting category.

title: Annmarie Garden prepares to build a greenhouse
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Annmarie Garden prepares to build a greenhouse

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 446
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 30-acre tract known as Annmarie Sculpture Garden and Arts Center continues to undergo value-adds, thanks to its many devotees providing stewardship.On March 18, the Solomons facility hosted a groundbreaking ceremony for its greenhouse project.
Annmarie Garden officials stated in a release that the greenhouse "is being built adjacent to our community garden and will be used extensively by the master gardeners and our own horticulture and grounds team."
The community garden is located on a 20-acre tract owned by the Koenig Private Foundation. Last year, Stacey Hann-Ruff, the director of arts center, announced during a presentation to the Calvert County commissioners that Annmarie Garden officials plan to expand the existing sculpture garden to include the 20-acres.
In 1991, Francis and Ann Marie Koenig donated the land where the facility is located. The expansion plans include a 15,000-square foot welcome center.
The Calvert County Master Gardeners program trains volunteer horticulture educators to support the University of Maryland Extension's initiative to educate locals about best horticulture practices.
Noting that the greenhouse project is being supported by state grant money from the Maryland General Assembly, the Rural Maryland Council and the Cove Point Natural Heritage Trust, Edward Goodman, the local master gardener specialist, called the effort "an amazing collaboration."
Goodman told Southern Maryland News there are about 50 active master gardeners. The training course takes about three to four months to complete and is culminated by a final exam. Then, the master gardener candidate must complete 40 hours of community service.
"There are lots of opportunities," Goodman said.
The fledgling master gardeners share their knowledge at such venues as the North Beach Nature Center, Calvert Marine Museum and numerous other locations.
"The biggest thing of the mater gardener program is to educate others on sustainable horticulture practices," Goodman said.
While he couldn't provide a timeline for when the greenhouse would be completed, Goodman said "the project has crossed the hurdle of permitting and processing."
"This is the first step in the [expansion] plan," Cari DeSantis of Ann's Circle, the nonprofit organization that supports many programs and activities at Annmarie Garden.
In briefly addressing the gathering, Bruce Fall of the Cove Point Natural Heritage Trust commended the garden's staff and volunteers "for bringing people in to our area with events."
Fall said the visitors, who come to the garden for such traffic-jamming events as Artsfest and Halloween in the Garden, spend their cash at local restaurants and other businesses, which bolsters the area's economy.
Before grabbing shovels for some fun in the patch of dirt where the new greenhouse will stand, plastic glasses of champagne and cider were distributed to attendees. Everyone drank a toast.
DeSantis said the toast was "to celebrate the public-private partnerships that make Calvert County such a beautiful place." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the construction of a greenhouse, master gardener training, and community horticulture initiatives, which are core aspects of agriculture. Secondary themes include environmental sustainability, educational training, and local economic impact.

title: Sharing, educating, connecting: Agricultural Awareness Day welcomes students
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Sharing, educating, connecting: Agricultural Awareness Day welcomes students

 April 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 258
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A coalition of agricultural educators, professionals and 4-H and FFA youth once again joined together to host an educational experience for students across the county for the eighth Agricultural Awareness Day at the 4-H Park in Centreville April 9 and 10."The long-term success of the agriculture industry depends on engaging and educating the next generation," said University of Maryland Extension Agriculture and Natural Resources Educator Jenny Rhodes.
Agriculture Awareness Day in Queen Anne's County directly addresses this by introducing seventh graders to the wide world of agriculture and its career possibilities. We are dedicated to providing an increasingly interactive and hands-on educational experience each year. The support of University of Maryland Extension educators statewide highlights the collective commitment to this program, and it's inspiring to see our community unite for this vital goal."
Introducing more hands-on activities and student immersion than ever before, experts facilitated stations on the diversity of agriculture across the Delmarva Peninsula, including agriculture's ever-changing technology, food safety, pollinators, grains, aquaculture, animal production and countless career opportunities.
At the career readiness station, Connie Dean, Workforce Development administrator with the county's Economic and Tourism Development welcomed 15 representatives of industries for student interaction.
"It is hands-on experiences like these, as well as this direct connection between students and our workforce/businesses that make such an impact on career awareness of our youth. and their career decision making journey," Dean said.
Over 100 volunteers and partners made the event possible.
"It's the whole agriculture community that comes together," Rhodes said.
Find information about the University of Maryland Agriculture and Food Systems Extension Program online.

title: Ag Education Day teaches students about careers in farming
author: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com
content:
Ag Education Day teaches students about careers in farming

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 604
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Over a thousand Cecil County middle schoolers journeyed to the Cecil County Fairgrounds in Fair Hill last week to learn about agriculture in and around the county as part of the second annual Ag Education Day."Ag education and literacy are two top priorities of our government and agency," said Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks, who attended the event on Wednesday. "Everything starts and ends with food."
Held from Tuesday through Thursday, with two of the county's six middle schools attending each day, the event was a joint effort between Cecil County Public Schools, Cecil Soil Conservation District, Horizon Farm Credit, Maryland Agricultural Education Foundation, Department of Natural Resources and University of Maryland Extension.
Throughout the day, students rotated in groups between twelve different stations spaced throughout the fairgrounds. At each station, volunteers talked to students about various aspects of the agricultural field, from animal sciences to land and water safety to farm drones. Organizers said that approximately 80 professionals volunteered their services during the event.
"It's giving these seventh graders insight to all the careers available in agriculture, not just working in a field," Atticks said.
Based on feedback after last year's Ag Education Day, organizers set out to make this year's event even better. Mel Bacon, Cecil County Farm Museum's executive director and an Ag Education Day board member, said that surveys and an essay contest given to students who attended the event last year helped them hone in on what made the event shine.
He also noted that CCPS has been a huge help in pulling the event off and raising funds
"CCPS has been very supportive," Bacon said.
According to CCPS Instructional Coordinator Day Mashongamhende, CCPS incorporated Ag Education Day as part of its curriculum for the 1,042 middle schoolers in the county this year, which allowed them to embed the event in the schedule and organize lessons around it.
"We teach kids fundamentals," Mashongamhende said. "We see how everything connects."
Mashongamhende also noted that CCPS officials took a trip to the Ag Education Day held in Queen Anne's County earlier this year to incorporate ideas from that event into Cecil's own.
One of the major goals of the event, organizers stressed, is to interest students in the ag industry and show them that there are a wide range of career options available within ag.
Following the event, there are options for students whose interest has been piqued.
"Search out a local 4-H club," recommended Paul Rickert with University of Maryland Extension, one of the event's organizers.
Another option is to enroll in the Ag Sciences programs that the Cecil County School of Technology offers once the students reach high school.
Alongside the adult volunteers staffing the event, a number of CCST Ag Sciences students manned stations and worked with the students at Ag Education Day. The CCST students spoke to kids about the programs they are a part of, giving them a preview into things they could be studying in a few short years.
Students from non-ag programs at CCST also came at lunchtime to speak with students about their own programs, according to Rachel Coffey, an Agricultural Sciences teacher at CCST.
CCST juniors Kaitlynne Harrigan and DeAnna Parker were part of the staff at the beekeeping station on Wednesday. The pair plan to do their capstone project on beekeeping together.
They enjoyed sharing their knowledge with the younger students and watching them get engaged with the subject.
"They're learning a bit of everything," said Harrigan. "It's amazing and I get really happy when the kids ask a question."
Harrigan noted that she didn't know much about ag before beginning at CCST, but finds the field fascinating.
"If I could recommend it to others, I would," Harrigan said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on an Ag Education Day event that introduces middle school students to agricultural careers and practices, making agriculture the primary focus, with education as a secondary aspect.

title: Growing green: Kent Island Community Garden celebrates open house
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Growing green: Kent Island Community Garden celebrates open house

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 211
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The Kent Island Community Garden opened its gates to the public June 14 for its first open house, welcoming about 60 garden enthusiasts to explore the site and its mission of promoting locally grown food and environmental education.Formerly known as the Galilee Community Garden, the new location sits off White Pine Lane in Stevensville, adjacent to the Cross Island Trail and Island Dog Park. The site is fully built and ready for the growing season.
The garden features 18 raised beds for community use, one charity bed for food bank donations, and three specialty education beds planted with native pollinators, flowers, and herbs.
In addition to offering residents a place to grow their own food and contribute fresh produce to local food banks, the garden serves as a hands-on learning space. Through partnerships with the Maryland Department of Agriculture and the University of Maryland Master Gardener Extension Program, it supports educational programs on native plants, beneficial insects, and land management practices that protect the Chesapeake Bay.
"There are life science hands-on opportunities available locally," said organizer John McKnight.
County officials, residents, and Bill Tharpe from the Maryland Department of Agriculture joined the open house to show their support for the project.
More information about the Kent Island Community Garden is available at kicg.online. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community garden that promotes locally grown food, partnerships with the Department of Agriculture, and hands‑on learning about native plants and land management, making Agriculture the primary theme.

title: Kent County 4-H Fair celebrates youth, farming and fun
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County 4-H Fair celebrates youth, farming and fun

 July 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 721
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TOLCHESTER, Md. — The Kent County 4-H Fair drew crowds July 16-19 with animals, contests, food and fun, showcasing the dedication and spirit of local 4-H youth.The fair officially opened to the public Wednesday evening with a prayer from Pastor Josh Rendulic of Hope Fellowship Church, honoring the late Pastor Bill Carroll of Still Pond United Methodist Church.
The ceremony also introduced the county's 4-H clubs, including Bits and Bridles, Kent Clover Calf, Fuzzy Tales and Shiny Scales, Kent Puppy Pals, and Kent 4-H Triple Shots.
The fair is a time for 4-H members to present the hard work they've invested throughout the year, judged by experts across a variety of categories. Livestock competitions — featuring cows, pigs, goats, rabbits, horses, ducks, dogs and chickens — continued into the weekend.
"It's hard work," said Beth Hill, principal agent associate for 4-H Youth Development in Kent County, "but it's also fun for participants and spectators alike. Our 4-H really shined in their project work and in all the other things we look for: teamwork, cooperation, responsibility, sportsmanship, character — even empathy and joy for others."
The 2025 fair theme was "Blue Jeans and 4-H Dreams." New to the lineup this year was a 4-H alumni showmanship event hosted by Kent County Young Farmers, along with the return of the lawn tractor contest.
Animals were a major highlight. Livestock were shown in the main staging arena, while rabbits and poultry had their own exhibition space. Glossy coats, straight backs, brushed fur — even moody horses — were all on display as handlers aimed to show their animals in peak form.
Thursday afternoon brought out tractor enthusiasts for the lawn tractor obstacle course. Under the direction of instructors Mitch and Drew Debnam, youth demonstrated their ability to maneuver a tractor pulling a two-wheel trailer through a series of challenges. The event even drew a visit from vintage tractor puller and former winner.
"I took off work just to come out and support these young fellas," he said.
On Friday, volunteer Jaime Orndorff hosted the fourth Youth Goose and Duck Call competition, judged by bird outfitter Steve Goss. Plaques for winners were provided by Mark Kwiatkowski of All For A Bird. Orndorff expressed gratitude for the support of her sponsors and contributors.
Inside the exhibit hall, judges evaluated everything from cakes to houseplants, herb arrangements, artwork, photography and even corn stalks. Select baked goods were auctioned off Saturday evening, with proceeds benefiting Kent County 4-H and the Kent Ag Center.
Throughout the week, fairgoers enjoyed police K-9 demonstrations, archery, turkey call contests, a cornhole tournament, fashion shows and a carnival of rides and games. Youth from programs like Horizons of Kent and Queen Anne's, as well as local parks and recreation camps, attended as part of their summer activities.
Each night featured live music from performers including Robert MacFarland, Quinn Arnold, Kevin Kemp and the Del-Mar Band. Wednesday night brought out dancers for a session led by local line dance instructor Minnie Maloney.
Food and refreshments were a big draw, with vendors offering fried treats, funnel cake, kettle corn and ice cream. Each evening also featured a full meal sponsored by local businesses, including crab cakes, barbecue beef and grilled chicken.
One of the most anticipated events came Friday night: the greased pig contest. About 200 people surrounded the fence to watch children — from toddlers to teens — chase and try to catch squirming piglets sponsored by local businesses. The event was emceed by Sherrie Spray, who kept the crowd entertained with lively commentary.
Saturday featured the return of the Power Wheels Demolition Derby for children ages 3 to 5. Toddlers, seated in 12-volt toy cars, delighted the crowd as they popped balloons in a playful smash-up competition.
"As always, we ended with the tug-of-war," Orndorff said. "It really is something for everyone."
Hill said the fair went smoothly overall.
"I will say we have the highest 4-H membership in over a decade, and it's very exciting going forward," she said.
Volunteer coordinator Valerie Mason estimated attendance at over 3,000 — slightly down from last year, likely due to the heat. She noted that gate proceeds support the Kent Ag Center and help reinvest in the fairgrounds.
Competition results will be posted online and published in a future edition of the Kent County News.
Hill thanked the community for their support. "We're grateful to everyone who helped make this fair a wonderful experience." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the Kent County 4-H Fair, highlighting livestock shows, farming contests, and youth agricultural projects, making Agriculture the most fitting category.
