llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on closing a funding gap for a community center, discusses fundraising amounts, economic impact of the Boys and Girls Club, and investment returns, making Business/Economy the strongest match.

title: Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business
author: Tom McCall
content:
Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — Zen, mindfulness and alpacas brought over 20 female leaders together on Tuesday.The super soft animals followed the women, who were all armed with green feed buckets, around in a pasture at Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm. This was the site of lunch and learn for the Caroline County Women in Business.
It was a fun moment of delight to see and touch these creatures from the Andes.
"Look at them following her. This is hilarious," Tracey Snyder, director of the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce, said.
"We love the alpaca farm. This is the second time the chamber has been here. Women in Business meets quarterly. We're going to eat a sack lunch from the Culinary Center. We are going to do a little sip and shop and we have Michelle Hammond as our guest speaker. She is going to show us how to be a little more zen in our hectic lives," Snyder said.
Owner of Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm Phil Liske gave a talk on the animal's behavior.
After the animal interaction, it was time to listen to the keynote speaker, healer Michelle Boulden Hammond.
"We are talking about mindfulness today. It is a peaceful forum and how to handle stress today. Some spiritual message like how to learn about frequencies. Learn about how to get yourself grounded. We will learn stress management techniques," Hammond said.
She said it is even beneficial for the animals and their frequencies. She specializes in sound healing.
"We are going to do a little breath work. I have got my sound bowls. I got my tuning forks and I have my ocean drum. So I will give a little demonstration. I have a brass and I have a crystal bowl," Hammond said.
She also had a comment on the current moment.
"In these times of high stress, there is a lot of hostility. You have got to learn to get grounded and centered. Always reflect the negativity with the goodness," Hammond said.
One participant was Nikendra Bordley, who runs the hair salon Scalp Reveals in Federalsburg. She specializes in dreadlocks.
"I love it. It is a new experience," she said about the event Tuesday. "I have never seen alpacas. I have only known of llamas. I like seeing everybody getting together and the other Chamber members." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a Chamber of Commerce‑organized lunch‑and‑learn event for women in business, focusing on networking, professional development, and mindfulness, which aligns most closely with the Business/Economy topic.

title: Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As Eastern Shore legislators prepare to cross the bridge and return to Annapolis for the first day of the Maryland General Assembly's 2025 legislative session on Wednesday, the state's budget is top of mind."It's just a tough time right now, and we're going to have to be very cautious and very thoughtful of the citizens and the impacts that our citizens are feeling," Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
The state is facing a predicted $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Jacobs said when it comes to the budget process this year, he thinks everything will be on the table. "The devil is in the details," he said.
"We're certainly — on the Shore — fiscal conservatives concerned with any cost increase, any tax increase or any cost toward citizens," Jacobs said.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he hopes state Democrats realize that some state goals, such as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and some climate initiatives, are unrealistic and need to be reexamined.
"So I hope there's some reality checks," he said.
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R- Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said the state has overspent. He said although House leadership seems to be ok with raising taxes to balance the budget, the governor might not be "comfortable" with that.
Ghrist said he expects to see a "clash" in the Democratic Party regarding the budget.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) sees this legislative session as a "defining" one for Gov. Wes Moore (D).
"He's going to have to balance this out within his own party," Mautz said about Moore. "Because the policies that are in place now that have caused these economic problems largely come from the Democratic Party and Democratic leadership."
BLUEPRINT FOR MARYLAND'S FUTUREThe Blueprint for Maryland's Future is another issue that legislators on the Shore expect to be one of the top issues this legislative session.
The Blueprint — a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and education quality across the state — has garnered some concern across the state due to funding challenges.
Hutchinson said that with a budget shortfall, the state should be "pulling back" on the Blueprint. He said the plan has "been devastating" to counties across the state.
Jacobs said he thinks this legislative session will result in adjustments to the timeline of certain Blueprint goals.
"I don't think that they're going to do away with Blueprint by any means," he said. "I just think that there may be some changes in the timeline of different parts of it."
Mautz said "something has to happen" with the Blueprint. He said he isn't sure if legislators will create bills "to address the damage that's been done" or create bills that put pauses on the plan.
ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTFrom solar energy to electric vehicles, Eastern Shore legislators see energy and environment issues as important heading into this legislative session.
Ghrist called the state's renewable energy goals "virtually impossible to achieve." He said he has concerns about who is controlling where solar energy systems are being placed in the state. He plans to put out "several" bills that address solar energy.
"Our number one industry is agriculture and it's being threatened right now by solar," he said.
Jacobs said he has heard that there have been some "serious conversations" about expanding nuclear energy in the state. He said he hopes state leadership and legislative committees that deal with energy issues will look more into nuclear energy and figure out if it's a direction the state should be going in.
When it comes to electric vehicles, Hutchinson said he doesn't think the state has the capacity for its electric vehicle initiatives.
"There's not enough power stations to be able to charge them," he said. "And based upon what I'm hearing from our local dealers, there's not a market for them and they want to stay with combustible engines."
Hutchinson said he expects a lot of debate this session.
"And again, I hope that we see some reality coming that we can't continue to afford to spend and that we have to make sure we address this $2.7 billion short fall that's going to get worse and worse each year if we don't do anything today," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the state budget deficit, fiscal policy, and economic implications of legislative decisions, making Business/Economy the most fitting category, with Education and Environment as secondary themes.

title: State of State ignores Eastern Shore realities
author: JOHNNY MAUTZ
content:
State of State ignores Eastern Shore realities

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHNNY MAUTZ | Section: Columns 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Moore's recent State of the State address painted a rosy picture of Maryland's future, but as your state senator, I need to be straight with you about where we really stand.Maryland currently ranks 43rd in economic outlook and faces a staggering $3 billion deficit that could balloon to $7 billion by 2030. This crisis wasn't created by Gov. Hogan or the Trump administration — it's the predictable result of expensive, unfunded policies and overregulation pushed through by the Democratic supermajority in Annapolis.
The most glaring omission from the governor's hourlong speech? The crushing cost of living hitting Eastern Shore families right now, especially those sky-high utility bills. His solution is to raise taxes on businesses and high earners, but we all know those costs always find their way down to workers, consumers, and our local businesses.
Let's break down what's really happening in Annapolis:
Instead of cutting wasteful programs, the governor wants to raise taxes and increase spending. Maryland already has one of the worst tax burdens in the country. His budget talks about job creation but ignores how businesses keep fleeing to states with lower taxes and fewer regulations.
The governor doubled down on the Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a massive unfunded mandate our counties and state can't afford. His proposed $1.6 billion in savings falls woefully short when we're facing a $4 billion annual shortfall to implement it.
Rather than working to control costs, the state has unleashed almost universal increases for licenses and other fees, accompanied by aggressive property tax assessment increases. Aspirational environmental mandates are being reenforced rather than reexamined, while they continue to drive costs. This includes their enormous impact on agriculture in comparison to the meager and in many instances, unmeasurable benefits. Meanwhile, the economy on the Chesapeake Bay has been strangled by poor management strategies that range across the board from the blue crab fishery to migratory waterfowl.
Here are a couple immediate actions to cut costs: eliminate thousands of funded, vacant positions; repeal costly mandates in the Blueprint that have not been implemented; cut wasteful spending like the Red Line Study and mass transit; and stop the new $2 billion annual payroll tax for paid family leave. Finally, there must be some incentive for agencies to save money rather than exhaust budgets to ensure they are funded in the following year.
Meanwhile, crime is a very real problem in Maryland and while ending recidivism is essential, the lack of attention and urgency over repeat offenders is alarming. The Eastern Shore way has always been practical and commonsense, there are options that support economic growth, environmental and educational improvement, and promote public safety without breaking the bank. That's what we should be supporting — not costly mandates from Annapolis. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The column focuses primarily on Maryland's fiscal deficit, tax policy, budget priorities, and economic impact on businesses and families, making Business/Economy the strongest match.

title: Shore legislators worry about tax hikes, energy, education in the wake of General Assembly
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Shore legislators worry about tax hikes, energy, education in the wake of General Assembly

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland General Assembly session officially ended Monday night. Lawmakers fought through a very tough fiscal year budget, which had some significant impacts for Eastern Shore communities, legislators said.Members of the Eastern Shore delegation stressed budget difficulties loom over state lawmakers, who spent much of this year's session tackling an over $3 billion deficit.
"I think the session was not a good session," Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "We've just made Maryland a very expensive, more expensive than it was, and it's going to make us less competitive in the region.
"If you believe that economic competitiveness is in fact a priority, I think that it is, and I think that by raising taxes and fees, both at the state level and then forcing the locals to also increase their fees and taxes is a double whammy."
Maryland lawmakers passed a balanced budget Monday, concluding their spring session after months of grappling with the deficit. The final budget included about $2 billion in cuts and about $1.6 billion in tax hikes.
"I think we left frustrated that we had to raise taxes $1.66 billion and there was no regard to wanting to really seriously cut expenses from the state budget," said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe after this year's session, the Shore will see lasting effects both fiscally and in several key industries.
Solar
One of the biggest concerns for the Mid-Shore this budget session has been solar energy.
A renewable energy bill aimed at increasing generation of energy within the state by promoting solar energy production was passed by both chambers of the state legislature.
Some Eastern Shore Delegation members feel provisions added to these bills during legislators' deliberations supersede counties' authority regarding solar permitting and regulation.
"It undermines all the work that the counties have already done to try to facilitate where and how to put solar," Mautz said. "It includes a new assessment for planting solar, which is going to raise energy costs."
Hutchinson echoed this sentiment, saying, "It falls on deaf ears that the Democrats from Montgomery and Prince George's county all think that they know how the quality of life is here on the Eastern Shore."
Utility bills
House Bill 1035 and Senate Bill 937, known collectively as the "Next Generation Energy Act," include plans to reduce energy bills and address shortfalls by modernizing the state's energy infrastructure and incentivizing in-state energy production.
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe this effort to get the cost down lacked the immediacy rate payers need to address bill hikes.
"We have not addressed the number one complaint I received when I arrived in January," Hutchinson said, "rate payers calling to say that their electric bills are astronomical. We put legislation forward to try to lower utility bills, and again, it falls on deaf ears."
Education funding
The Blueprint for Maryland's Futue, the state's education improvement and funding initiative through 2032, originally outlined an increase in teacher collaborative time, during which teachers are not in classes and can plan, grade or meet with students individually. But with adjustments made in the state's budget to combat the deficit, funding to implement the change has been postponed.
The Blueprint also sustained several other cuts and freezes that impact county finances. Multiple Mid-Shore county school boards have had to make budget cut decisions and potential layoffs in response.
"So let me take Dorchester County, for example," Hutchinson said. "They pushed down the teachers' pensions. They pushed down the Blueprint. They pushed down other mandates that the state usually paid for, but now it's all the county, they have to pay for (it)."
"The school board is short about $5 million. They just eliminated summer school," he said. "They're looking at having to lay off student support personnel. They say we want to create a world-class education. Yet you look at the results of what's happening in Maryland and say that doesn't make sense."
Potential special sessions
While the 2025 session has ended, Mautz doesn't believe discussion is officially over.
As the federal government continues to shift funding priorities, state legislators may need to reconvene to address any impacts this has on the balanced budget, he said.
"Counties are probably going to have to raise revenue through taxes and different things," Mautz said. "The federal government is probably going to continue to reduce spending. Then there's a high likelihood that we're going to have a special session."
"So we would have to go back to Annapolis again to address any changes that that come from federal spending reductions. Just as the federal government is reducing its spending, the state is doing the same thing to the counties, and so where all this ends, it seems to be, taxpayer, taxpayer, taxpayer.
"Everybody should know it's very hard to predict how this is all going to play out, but I don't think the discussion about the budget is is officially over." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on state budget decisions, tax hikes, fiscal deficits, and economic competitiveness, which align most closely with Business/Economy. It also touches on local government impacts and education funding, but the primary emphasis is on economic and budgetary issues.

title: Court rules digital ad tax violates First Amendment
author: BRYAN P. SEARS Maryland Matters
content:
Court rules digital ad tax violates First Amendment

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRYAN P. SEARS Maryland Matters | Section: State News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A provision in Maryland's digital ad tax is an unconstitutional restriction on free speech, a federal appeals court ruled Friday.The 2021 law — the first of its kind in the nation — imposes taxes on large tech companies for the digital ads they sell within the state. But it prohibits those companies from passing the tax on to consumers as a surcharge, fee or line item on their bills — what a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals saw as a ban on telling customers about the new added tax.
In a ruling that invoked American protests against the Colonial-era Stamp Act, Circuit Judge Julius Richardson wrote that, as then, "complaining about taxes remains a grand American political tradition." And the court said Maryland lawmakers went too far by adding language to the tax bill that was intended to shield them from public criticism.
"Perhaps fearing such complaints, Maryland paired its tax with another rule," Richardson wrote for the court. "Companies that make money advertising on the internet must not only pay the tax, but avoid telling their customers how it affects pricing: No line items, no surcharges, no fees.
"If companies pass on the cost of the tax, they must do so in silence — keeping customers in the dark about why prices have gone up and thereby insulating Maryland from political responsibility," he wrote.
The ruling reverses a 2024 decision by U.S. District Judge Lydia Kay Griggsby, who agreed with the plaintiffs — a group of tech firms and business associations — that the law created some First Amendment issues. But she let the law stand because the offending provision had "many constitutional applications."
Friday's circuit court ruling sent the case back to Griggsby with instructions to determine an appropriate remedy for the plaintiffs.
The ruling is a blow to officials who looked to the unique tax to help pay for expensive K-12 education reforms contained in the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. Expenses associated with that law continue to rise and are potentially budget busting — even if the digital ad tax survives the onslaught of legal challenges.
The 2021 law — sponsored by Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) — targets big tech firms including Apple, Meta and Google.
Under the law, companies reporting $100 million of gross global annual revenue are subject to a 2.5% levy. The tax increases in increments of 2.5% to a maximum rate of 10% levied against companies reporting more than $15 billion in gross global revenue.
The state could collect as much as $250 million annually from the digital ad tax, according to a legislative analysis. The funds are earmarked for the education reform program.
Neither Ferguson nor Comptroller Brooke Lierman (D), the defendant in the lawsuit, immediately responded to requests for comment on the ruling Friday. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a legal challenge to Maryland's digital ad tax, a fiscal policy affecting large tech companies and revenue earmarked for education. The primary focus is on the tax's business and economic implications, making Business/Economy the best fit, with Education as a secondary relevance.

title: QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable

 September 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Local manufacturing representatives gathered to hear about available resources and opportunities to connect during a Manufacturers Roundtable with the Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development at Chesapeake College Aug 28.Collaboration is the key to economic and workforce success, and QACETD welcomed manufacturers, county officials and regional partners for open dialogue on training initiatives, grant resources, technology adoption, supply chain resilience, and policy support as well as a tour of Chesapeake College's Advanced Manufacturing Program.
Serving as the voice of manufacturers across industries and regions of the state, Maryland Manufacturing Extension Partnership is a nonprofit focused on growing and strengthening Maryland manufacturers.
Maryland MEP Executive Director Mike Kelleher said finding, recruiting and keeping qualified talents is the number one challenge faced by manufacturers.
There is no one-size-fits-all for training and Maryland MEP has a number of programs to support honing qualified talent and helping companies apply and find services and programs, including specific to rural manufactures, he said.
"It is important to improve the skills of the people," Kelleher said.
Providing a glimpse into what manufacturing officials are seeing out in the field, open discussion shared challenges in recruiting and marketing the availability of quality local jobs especially for a younger generation, as well as a lack of affordable housing and transportation.
QACETD Workforce Development Administrator Connie Dean stressed the power of connecting local business with local youth.
The county's Workforce Development supports opportunities for youth on-the-job training and experiences, especially those in technology and trade industries and since the implementation of high school career coaches, workforce development has increased the number of students in "career focused internships," Dean said.
Understanding students can't get interested about an industry they don't know about, this year, the department is moving forward to bring local industries to the students, with more career fairs and field trips to visit manufacturing areas in person, Dean said.
Partnering with QACTV, the department also highlights business and local field opportunities with career awareness videos to present in schools and online at QACTV.com.
Encouraging local industries to get involved with workforce development, "It's important to let people know what the business is," she said.
More information about QAC Economic and Tourism Development can be found at choosequeenannes.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a manufacturers roundtable, economic development, workforce training, and grant resources, which aligns primarily with Business/Economy, with secondary relevance to Education through workforce development initiatives.

title: AI course offered for business owners, managers
author: Staff Writer
content:
AI course offered for business owners, managers

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 296
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eastern Shore business owners are encouraged to participate in a free, first-of-its-kind artificial intelligence online training series for local businesses this fall.The two-part online program takes place Oct. 27–28 from 6 to 8 p.m. via Zoom and marks the first time the economic development departments of Dorchester, Caroline, Talbot and Worcester counties, along with the Mid-Shore Regional Council, have partnered on a training initiative of this kind.
The training will give entrepreneurs and business owners practical tools to integrate AI into marketing, sales, lead generation, fundraising, operations and proposal writing.
Cassandra Vanhooser, director of Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism, recently completed an AI certification course through Johns Hopkins University and says the timing could not be better for local businesses to embrace these new tools.
"This partnership allows us to bring high-level, practical training to entrepreneurs across the Eastern Shore, free of charge," Vanhooser says. "It's an unprecedented opportunity to make sure our local businesses aren't left behind, especially as this technology becomes essential for growth and competitiveness."
Consultant Will Holmes, who facilitates the program, emphasizes that the program's purpose is to demystify AI and empower business owners with practical strategies they can implement immediately.
"AI is no longer a futuristic concept. It's a present-day tool that can dramatically accelerate growth," Holmes says. "By breaking down what can often feel like a complex or intimidating subject, we're helping entrepreneurs gain a clear understanding of how AI can drive results for their businesses."
The AI training series reflects a broader regional commitment to fostering innovation and economic vitality. By combining expertise and resources, the partners are delivering an accessible program that would otherwise be cost-prohibitive for many small and midsized businesses.
Eastern Shore business owners and entrepreneurs are encouraged to register for the free online training sessions. Registration is available at talbotworks.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

It also involves educational content, but the primary focus is on supporting the business community.

title: Dorchester Dems hosts climate change forum
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester Dems hosts climate change forum

 August 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 637
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Electric school buses and creating recycling education programs were discussed at a Dorchester Democratic Party forum as possible solutions to address climate change locally.More than 20 people attended the Aug. 2 event, both via Zoom and in person at the organization's headquarters in Cambridge. The forum included a presentation by Cambridge resident and environmental advocate Susan Olsen, a Q & A and a moderated discussion.Olsen's presentation outlined what climate change is and its affects on the Eastern Shore before diving in to discuss Maryland's Climate Solutions Now Act of 2022."We are doing a great job in Maryland," Olsen said. "The Climate Solutions Now Act of '22 is the most ambitious greenhouse gas reduction program in our country." The act requires the state to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions through setting new goals and developing emissions reduction requirements.Olsen said environmental justice is a large part of the environmental bills being passed.She said the Climate Solutions Now Act uses tax incentives to encourage community solar for low and moderate income Marylanders.Community solar gives utility customers who rent or are unable to purchase solar panels the option to power their homes with solar energy through a subscription, according to the Maryland Office of People's Counsel."It's wonderful," Olsen said. "It really is." Olsen ended her presentation by sharing how residents can be a part of the solution in Dorchester County and on the Eastern Shore.She mentioned tree grants from the state's 5 Million Trees Initiative. The grants can pay for trees that are planted in public areas. Olsen said that folks who are interested in getting involved with planting trees can look into the ShoreRivers Tree Stewards program.Other ways to get involved include joining environmental groups or lobbying for the implementation, compliance and enforcement of the Climate Solutions Now Act.Olsen also talked about her experience trying to get Dorchester County Public Schools on board with electric buses. She said the Environmental Protection Agency has been giving out grants to school districts to trade in their diesel school buses for electric, propane or low-emission buses."Last year, we were a priority district," Olsen said about Dorchester County Public Schools."They would pay the full cost of the buses." However, Olsen said the Dorchester County Board of Education decided against switching to zero-and low-emission buses.Maris Wicker, who attended the forum, said she remembers when the Board was discussing this."I was very disappointed to learn that there was not a move toward electric buses," Wicker said. "I thought it could have been a great learning moment for kids riding school buses." Olsen said that while Dorchester County is no longer a priority district for this grant - meaning the EPA would only fund a percentage of the cost of each bus-it is still possible for the district to get involved with the program.Sarah Gavian, chair of the Dorchester Dems Committee, said she could see a group of advocates coming together for this issue."I think there probably is a lot of momentum around things that could be done to support at least understanding what Dorchester can win and lose from (with electric) school buses," Gavian said. "I think (we could) probably find some advocates in this room to work with Susan on this." Forum attendees also talked about how to improve and increase recycling in the area.During her presentation, Olsen said that recycling correctly can decrease the amount of methane, a greenhouse gas, in landfills.Miriam Zijp said that when it comes to recycling in Dorchester County, the problem is information."People don't know how to recycle," Zijp said. "But they don't get taught." Zijp suggested creating programs to teach children how to recycle."You have to start somewhere," she said. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Mary Dennard-Turner talks about recycling at a forum on climate change hosted by the Dorchester Dems on Aug. 2 at the organization's headquarters in Cambridge. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a climate‑change forum discussing electric school buses, recycling programs, and state environmental legislation, making the environmental focus the strongest match.

title: CCC Corps class graduates at CBEC
author: Doug Bishop; dbishop@kibaytimes.com
content:
CCC Corps class graduates at CBEC

 August 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Bishop; dbishop@kibaytimes.com | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE - More than 30 participants in the Chesapeake Conservation and Climate Corps graduated Tuesday, Aug. 15, in a ceremony held at the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Center in Grasonville.This was the first class since the expansion to include climate change work in the Corps."Maryland has just taken a bold step toward comprehensive bay restoration with the announcement of the Moore-Miller administration's Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Improvement Strategy.We are counting on Corps members and alums to play a key role in helping us reach the goals outlined in the Governor's executive order to better protect the Chesapeake Bay, our state, and our planet," said Maryland Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller. "The growth of this program is essential; it not only addresses the urgency required by an escalating climate crisis, but it closely aligns with our administration's commitment to service and to empowering our youth to gain real-world professional skills." The Class of 2022-2023 was made up of students from Allegany, Anne Arundel, Caroline, Howard, Montgomery, Talbot, Washington and Worcestor counties and Baltimore City.They were addressed briefly by seven special guests: Miller, Comptroller Brooke Lierman, Maryland Senate President William Ferguson, Maryland Senator Pamela Beidle, Maryland Energy Administration Director Paul Pinsky, BGE Sr. Vice President Alexander Nunez, and Chesapeake Bay Trust President Dr. Jana Davis. Each speaker touched on the potential each of the graduates have to continue the fight to protect Maryland's environment and the restoration efforts of the Chesapeake Bay.Pinsky told the graduates, "Never doubt what you can do to change things for the better. A group of young people in Wyoming brought action in court to protect the environment there. Those young people are the same ages you are. You do the same thing they did, if the cause arises." Beidle also focused on the power of individuals. Quoting Margaret Mead, she said, "The power and influence of one person has always been the force for change throughout history." The CCCC was created by the Maryland General Assembly in 2010. It is administered by the Chesapeake Bay Trust. The multi-faceted expansion of the program to include more intentional climate work is possible due to the additional $1.5 million per year investment from the State of Maryland.CCCC provides career and leadership training for young people interested in environmental careers.Corps members are matched with non-profit and government host organizations and receive firsthand training on a wide variety of topics on the realms of climate, energy, watershed restoration, agriculture, forestry and education."The goal of our Corps program is to create future generations of environmental stewards who are poised to address climate change and other environmental challenges, either in their personal or professional lives or both," Davis said. "I am so proud of these amazing young people. Their efforts not only serve the environment, but also boost local economies and revitalize often underserved neighborhoods." The 55 selected 2023-24 Chesapeake Conservations and Climate Corps participants will serve this year in Anne Arundel, Charles, Calvert, Garrett, Howard, Kent, Montgomery, Prince George's, Talbot and Worcester counties, and Baltimore City. 
 
 Caption: DOUG BISHOP/BAY TIMES AND RECORD OBSERVER
 
Members of the 2022-2023 Chesapeake Conservation and Climate Corps receive the symbolic golden shovel from previous graduates following their graduation, Tuesday, Aug. 15, at the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Center in Grasonville. title: Pickering Creek Gets New Interpretive Panels - Life
content:
Pickering Creek Gets New Interpretive Panels - Life

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 792
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Pickering Creek Audubon Center is a 450-acre nature center in Talbot County, which is open to the public daily with no admission for exploring on our trails.The center is a primary provider of outdoor science experiences for school systems on the Eastern Shore.Visitors to the Center on a daily basis use Pickering Creek's Farm to Bay Trail, which is 2.5 miles in length. The Farm to Bay Trail winds its way through cool season grass meadows, warm season grass meadows, brackish wetlands, freshwater wetlands, pine forest, emergent hardwood forest, mature hardwood forest and gives up close views of agriculture on Delmarva on a working farm.While exploring the habitats, about half of the trail borders agriculture fields while the other half borders brackish Pickering Creek.The trail affords a rare opportunity to experience most of the rural, coastal plain's habitats in one place coexisting with agriculture successfully. Interpretive panels along the Farm to Bay Trail tell the story of Delmarva's key ecosystems and species.In the fall of 2022, Pickering Creek received a grant from the Rural Maryland Council to support creation of new messaging and new artwork for nine interpretive panels. People visit places like Pickering Creek Audubon Center to learn, explore, find adventure, relax and exercise.Interpretive panels help give meaning to the visitors experience by telling the story of the land: past, present and future. Interpretive panels help draw connections between habitats, plants, wildlife and people.The panels highlight the key habitats along the Center's Farm to Bay Trail, which include forest, wetland, meadow, agriculture and brackish water creek. Through the panels we tell the story of key habitat features, flora and fauna through both concise written messages and compelling visuals. Panels help the visitor understand the interconnected nature of land and water on Delmarva.The panels replace aging panels that have been weathered by the sun and rain. None of the existing panels were replicated, so each of the nine panels shares a brand new story about the center, its wildlife and habitats. In addition to replacing existing panels, the new panels fill in spots along the trails that have not been previously highlighted.Over the course of the past year, center staff researched, designed, contracted fabrication and installed nine interpretive panels. At the Center's entrance parking area you will now be greeted by a timeline history of the center that explains its donation and evolution over time.New panels along the Farm to Bay Trail highlight songbirds in the woods, no till agriculture, the importance of forested buffers between land and water, fungi of the woods and birds seen on the creek.New panels along the Wetland and Meadow Trails highlight which amphibians you are likely to see and hear, the importance of milkweed in meadow communities, and bluebird boxes and their benefits."Pickering Creek is unique as a nature center in that we are also agricultural landowners. As the Olds Family who donated the center's core property wished we continued to highlight agriculture as part of the landscape on Delmarva while also sharing how conservation practices coexist with great habitat for wildlife," said Center Director Mark Scallion.Pickering Creek is open to the public daily during daylight hours. Check the center website for exact open times as evening daylight gets shorter this fall.There are several viewing platforms and blinds along the way for you to enjoy scenery and wildlife.Benches for resting are spread throughout the trails. The new panels join seven existing panels that have been installed in the last five years in both wetland and meadow habitats.Together they share the story of outdoor habitats and ecosystems and the creatures we share them with on Delmarva. 
 
 Caption: Keep an eye out for mushrooms growing high on trees!
 
Species like this Dryad Saddle (right) or Cracked Cap Polypore (above) can grow dozens of feet off the ground on standing snags.
 
"There is Fungus Among Us" is one of the new interpretive panels.
 
Some species of fungus grow directly in the ground. These species, like this Russula species (above), are seeking nutrients like nitrogen that are already in the soil and therefore don't need to grow on wood.
 
Look around our forests and you'll find some kind of mushroom. Coming in all colors of the rainbow, most mushrooms are easy to see but they are only the fruiting body of the fungus or mycelium. Mycelium, which look like thin roots or strands of hair, help to break down organic material like leaves and wood for food which recycles the nutrients back into the soil for other plants!
 
Check fallen logs for mushrooms. Many mushrooms like the False Turkey Tails (right top) and Bonnet species (right below) can only grow out of dead wood so fallen logs and branches are crucial! 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a nature center, habitats, wildlife, and ecosystem interpretation, which aligns most closely with the Environment topic, while also touching on educational outreach and agricultural context.

title: Head Of Environmental Science Center Retiring
content:
Head Of Environmental Science Center Retiring

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - After a 40-year career in science and higher education culminating in leading Maryland's university for the environment, University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science (UMCES) President Peter Goodwin retires at the end of September. He has been leading the university's commitment to unbiased scientific research and public service while developing the next generation of environmental scientists since 2017."The University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science is a very special community within a unique institution driven by a common mission driven by truly exceptional researchers and staff," Goodwin said. "It has been the honor of a lifetime to lead UMCES toward its second century of impact in Maryland and around the world."An internationally known expert in ecosystem restoration, he has championed bringing together the best available science around issues of coastal resilience, oyster recovery, ecosystem management, and using large-scale environmental data in decision-making to Maryland. As part of UMCES' longtime role to advise the state on Chesapeake Bay management and restoration programs, he has served an integral role on the Governor's Chesapeake Bay Cabinet, as well as lead science advisor on the Maryland Commission on Climate Change. He has been a consistent leading voice associated with expanding Diversity, Equity and Inclusion initiatives not only within UMCES but throughout the environmental sciences."President Goodwin's leadership of UMCES has been vitally important to the state and to the nation, as the science coming out of his institution guides the approach to our shared environmental and climate challenges," said University System of Maryland Chancellor Jay A. Perman. "President Goodwin's compelling vision for UMCES, his skill in developing the next generation of talented and diverse environmental scientists, his well-earned influence in Annapolis, which advances better policy and practice - all of it will be greatly missed. I thank him for the exceptionally strong foundation he's laid for UMCES' dynamic future."A globally eminent research institution aimed at advancing scientific knowledge of the environment, UMCES has a unique mandate from the state of Maryland to conduct scientific research and provide sound advice to help leaders manage Maryland's natural resources. Since its establishment in 1925, UMCES has played a key role in expanding our understanding of the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem and is known for tracking progress on its restoration.UMCES addresses some of the most pressing environmental challenges facing society nationally and internationally and prepares future scientists to meet the global challenges of the 21st century through the Marine Estuarine and Environmental Sciences (MEES) graduate program, as well as other educational offerings."On behalf of the Board of Visitors, we have greatly enjoyed working with Peter to advance UMCES these years. He has moved this institution forward in so many ways," said outgoing Board of Visitors Chair Charlie Monk. "Thank you for giving us the opportunity to share our ideas and support your vision for this unique institution."Perman has appointed longtime UMCES Vice President Bill Dennison as interim president, effective Sept. 25. He will serve in that capacity until a permanent replacement is named by the Search and Screening Committee appointed by the USM for the UMCES, one of the university system's 12 institutions. 
 
 Caption: AMY PELSINSKY/UNIVERSITY OF MARY LAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE
 
University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science President Peter Goodwin retires after 40 years in science and higher education. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lawrence Wetlands Preserve officially opens in Chestertown
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Lawrence Wetlands Preserve officially opens in Chestertown

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - It took the efforts of county, state, and federal governments to make Michael Lawrence's dream of children learning in the outdoors a reality. The Sultana Education Foundation held a ribbon cutting ceremony for its new Lawrence Wetlands Preserve this week.Drew McMullen, President of the Sultana Education Foundation located in Chestertown, said the educational programs provided by the foundation show how the Chesapeake Bay includes wetlands, shoreline, and now the watershed. "We can now show the connection between land and water," he said.Under development since 2017, the Lawrence Wetlands Preserve is an 8.5-acre urban nature center that features a variety of ecosystems including upland forest, swamp, marsh, shrublands, meadows, and a freshwater pond. In addition to its natural elements, the property boasts an accessible trail network, wetland boardwalk, viewing platforms, an activity field, and the 1,200-square-foot Harwood Nature Center.The land was purchased from Washington College in 2017.McMullen told the ribbon-cutting guests that already the foundation has provided over 200,000 students from the Eastern Shore and 15 other counties hands-on lessons, "now that the center is open new programs start next week." Joining the ribbon cutting team were state Senator Stephen Hershey, state Delegate Jay Jacobs, National Park Service Planning and Development Manager Bob Campbell, Chestertown Councilman Albert Nickerson, and Kent County Superintendent of Schools Dr. Karen Couch.Jacobs, a Kent County resident, took a tour of the area before the project began. "I've seen the before and after, and it's remarkable" he said. As for funding they received from the state, Jacobs said, "It speaks to the credibility of the Sultana foundation that they were able to get that kind of funding level - when you get what you want when you want it." "We are grateful to Mr.Lawrence and the individuals, foundations, and government agencies that made the creation of the Preserve possible," commented Sultana Board Chair Robert Hindman. "We're thrilled to have created a resource that will enhance the Foundation's environmental education programs while serving as a green space for the entire community." Several state and federal agencies awarded sizable grants to the project including the Maryland General Assembly, the National Park Service, Chesapeake Bay Gateways Network, the Maryland Heritage Areas Authority, the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, and the Stories of the Chesapeake Heritage Area.The Lawrence Wetlands Preserve will host environmental literacy programs and professional development opportunities for 3,000 students and teachers annually, with a focus on PreK through fifth grade. The Preserve will often be used in conjunction with activities taking place at other locations on Sultana's Chestertown campus, including its LEED Platinum Holt Education Center, the schooner SULTANA, and canoe and kayak trips based out of Wilmer Park.When not in use for programs, the Preserve will serve as a contact point for the National Park Service's Chesapeake Bay Gateways Network, host programs for the public, and be open for general visitation daily from dusk to dawn.Kent County Superintendent Dr. Karen Couch said McCullen was one of the first people she met when she came to the county. "I found we weren't accessing the foundation like we should. Together we worked diligently to provide students valuable lessons to become good environmental stewards," said Couch.All KCPS students from pre-k through grade eight have had at least one activity with the foundation. Using the Maryland state science standards, plans are for all first grades to visit and study bird adaptations; for all third graders to student pond ecology, and all eighth graders to study soil and water chemistry."This is hands-on learning by doing," said Couch. These lessons will stay with them the rest of their lives." Said Hershey, "It's important that students learn how things work outside of the classroom. A lot of us would have loved to get these opportunities when we were young." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
State Delegate Jay Jacobs, State Senator Stephen Hershey, Kent County Schools Superintendent Dr. Karen Couch, Kent County Commissioner Albert Nickerson, National Park Service Planning and Development Manager Bob Campbell, and Drew McMullen, president of the Sultana Education Foundation cut the ribbon to open the Lawrence Wetlands Preserve in Chestertown. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the opening of a wetland preserve and its role in environmental education and stewardship, making the environmental focus the strongest match.

title: Officials tout Bay education and funding bill
author: Shifra Dayak; Capital News Service
content:
Officials tout Bay education and funding bill

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Shifra Dayak; Capital News Service | Page: A4 | Section: News 
 
 603
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - A House panel held a hearing Wednesday on a bill that would boost Chesapeake Bay restoration and environmental education programs.The Chesapeake Bay Science, Education, and Ecosystem Enhancement Act of2023, sponsored by Rep. John Sarbanes, D-Maryland, would reauthorize the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrations Chesapeake Bay office for the first time since 2006.Congress has appropriated funds to the NOAA office each year, but an official reauthorization would allow the office to more efficiently carry out Chesapeake Bay restoration and monitoring initiatives, Sarbanes told the House Natural Resources Committee's water, wildlife and fisheries subcommittee."In recent decades, the health of the Chesapeake Bay has been negatively affected by nutrient runoff across the watershed, disappearing coastal and marine habitats and many other factors," Sarbanes said. "That makes the passage of the Chesapeake Bay SEEE act all the more important."The bill would also enhance NOAA's interpretive buoy system, which collects data on water quality, weather patterns and more; enhance NOAA's aquaculture programs that aim to support marine habitats and workers in the seafood industry; and finance grants for hands-on environmental education in kindergarten through 12th grade classrooms in the region.This bill, introduced in the summer, "could not come at a more critical time," according to Allison Colden, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation's executive director."There's still much work to be done," Colden said. "To achieve meaningful and lasting restoration we need all of our federal partners at the table."Colden pointed to the NOAA Chesapeake Bay office's positive track record on oyster restoration projects, citing the bill as an avenue to continue such initiatives in the future by ensuring the office has financial stability.NOAA staff are working to restore oysters in 11 tributaries in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, and have completed restoration across more than 1,900 acres, according to a tracker by the Chesapeake Bay Program."The scale of this work is really unprecedented," Carrie Selberg Robinson, the director of NOAA's habitat conservation office, said of the oyster conservation efforts. "We want to continue to build upon our successes that we've had and continue this great work of oyster restoration into the future."Rep. Rob Wittman, R-Virginia, who co-sponsored the bill, also praised its potential impact on furthering oyster restoration projects."Large scale oyster restoration is really Mother Nature's filter in taking a lot of stuff out of the bay that would otherwise take years and years to do," Wittman said.The Chesapeake Bay SEEE Act comes amid other efforts this congressional session to restore the health of the nation's largest estuary.Sarbanes also sponsored a bill that would designate the bay as a national recreation area under the National Park Service. Wittman sponsored a bill that would fund conservation initiatives in the watershed, such as a pilot project to plant riparian buffers.The latest Sarbanes-Wittman bill includes provisions to instill stewardship values into students, allowing for bay restoration to continue in the longterm, witnesses told the subcommittee. If passed, the bill would continue to fund NOAA's Chesapeake Bay-Watershed Education and Training Program, which provides grants for environmental education in the watershed.Witnesses faced slight pushback on the bill from Rep. Cliff Bentz, R-Ore-gon - the ranking member of the subcommittee - who called for supporters to provide more specific metrics about the benefits of environmental education.Colden said that the Chesapeake Bay Foundation will provide the subcommittee with numbers ahead of further movement on the bill, but added that the positives of teaching children about caring for the bay are evident."We're building the workforce that can continue the work of Chesapeake Bay restoration," Colden said. "It's so incredibly important to make that investment in our next generation of bay stewards." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a congressional bill aimed at Chesapeake Bay restoration, NOAA's environmental programs, and ecosystem enhancement, making environmental policy the primary focus, with secondary emphasis on education and aquaculture.
