title: How will dogs, cats, birds, livestock and wild animals react to the total solar eclipse?
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
How will dogs, cats, birds, livestock and wild animals react to the total solar eclipse?

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Eclipse 
 
 588
 Words 

 Read News Document

 All eyes will be to the sky for Monday's total solar eclipse when the moon will darken the sun bringing with it daytime darkness.But there is also interest in how animals — from family dogs and house cats to birds and other wild creatures — react to the eclipse across the U.S.
Jacob Dykes, a wildlife specialist and assistant professor at the Texas A&M University in Corpus Christi, will be keeping tabs on how animals react to the eclipse.
"Even among members of the same species, there is quite a lot of variation in how animals respond," said Dykes, who studies animal behaviors. "It may be down to the individual. Some animals respond and some don't. Right now, it's a question that nobody seems to have a complete answer to."
The Texas A&M researcher said animals at a zoo in South Carolina showed varying reactions to an eclipse in 2017 — including some that began nighttime preparations, some that looked to the sky and others who displayed signs of anxiety or unusual activities.
"Researchers saw giraffes suddenly start running around their pen," Dykes said. "Some of the male gorillas became more aggressive. These were some of the anxiety behaviors."
"For birds, they would suddenly go to nest and then a few minutes later, when the sun came back out, they would seem to start their day all over again," he said. "There's no telling what's running through these critters' minds when, suddenly midday, the sky goes dark. Their environment is always having an influence, whether through rain, temperature, wind speed, the amount of sunlight or the length of day. Wildlife are deeply in tune with their surroundings."
Researchers from other universities as well as students and teachers from high schools will also be studying animal and wildlife behaviors.
That includes a contingent from North Carolina State University who will be part of a research effort at the Fort Worth Zoo in Texas during the April 8 eclipse.
Adam Hartstone-Rose, a biology professor at North Carolina State, was also at the Riverbanks Zoo and Garden in Columbia, South Carolina in 2017.
He's excited for the 2024 total solar eclipse to see how animals react.
The researchers welcome input from others who see how farm animals, dogs and cats and other wildlife react during the cosmic happening.
"We're interested not only in figuring out which animals react to the eclipse and how, but (to) what extent of totality is necessary to cause a reaction," Hartsone-Rose said.
"We're really excited about getting data from people that might be at farms or cattle ranches," he said. "We're hoping that people will go out into the woods and see what squirrels, deer and birds are doing. And I'm really excited about people just observing their pets in their backyard."
The eclipse will be visible to varying degrees across the U.S. with a path of totality where the moon will completely darken the sun for three to four minutes stretching from Texas and Oklahoma and into Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, upstate New York and New England.
Overcast conditions and stormy weather could impact how visible the eclipse is in parts of the country — including Texas and Ohio.
It will be the biggest eclipse in the U.S. since 1806 and there will not be another similar event until 2044.
Zoos — especially those in or near the totality path of the eclipse — will also be hosting special events for visitors Monday. That includes ones in Indianapolis, Toledo, Ohio, St. Louis and throughout Texas.
The eclipse comes after a 4.8 magnitude earthquake hit Friday in New Jersey near New York City. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on how various animals respond to a total solar eclipse, discussing wildlife behavior and observations, which aligns most closely with the Environment topic.

title: Garden Potluck unites residents and students in environmental efforts
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Garden Potluck unites residents and students in environmental efforts

 May 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — As the weather warms up, more people want to get outside and plant their crops and flowers, and do some outdoor activities. For the Washington College Campus Garden Club that's not just a seasonal thing.They, and residents interested in sustainable living practices, gathered together for a monthly potluck dinner April 12 — a Permaculture Potluck, this time held at the community garden on campus.
President of the club, Jo Perkins described permaculture as a, "smash of two words, permanent and agriculture."
She explained, "It's essentially a set of 12 design principles and three fundamental ethics: earth share, people care and fair share. It's a way to design your systems to be good for humans and for the environment simultaneously."
For member, Justinian Dispenza, permaculture is a way to get back to our growing roots.
"Let's get our feet in the dirt. Eat local and help heal. Everyone is capable of fixing where they're at."
The space itself is a good indicator of this lifestyle in practice.
Since its early roots in 2012, when students put in some vegetable beds and trees, the club has grown significantly. The space now has a fenced area with a coop of happy chickens, a renovated pond, a bridge over a little waterfall, a mud pizza oven (primitive earth oven), a beehive, an insect hotel (for pollination purposes) some fruit trees, some buckthorn trees, and some compost piles.
This all lies beyond the painted wall on campus. A surreal area, especially surrounded by brick dorm buildings and cars chugging by.
Perkins said, "It's really impressive how far the space has come."
She pointed to her first project she started, over the fence where a scarecrow in Perkin's clothes is humorously referred to as 'The Scare-Jo," towards the chickens.
There are eight chickens in total, among them Black Jersey Giants, a Leghorn, some Easter Eggers, a Rhode Island Red and a Favorolle.
As nature teaches lessons, Perkins described permaculture at work inside the coop.
She said that chickens eat bugs which have nutrients, then chicken manure fertilizes the fruit trees, then the chickens eat some of the apples that grow, becoming a catalyst for compost and finally humans eat the nutritious eggs.
Everything in nature harmonizes.
Shane Brill the permaculture educator at Washington College called it applied common sense.
He's been introducing these concepts to his classmates and the've been acting on them, which has produced incredible results.
The growing principles and rural way of life is something that Kent County and Eastern Shore residents know about already, so the club hopes to keep good camaraderie with the public.
Based on the laughter and fellowship it's effective.
Dispenza, who takes the lead in the potlucks, said they always start with people introducing themselves and their field of interest.
For example, he said, one could say 'I'm a bee keeper,' and from there, the crowd would learn about another facet of sustainable living.
As it stands, the garden has plenty of green space for people to congregate, and they're building a new addition, a section for poetry, for classroom instruction and planning events.
"There's a lot of potential for things to come in and do a lot of cool things," Perkins commented.
Dispenza and company are always working on more activities for community engagement. They have master gardeners come in, and community events as well as volunteer with the Chestertown Garden Club on various projects.
But they are always looking for more people with knowledge on growing, planting, building, producing, harvesting, foraging, or anything else like that.
Dispenza said if anyone is interested in hosting a permaculture potluck, he encouraged them to reach out. He stressed the importance of going to different places in the county to learn, since no two areas are alike.
"There's a lot of great people in Kent County and Eastern Shore Community that know about sustainability. I'm here to learn," Dispenza said.
The next potluck is May 5, at 6 p.m. at Kentmore Park.
People can check out www.facebook.com/espigrow or email espigrow@gmail.com for more details. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community garden club promoting permaculture, sustainable living, and ecological practices, which aligns most closely with the Environment topic, with secondary relevance to Agriculture and Education.

title: Maryland Conservation Corps graduates celebrated
author: MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES
content:
Maryland Conservation Corps graduates celebrated

 August 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES | Section: Life 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of Natural Resources honored 39 members of the 2023-2024 Maryland Conservation Corps during their graduation program at Wye Island Natural Resources Management Area.The Aug. 1 ceremony capped the members' completion of 10 months of job training, conservation work and stewardship with the Maryland Park Service.
"Through the past 10 months, these dedicated young professionals have shared their passion for our natural resources and public lands through hours of plantings, training, projects and public engagement," said Maryland Park Service Director Angela Crenshaw.
"I am thankful for their hard work and hope they've grown both professionally and personally during their time with us," she said. "I am exceedingly proud of our graduates and excited for the many meaningful things they will accomplish in the future. I would also like to thank our wonderful Conservation Corps Team and everyone in the Maryland Park Service who helped support our corps members."
Maryland Conservation Corps members come from across the country, are between the ages of 17 and 25, and complete at least 1,700 hours of service.
This year's corps class improved more than 2,400 acres of parks and public lands; planted more than 9,963 native trees, bay grasses and plants; treated more than 7,902 trees against harmful insects and diseases; and taught environmental education programs to more than 23,750 students, youth and park visitors.
The program offers hands-on, real-world experience in a team-based environment in subjects ranging from aquatic systems to public lands management.
Many alumni of the program have gone on to conservation careers with organizations including the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the National Aquarium, the United States Geological Survey and others.
The Maryland Conservation Corps, an award-winning AmeriCorps program, has been managed by the Maryland Park Service since 1984. The Park Service is now accepting applications for the next class, which begins in the fall.
More information and applications for the Maryland Conservation Corps can be found on the DNR website. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a conservation corps graduation, highlighting natural resource stewardship, habitat restoration, and environmental education, which aligns most closely with the Environment topic.

title: Chef tours: learning the story of Chesapeake Bay seafood
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chef tours: learning the story of Chesapeake Bay seafood

 August 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 500
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS — On Tuesday morning, the Maryland Department of Agriculture hosted a tour to educate chefs and local organizations on the story and ecology of the region's seafood.The hope for the chef tours was to educate chefs from the region on seafood from the Bay, including wild-caught blue catfish, striped bass, crabs, oysters and other processed seafood.
Representatives from several organizations were in attendance, including the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, Oyster Recovery Partnership and Maryland Food Bank.
The tour began with pastries and coffee before loading all attendees onto a boat chartered by Off Da' Hook, a local fishing charter providing tours across the Chesapeake Bay. Touring through the waters of Kent Narrows, countless boats and watermen were harvesting crabs and oysters in the vicinity.
Kristin Hanna, director of special projects for the Maryland Department of Agriculture, said educational tours such as the chef tour are important in supporting watermen and the local economy.
"It helps people tell a story," Hanna said. "So when you're a restaurant, you are competing with so many other restaurants, and everyone really cares about the food they're serving, and this (tour) gives them another story to share about how they're helping the Chesapeake Bay, whether they're serving the blue catfish or crab or oysters. We're supporting a legacy of watermen, which is historical to our state, and that matters."
Afterwards, the group was taken on a tour of the historic Harris Seafood, one of the last remaining packing houses on Ken Narrows and the last full-time shucking house in the state.
During the tour, attendees were shown the quick-paced crab packing process, the oyster preservation process and the various differences between female and male blue crabs.
Zach Jeffries, a sourcing manager for Maryland Food Bank, said the Maryland Food Bank started ordering blue catfish a few years ago through the Local Food Purchase Assistance program, a program that provides funds to purchase food to support local, regional and underserved producers.
"It was very educational," Jeffries said. "I've worked … with the state of Maryland to fight invasive species, but oysters, crab harvesting, it was all very educational … and extremely fascinating. You learn things you never learned before about the lifespan of oysters and crabs that blows your mind."
Toward the end of the event, attendees were treated to a seafood lunch at Harris Crab House, where they feasted on to crab dip, oysters and a variety of different entrees including a crab cake sandwich and a fried oyster sandwich.
Chris Jones, an invasive fish biologist for the Maryland Department of National Resources, said it's important to educate the public about the wildlife in the Chesapeake Bay for the protection of native species.
"The Chesapeake is a very unique ecosystem, and these invasive species pose a threat to a lot of our native species," Jones said. "They are out-competing some of our native species … Invasive fishes in general are posing a threat because they are competing with other species, and they're taking away from species that are important to the bay." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem, invasive species, and the ecological story of local seafood, making environment the most relevant category, with secondary relevance to business/economy and education.

title: Horn Point Lab talks community at Cambridge City Council meeting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Horn Point Lab talks community at Cambridge City Council meeting

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In an effort to build a closer relationship between the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science at Horn Point and the city, Horn Point Laboratory Director Michael Sieracki came before the Cambridge City Council Monday.Before delving into the school's existing community engagement and ideas for more engagement opportunities, Sieracki told commissioners about the school's history and its mission.
"We have a unique statutory mandate as a university to conduct a scientific program that informs the improvement and preservation of Maryland's physical environment," he said. "Not many universities have a mission like that."
Sieracki talked about the lab's areas of research, which include oyster restoration, sea level rise and coastal resilience. Currently, the lab is working with the city on a flood mitigation project along the Choptank River.
Getting to community engagement, Sieracki brought up what Horn Point already does to connect with the Cambridge and Dorchester County community. Along with the flood mitigation project, he mentioned the school's weekly Tuesday lab tours, its annual open house in October and the science talks it hosts. He also talked about student internships, K-12 programming and a summer camp the lab hosts called Toadfish Adventures.
In looking at where community engagement could expand, Sieracki brought up ideas of supporting local oyster aquaculture and expanding the number of internships and K-12 student programming available. He also mentioned workforce development.
"And I want to just challenge you to talk with us about new ideas or directions that we could go that would impact our town," he said to the commissioners at the meeting. "I'm a citizen and resident of the City of Cambridge, so I'm interested in what happens here."
After his presentation to the council, Commissioner Shay Lewis-Sisco talked about her experience working with Horn Point as a Dorchester County Public Schools employee. She said the district has a student apprenticing at Horn Point this year and she would love to expand those opportunities.
Commissioner Brett Summers talked about an idea to promote tourism through oysters in a partnership with a variety of players, like Horn Point, ShoreRivers and the Richardson Maritime Museum.
"Perhaps creating some kind of destination where you get to enjoy oysters, learn about what Horn Point's doing and just the history of our area," he said.
Summers said the city could help develop this potential "oyster trail."
"And I'm interested," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a university environmental science lab discussing research on oyster restoration, sea level rise, and flood mitigation, which aligns most closely with the Environment topic, while also touching on aquaculture and education.

title: Charles humane society celebrates 50 years
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Charles humane society celebrates 50 years

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While many things have changed over the last half century, once constant has been the care provided to animals by the Humane Society of Charles County.The nonprofit organization is hosting its Golden Paws Gala on Oct. 10 to celebrate 50 years of taking care of sick, injured and homeless animals.
The event is from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. at the Waldorf Jaycees at 3090 Crain Highway. Tickets are $75 per person.
Local humane societies are not directly attached to the National Humane Society, making the Humane Society of Charles County 100% reliant on local donations, grants and fundraising, Rayanne Benya, president of the board of directors for the Humane Society of Charles County, said.
In 1975, the humane society did not have a building. Instead, people who found an injured animal had to take them home, Anne Gardiner, founder of the Humane Society of Charles County, said. In 1981, the St. Charles County Association of Realtors gave the humane society the land for a shelter and it opened in 1983.
"It was tough getting started," Gardiner said. "One time I had [animals] in all three bathrooms and we were wondering what we were going to do."
The humane society has three sections: the kennel, which houses animals ranging from dogs and cats to guinea pigs, rabbits, lizards, turtles and snakes; the humane education program, which teaches students about animals and environmental science; and the clinic.
"Fifty years later, we're still here," Benya said. "We're here because we're supported by the residents of the county … and I think that's something to celebrate."
The gala will have a silent auction with dog baskets, Gardiner said. Other baskets will have household items. Wine and alcohol will be raffled, and there will also be gift cards for restaurants and businesses.
Live music will be performed by the "Original" Moonlighters and there will be a lipsologist — a person who "reads" lip prints — and a cash bar. Food is being donated by the Waldorf Jaycees.
"It's just for a great cause," Benya said. "We adopt out anywhere from one to 2,000 animals a year and all those animals need medical care."
Under the shelter's care, the humane society often has about 150 animals, an amount that can go up to 250 animals during the summer, Benya said.
Throughout the year, the shelter has around 200 volunteers who help with adoption events, laundry and being around the animals. They also want to build an animal medical facility for emergencies and a larger surgery wing.
"When [people] come here and they volunteer, they see the connection … between humans and animals," Benya said.
The humane society is holding its annual photo contest until Sept. 27, Benya said. People can send a cute photo of their pet that can be featured in a calendar.
On Sept. 20, they will have an adoption event at the humane society, Benya said.
The nonprofit also has a program called Freedom Friends year round that offers discounts to veterans to adopt animals for animals that have been in the shelter for six months or longer.
"It's important that we receive the funding … so we can continue to be here for the county," Benya said. "If we disappear, that's going to be devastating for the animal population.
For more information about the Oct. 10 gala or to purchase tickets, go to humanesocietycc.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a local humane society’s animal care, shelter, and its humane education program about animals and environmental science, fitting best under the Environment category.

title: One seedling at a time: Nonprofit gives away native plants, empowers youth
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
One seedling at a time: Nonprofit gives away native plants, empowers youth

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Esther Bonney turned her grief into growth by starting a nonprofit that aims to spread native plants.Nurture Natives, a youth-led nonprofit organization, empowers young people through native biodiversity, restoration and education.
About a year and a half after losing her older brother to suicide, Bonney, a La Plata resident and founder of Nurture Natives, joined 4-H with the Charles County Pollinator Masters Club to study and dive into being outside with pollinators and native plants.
"I felt pretty lost," Bonney said. "Then 4-H came into my life … and I joined it not knowing that it would be such a beam of support."
After attending the National 4-H Youth Summit on Agriscience, members were encouraged to design a project that would solve an agricultural issue, Bonney said. One of the issues that came up during conversations with farmers in Southern Maryland was invasive plant species.
Nurture Natives was created to address this agricultural issue and the broader environmental issue of invasive species.
These sustainable efforts helped the National 4-H Council select her as one of the 2026 4-H Youth in Action Award winners. Nurture Natives has planted 2.4 million native seeds, distributed 70,000 seedlings and engaged more than 10,000 young people to help protect native plants and pollinators, according to a release from 4-H.
"Pollination is what keeps our world functioning," Bonney said. "Pollination is so key to both our agriculture and our environmental systems."
Jeremy Tidd, owner and founder of Bona Terra, looked for ways to give back to the community and get more engagement about his native plant nursery when he decided to start giving seedlings away for free as part of a grant application, he said. Bona Terra grows 30 native plant species and is working to give away one million seedlings a year.
"There's no shortage of seeds in the world," Tidd said.
Bona Terra became involved with Nurture Native's mission when Bonney called local nurseries to put pamphlets on display racks, Tidd said. Bona Terra invited Nurture Natives to the nursery.
"They saw that I was giving away seedlings and they wanted to volunteer," Tidd said.
Bona Terra and Nurture Natives partnered to decide how to run seedling giveaway events and what training sessions to offer, Tidd said. They had their first training in March.
"Every time the world changes it's because we've taught the next generation," Tidd said. "Young adults … were taught … that we had to do something about it and now it's just accepted, common knowledge."
Nurture Natives is at the intersection of environmental stewardship and youth mental health, Bonney said. The organization is meant to help young people find meaning through environmental action who feel disconnected from nature or who feel powerless when hearing about the biodiversity crises.
"You might notice a lot of people who have a passion for gardening are older," Bonney said. "A discussion that has been pretty consistent … has been how do we bridge this gap?"
Bonney is a freshman at the University of Maryland, College Park and hopes to continue to grow Nurture Natives as a fellow with the university's Do Good Institute, where she will work on expanding the nonprofit's initiatives, she said.
"The coolest thing about the seedlings is it has made people brave," Tidd said. "This is a learning opportunity. Plants are amazing and have so much to teach us." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a nonprofit promoting native plants, pollinator health, and invasive species control, which are core environmental stewardship topics, while also touching on agricultural and youth education aspects.

title: Anonymous note about son's hygiene angers parent
author: Harriette Cole
content:
Anonymous note about son's hygiene angers parent

 August 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: A18 | Section: Advice 
 
 327
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I have a friend or family member who wrote me an anonymous note telling me that I should teach my 13-year-old son to have better hygiene.I opened my mailbox last week and found it, and I started crying. My family and I live on a farm, and my son loves to spend a lot of time with our pigs, cows and goats. He loves taking care of them every day because they are his pride and joy. As a result of this, he and his clothes often end up having a distinct scent on them from the animals. He tries to get it off of him, but it sticks.I am offended and upset that someone wouldn't have the guts to tell me to my face. Instead, they chose to leave a note without signing their name. I now feel as if I can't trust the people around me anymore, and I feel as if it could've been anyone from my life.How am I supposed to find out who did this and confront them? - My Son's Hygiene DEAR MY SON's HYGIENE: I'm sorry, but I think you are looking at this through the wrong lens. It isn't that the person lacks courage. I believe the message was delivered anonymously so that you can seriously address this situation rather than get in a rage over the messenger.Stop trying to figure out who wrote it. Start getting creative on helping your teen son learn how to take better care of his body and clothing as he continues to love his animals. Ask some of your male farmer friends what they recommend for cleanliness. This is not a new problem for farmers. Somebody should have solutions you can try.Forgive the messenger, and receive the message.Harriette Cole is a life stylist and founder of DREAMLEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions to askharriette@harriettecole.com or c/o Andrews McMeel Syndication, 1130 Walnut St., Kansas City, MO 64106. ©2023 HARRIETTE COLE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: New book promotes physical activity, family fitness
content:
New book promotes physical activity, family fitness

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: News

 Maryland SNAP-Ed, a program of University of Maryland Extension in partnership with Maryland Department of Human Services, has written a new original storybook promoting family physical activity.More than 125,000 free copies of the book will be distributed to low-income sites across the state throughout the summer."The Secret to an Extraordinary Day" follows the story of an ordinary family that takes an unexpected adventure, prompted by a series of mysterious notes. Along the way they discover that being active together is a secret weapon for overcoming the summer blues.SNAP-Ed delivers multi-faceted interventions that support adoption of healthy behaviors by low-income audiences."Physical activity has emerged as a priority for SNAP-Ed, both nationally and in Maryland," Maryland SNAP-Ed Director Lisa Lachenmayr said in a news release. "Among the many lasting effects of the pandemic, sedentary behaviors increased due to increased reliance on technology for school and education. While SNAP-Ed's interest in physical activity is as a tool for obesity and chronic disease prevention, our partners also recognize the power of movement to address critical concerns around social-emotional health." Physical activity is a current focus area for SNAP-Ed, due to well-documented impacts on chronic disease prevention. Supporting youth in developing a lifelong relationship with physical activity also benefits overall well-being.Books are being distributed to partnering schools, early childhood sites, out of school programs, Maryland WIC offices, SNAP Outreach community partners, low-income 4-H youth programs, and summer meals sites, allowing SNAP-Ed to deliver health promotion messages while supporting family literacy and summer learning.For more information or to read the book, go to https://extension.umd.edu/active-fun.

 Choptank Community Health System is expanding its schoolbased services in Caroline and Talbot County Public Schools with the addition of three new behavioral health providers.Behavioral health therapists Maura Cavalieri and Fiona Kay have joined Choptank Health's Talbot County Public Schools health center team, and behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo joins behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb in serving the students at Caroline County Public Schools."Choptank Health recognizes the importance of behavioral health as part of the integrated health services we provide to our patients, and that includes students enrolled in our School-Based Health Centers throughout Maryland's Mid-Shore," said Choptank Health President and CEO Sara Rich. "These three new providers are part of our treating the whole person with medical, dental, and behavioral health services."Behavioral health therapist Maura Cavalieri holds a Master of Science in education from the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education and a Bachelor of Arts in psychology with a minor in justice, law, and society from Washington College.She holds a trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy certification, with counseling experience in school and family environments, including the William Meredith School and Family Center at Jefferson in Philadelphia. Cavalieri sees students at Easton Elementary and the St. Michaels campus of schools.Behavioral health therapist Fiona Kay holds a master's of social work from the University of Maryland, Baltimore. She is an experienced school social worker and clinical mental health therapist in local and rural settings.Her experience includes working with Talbot County Public Schools, For All Seasons, Eastern Shore Psychological Services and the Caroline County Department ofSocial Services. Kay sees students at Easton Middle School, Easton High School and White Marsh Elementary School.Behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo received her master's degree in social work from Salisbury University and holds a certificate in advanced trauma treatment Level 1 from the Ferentz Institute.Before joining Choptank Health, Ronquillo worked for Channel Marker in Easton and Denton, Maryland, most recently serving as an adult services director, and working in crisis and youth services.Her community involvement includes serving with the Caroline YMCA Mentor Program, Asian Student Social Workers and the Special Education Citizens Advisory Committee. title: Students learn to save a life - St. Michaels Y training session prepares students for emergencies
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Students learn to save a life - St. Michaels Y training session prepares students for emergencies

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS-Nine middle school students gained lifesaving skills Wednesday afternoon, thanks to a partnership between the St. Michaels Community Center, St. Michaels Youth & Law Enforcement (SMYLE), Talbot County Emergency Services and the Perkins Family YMCA.Talbot County paramedic Rachael Cox led the afterschool CPR and AED training class at the Y, guiding the young students through the steps to take in an emergency.The class was free for all who participated, thanks to a $200 donation from SMYLE, the St. Michaels Police Department's youth program, that covered certification costs for the students. The St. Michaels Community Center assisted in facilitating the program.Cox began her class by showing how to check if a person is responsive, then asked the students what they thought the next step was.The answer? Calling 911 and staying on the line with the dispatcher.The next step, as Cox demonstrated, is checking if the person is breathing. If not, it's time to start chest compressions, she said.Each student practiced chest compressions on practice manikins and learned how to use an AED before moving on to learning how to do CPR on infants.As a community risk reduction paramedic and CPR and AED coordinator for Talbot County, Cox loves teaching. She likes being able to introduce preteens and teenagers to CPR, first aid and AED skills to prepare them for any emergency situation, even if they're alone without adults present."I feel like we call EMS, police, fire and dispatch first responders, but I really don't believe we're first responders because we're not there when the emergency happens-the community is," she said. "And that's why I feel these types of classes are so important."Amethyst Monroe, a Perkins Family YMCA staffer who supervised Wednesday's class, is continuing to coordinate other developing middle school programs. She's planning another CPR and AED session soon.Monroe's aim is to make sure future programs are lowcost and provide the area's youth with more life skills.Anyone who wishes to support future after-school programming at the Perkins Family YMCA can donate to the center's annual campaign or reach out to Tracy Eutsler, the Y's executive director, at teutsler@ymcachesapeake.org.Those who are interested in scheduling CPR and AED classes can contact Rachael Cox at rcox@talbotdes.org.

title: Community Center to host talk on human-animal bond
author: Contributed
content:
Community Center to host talk on human-animal bond

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 OXFORD - Ahead of this Veterans Day, join the Oxford Community Center for an inspiring evening with Meg Daley Olmert, a world-renowned expert on the neurobiology of the human-animal bond.On Thursday, Nov. 2, at 5:30 p.m., Olmert will speak about the profound therapeutic effects of human-animal relationships.Meg Daley Olmert is an accomplished subject expert, author and lecturer, recognized for her groundbreaking book, "Made for Each Other: The Biology of the Human-Animal Bond," published in 2009.This book traces the evolution of the ancient bond between humans and animals, delving into the emerging neuroscience that underlies this profound interspecies connection.With her expertise in the therapeutic effects of the human-animal bond, Olmert has been a trailblazer in the field, and her two TEDx talks have captivated the hearts and minds of thousands."We're thrilled to host Meg and share her wisdom on the healing power of the human-animal connection," said Liza Ledford, Director of OCC. "Her work has made a tremendous impact, especially for our veterans, and her message is perfect for Veterans Day as we honor those who have served our country." In addition to her remarkable contributions to the field, Olmert serves as the science advisor and board member of The Comfort Dog Program of Northern Uganda.She was also a co-creator of Warrior Canine Connection's Mission-Based Trauma Recovery Program at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda.Additionally, she will be featured in the upcoming documentary, "By My Side," which highlights the impact of service dogs on veterans with trauma. The documentary has been selected for the CFF Virtual Doc program.For more information and to reserve your space, please visit the Oxford Community Center's website at www.oxfordcc.org or contact the center at 410-226-5904

title: College junior feels jealous of friend
author: Harriette Cole
content:
College junior feels jealous of friend

 October 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am a junior in college, and I'm struggling with feelings of jealousy toward my friend. It seems like everything comes so easily to her, and it's hard for me not to compare our paths.Recently, my friend received a $10,000 scholarship for a study abroad program in Japan and landed an internship at one of the top investment banking firms in the United States. She applied to only one internship and only one scholarship, and things fell into place effortlessly. It's as if a fairy comes in every night while she's sleeping and throws magic pixie dust at her to make everything work out. Meanwhile, I feel like I have to fight tooth and nail just to make half as much progress. Every day is a continuous struggle to accomplish the goals that I have. I try hard to be positive, but obstacles pop up constantly. How can I deal with these feelings of envy and move forward with a more upbeat outlook on life? - Jealous DEAR JEALOUS: It is understandable that you would be envious of your friend for what appears to be an easy life. As you also know, it is toxic to dwell on what other people have. No good will come out of that longing. Instead, you must focus on yourself. Do your best to view your life as your perfect challenge. You are gaining resilience as you live through each experience.Claim your small victories.To keep on track, create a vision board. Look through magazines and newspapers for images that reflect the things you want for your life. Cut them out. Brainstorm words and ideas that represent your dreams.Write them down. Next, on a large piece of cardboard or paper, place the images and words together. Make a simple art piece out of this collection of ideas to create your vision board. When thoughts creep in about your friend's success - or anyone else's - wish them well and pivot back to planning your own life. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article addresses emotional well‑being and coping with jealousy, which falls under mental health rather than sports, business, or other categories.

title: Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school
author: LAURA TAYMAN
content:
Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LAURA TAYMAN | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last month, Kent County Board of Education members were provided stark facts about the rise in sexually transmitted diseases (STD) in the community, the state, and the country at its recent monthly meeting.Ashley Minietta, communicable disease and family planning contact for the Kent County Department of Health, made a presentation to the board before the holiday break, saying the solution to reversing the trend is "to provide ground support, monitor trends, and turn data into action."
"While 20% of Marylanders have an STD, almost half of the cases are ages 15-24," Minietta said, citing the 2020 U.S. census map — putting Maryland in the South region of the country, "It's one of the highest rates in the region."
Minietta said the barriers to effectively preventing both STDs and teenage pregnancies in Kent County are lack of education, the cost of birth control, parental resistance to alternatives, lack of public transportation, the geographic barriers of the rural area and lack of health care options.
Teen pregnancy rates are down, Minietta said, because parents have been proactive with putting teenage daughters on birth control. But pills and IUDs do not allow the prevention of STDs that can lead to long-term health consequences.
"Research in 2020 shows only 9% of sexually active high school students used a condom," Minetta said. "That has only increased."
Minetta shared various ways local school systems are providing a condom availability program to meet the needs of their high school students, including those in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties, and counties on the western shore.
While some have availability through the school's nurse's office, others provide a "brown bag" approach, where students can pick up a paper bag on an anonymous basis.
Board member Aretha Dorsey said that as a parent she was concerned that a program like that would encourage secrets among parents and their children.
"I feel like parents' rights are being taken away," Dorsey said. "I believe that kids might form a lack of respect for their parents and think they can do things their own way."
Board member Francois Sullivan said Kent County and its rural location is a valid argument for such a program.
"There is a difference between a nurse providing condoms and a cashier."
When asked to share her opinion, student board member Madison Messick said she couldn't even remember her sex education class.
"I think this is really important," she said. "There is a stigma. We can't go to Walgreens because we know the cashier. I know kids that would definitely benefit from this."
Vienna Walker, supervisor of student services for the Board, said she recommended the board adopt a policy where Kent County students can meet with a high school nurse and ask for information and guidance.
Superintendent Karen Couch said she had been asked by parents how students could be opted out of a program if they don't approve. Walker said she would need to check with the state's Department of Education to see how that could be handled.
"Some students have much more open communication with school nurses than their parents," Walker said. "Their office is much less threatening to students who then become comfortable enough to come back if they are not feeling great."
That is Walker's goal. She recommended the board consider approving a program that requires students to visit nurses who can provide education and guidance on condom use.
"Nurses also encourage students to be open and honest with their parents," Walker said.
Messick agreed.
"Students will participate not because kids don't trust their parents," she said. "The program encourages conversations between parents and their children. It's like therapy where they can't tell parents what their child is talking about. This actually helps to form a better relationship between students and parents."
School Board President Joe Goetz said he would like for Walker to get information from other districts on how they manage parent objections.
"I think real life examples would help," Goetz said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on STD rates, condom distribution, and teen health concerns, which are core health issues, though it also involves school policy and education.

title: Eastern Shore Delegation hears about health care access expansion
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore Delegation hears about health care access expansion

 February 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Expanding access to health care on the Shore was a recurring topic at the Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday morning.During the meeting, which was held on Zoom, Mark T. Gladwin from the University System of Maryland spoke about a new program that would bring medical students to the Eastern Shore, and Sara Rich talked about the growth of the Choptank Community Health System.
Gladwin, who is dean of the University of Maryland School of Medicine and vice president for medical affairs at the University of Maryland, Baltimore, talked about the Rural Health Equity and Access Longitudinal elective program.
Once in place, he said the program will have students spend their first two years in Baltimore, coming to the Eastern Shore to do rotations. For students' last two years, they will spend four months of each year learning and training on the Eastern Shore.
This program will address a need for more health care on the Shore, Gladwin said. The five counties in the state with the fewest primary care physicians per capita are all on the Eastern Shore.
"As we all know, there is a pressing need to enhance physician and medical provider services and hospital services for the Eastern Shore," he said.
This new program is a partnership between the University of Maryland, Baltimore, the University of Maryland School of Medicine and the University of Maryland Eastern Shore. Between the three partners, Gladwin said $300,000 has been invested to start the program.
He said a director, assistant director and administrative support staff have been hired. The estimated cost to support and build the program is about $2.2 million per year, Gladwin said.
"We put in a federal grant for the program," he said. "And we think it would be very helpful to get state support for this."
Gladwin said they are mainly seeking scholarship support for the program. He said they would like to be able to give out full scholarships to students in the program who agree to staying on the Eastern Shore to work.
"We think there's a lot of interest (from) our students in rural health care, in health equity," Gladwin said. "And we think this could be a signature program to attract future doctors."
Eastern Shore Delegation Chair Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he was appreciative of the efforts to get this program going.
"It is surely needed," he said of the program.
Also during the meeting on Friday, Choptank Community Health System CEO Sarah Rich talked about Choptank Community Health's expansions on the Shore.
Currently, the health system has seven health centers and 18 school-based health centers across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
Rich said progress on the construction of its new center in Federalsburg is moving along "very well." The health system broke ground on this project in the early summer of 2023.
This new center will have five wings for medical, dental and behavioral health services. It will house a rural residency program in partnership with the University of Maryland School of Medicine and University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, as well as a dental residency program.
Rich also talked about Choptank Community Health's expansion into Kent County, which includes a health center in Chestertown and a school-based health center in Rock Hall.
Behavioral health in schools is another way the health system has expanded.
"We know that is a huge need," she said. "So we do have therapists now in Caroline and Talbot counties."
Rich said they plan to offer these services to students in Kent County and Queen Anne's County schools next. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses expanding health care access, a new medical student program, and health system growth on the Eastern Shore, making health the primary focus.

title: Board of Education president undergoes liver transplant

Board of Education president undergoes liver transplant

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Board of Education President Mike Diaz is recovering from a liver transplant.At a Board of Education meeting Thursday, Diaz called into the meeting to thank everyone who had reached out with well wishes and prayers.
