title: Talbot goes purple another year
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Talbot goes purple another year

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County is going purple for the ninth year this September to engage the community and youth in standing up against substance use.During the monthlong awareness and education campaign, businesses, organizations and government agencies will be lit up in purple not just in Talbot County, but throughout the Mid-Shore.
The program was founded by Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble to raise awareness about the prescription opioid crisis. Gamble said the program has since changed to reflect the evolving drug trends in the county.
Gamble said he created Talbot Goes Purple to start a conversation the county wasn't having. He said he was speaking at a fundraiser when he had this realization.
"I stood up and I said, 'raise your hand if you talk to your kids about drinking and driving,' and all 400 hands went up. And I said, 'raise your hands if you talk to your kids, your grandkids, about seatbelt use,' and 400 hands went up. And then I said, 'Raise your hand if you talk to your kids about prescription painkillers,' and only 11 hands went up," Gamble said.
For Gamble, these were conversations that parents, guardians and community members needed to be having with their children to give them the proper tools to handle situations involving drugs.
"In my world of policing, 80% of what we deal with is connected to some form of substance abuse," Gamble said.
Maryland has tracked much fewer overdose deaths for the past two years. According to Gamble, there has only been one overdose in Talbot County this year.
However, fentanyl is still a major concern, he said. "We're not seeing any heroin in Talbot County, Maryland that doesn't have fentanyl in it," Gamble said. "We're seeing a lot of cocaine in Talbot County, Maryland that has fentanyl in it."
Educational efforts through September will be extensive, Goes Purple organizers said, and they will address fentanyl along with other substances.
Talbot Goes Purple Coordinator Kelley Callaghan said the broadening of the program's focus to include education on marijuana is more important than ever with a potential dispensary coming to Easton, and Gamble agrees.
"Youth are being hospitalized for marijuana use," Gamble said. "I want parents to understand, you know, the weed they smoked when they were in college 30 years ago is not the same weed today."
Callaghan highlighted alcohol as one of the commonly abused drugs by youth.
There will be posters around Talbot County schools of a real prescription pill next to a fake one, showing how difficult it is to tell the difference.
Teaching the youth about the Good Samaritan Law, which protects individuals from prosecution for minor drug or alcohol offenses when calling 911 for a medical emergency, is a critical part of the prevention tactics, Goes Purple organizers said.
In addition, Talbot Goes Purple provides Narcan trainings and has installed Narcan boxes at several business and trained the employees how to use them. Narcan, or Naloxone, is a medication used during opioid overdoses to reverse or reduce the effects of the drug.
There is also a comprehensive toolkit on the Goes Purple website to help families navigate recovery services and find help regardless of insurance status.
For resources regarding substance use, visit talbotgoespurple.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community campaign addressing substance abuse, opioid overdose prevention, and related health education, making Health the most relevant category.

title: QAC Goes Purple 2025: standing stronger than ever
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Goes Purple 2025: standing stronger than ever

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY — QAC Goes Purple is once again rallying the community this season to stand against substance abuse, as county leaders note progress but stress that education must continue.The countywide initiative, launched in 2017, is a collaboration of the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff and the Queen Anne's County Drug-Free Coalition, in partnership with the Opioid Intervention Team and Health Department, Queen Anne's County Public Schools, the county commissioners, the Mid-Shore Community Foundation and other agencies. Its mission is to raise awareness of substance abuse and opioid overdose prevention.
One of the program's first actions was to place six opioid signs across the county, updated weekly to show overdose data. At the time, opioid misuse was on the rise.
In 2018, Queen Anne's County reported 122 overdoses and 16 overdose-related deaths. By 2024, those numbers had dropped to 18 overdoses and four deaths.
So far in 2025, the county has recorded eight overdoses — and no overdose deaths — an encouraging sign, officials said. But they stressed that continued education and prevention efforts are needed to keep the numbers low.
"Even one death due to opioids is too many, and work must continue," coalition members said.
Education, Prevention and Treatment
Through awareness campaigns, free Narcan distribution by the county Health Department, a standard reporting system developed by Queen Anne's County Emergency Services, and the QAC Data Dashboard, local leaders say the effort is showing results.
In 2025, the initiative expanded its banners across the county to more than 100, all carrying the slogan: "Taking a stand against substance abuse."
Progress is being seen "across the board," said Warren Wright of QAC Goes Purple. He credited strict penalties for drug sellers, enforcement against tobacco and liquor outlets that sell to minors, and the strong work of the county's Drug Court.
Also contributing are Prevention Services, Peer Support Workers and the Local Management Board, which is conducting an asset-mapping project. The county Board of Education has added Bodkin life skills programs for younger students. The commissioners are working with neighboring counties to expand treatment services for residents at the Whitsitt Center.
Youth Involvement
Recognizing that most young people make choices about alcohol, tobacco and drug use during middle school, QAC Goes Purple has focused on youth outreach.
A Youth Risk Behavior Survey found that more than 13% of Queen Anne's County high school students reported taking a prescription drug not prescribed to them — a troubling trend that highlights the need for early conversations at home and in schools, officials said.
To reach peers directly, the QAC Drug-Free Student Ambassador Program includes students from public and private schools who design posters, lead team-building events and stage award-winning activities.
"We believe that involvement is key to prevention for our students," Wright said. "Join a team, try a club, and discover your passion. After-school programs and activities are offered through schools, the YMCA and the Giving the Edge Foundation."
Changing Perceptions
QAC Goes Purple emphasizes that substance use disorder is not a choice but a disease that affects the brain. Understanding the science of addiction, officials say, can reduce stigma and encourage compassion.
September is recognized as National Recovery Month, followed by Substance Use Prevention Month in October. International Overdose Awareness Day is marked every year on Aug. 31 to honor those lost and support families affected by substance use disorders.
"We can all make a difference," said Emily Keller, Maryland's special secretary of overdose response. "Hundreds of lives are saved every year from bystanders who had naloxone and knew what to do in the event of an overdose. We have to make sure that anyone who wants naloxone can access it wherever they are and whenever they need it."
Free naloxone is available at the Nielsen Center, 205 N. Liberty St., Centreville.
Upcoming Event
The sixth annual Going Purple Together event will be held Sept. 27 at Church Hill Park from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. The family-friendly gathering will feature live music, food trucks, face painting, dunk tanks and raffle prizes, while celebrating recovery and raising awareness.
The community is also invited to complete the QAC Goes Purple Marijuana Survey, available at the county Health Department website under the Behavioral Health tab.
"Everyone in Queen Anne's County can keep fighting by knowing the facts, discussing them with loved ones, colleagues and friends," Wright said.
More information is available at qacgoespurple.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on opioid overdose prevention, substance‑abuse education, naloxone distribution, and related health initiatives, making Health the most appropriate category.

title: Local testicular cancer survivor shoots for a hole in one
author: Amelia Blades Steward
content:
Local testicular cancer survivor shoots for a hole in one

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Amelia Blades Steward | Section: Events 
 
 867
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to Johns Hopkins Brady Urological Institute, testicular cancer is one of the most common cancers in young men, with nearly 10,000 new diagnoses each year in the United States. It is highly curable when it first develops but can quickly spread if not treated promptly.Andrew Dorbin of Preston is a husband, father and testicular cancer survivor who hopes to educate men about the risks and symptoms of testicular cancer at the "Putts Fore! Nuts" miniature golf tournament on Oct. 18 from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Embers Island Mini-Golf in Ocean City. The rain date will be Oct. 25.
Dorbin was diagnosed with late-stage testicular cancer (Choriocarcinoma) in the spring of 2023. It then metastasized to his lungs and abdomen.
While undergoing multiple rounds of chemotherapy, he was overwhelmed by the generosity of his family, friends and community, who rallied to support him and his family through his diagnosis and treatment. That experience of compassion and care lit a fire in him.
"During my longest inpatient stay at Johns Hopkins Hospital, I witnessed other patients facing their battle alone without the same support system I had. That was hard for me to stomach. It made me realize that I wanted to give back when I was able and build something that could offer strength, resources and connection to others navigating their fight against testicular cancer," Dorbin said.
"Honestly, I'm not particularly good at regular golf — I'm only there for my friend's comic relief — but I've always enjoyed miniature golf and came up with this funny tournament name on one of the sickest days of my treatment," he said.
The idea eventually grew, and Dorbin founded the Wayfinders Testicular Health Fund, a component fund of Chesapeake Charities Inc., a Maryland-based nonprofit. The fund is focused on raising awareness, providing education and building a supportive community fighting this disease.
He is committed to making testicular health a topic that young men are not afraid to talk about and ensuring that no one faces cancer without a community standing beside them. The tournament is the first step to accomplishing that.
"I chose an amazing partner in Chesapeake Charities to help make my dream a reality. The money that was used to found this venture came from what was left over from my personal GoFundMe campaign, making this essentially a 100% community-funded initiative," Dorbin said.
The fund's fundraising efforts will go toward community networking opportunities and mental health and wellness programs to ensure no one feels like they are facing the testicular cancer fight alone. Dorbin hopes his educational outreach will encourage young men to challenge the stigmas and pay attention to their health.
"We are encouraging our communities of young men, ages 14 to 35, to be aware of their bodies and to take action when something doesn't feel right," he said.
Dorbin reflects on his journey, sharing, "My journey almost ended before it started. When I found the lump, I almost didn't act. It seems petty now, but I was worried about the cost of my health insurance deductible and thought it was nothing serious. Through the encouragement of a friend who was a nurse, I decided to get it checked out. If I had not acted as quickly as I did, I'm not sure I would be sitting here today."
He said that, like him, men in their early 20s and 30s feel they are invincible and that they will not develop any major medical issues.
"No one wants to go to the doctor when they are young. Also, I had never been shown how to correctly check myself for abnormalities in my testicles. Self-examination is key to early detection," he said.
Dorbin hopes that teens and adults will participate in the tournament while learning more about the disease and how to protect themselves and their loved ones. He shares that the event will also create community connection — helping people learn who the disease is affecting, what support people need and connecting people to resources in the community.
"This event is going to be a blast. Participants can expect to play two rounds of mini-golf, all while challenging their knowledge, luck, and putting skills. Hole Hecklers — professional comedians will set up a mock sports casting both at one of the miniature golf holes and roast participants as they putt. We also have a variety of prizes and awards that will make the event enjoyable for everyone. For me, the best part is that you don't have to be standing on the podium to walk away a winner," Dorbin said.
In the future, Dorbin hopes that the Wayfinders Testicular Health Fund can support outings for survivors of testicular cancer and help build a community of survivors, since many men still suffer in silence with the stigma attached to the disease.
"This launch would not be possible without the incredible generosity of my friends, family, and neighbors here on Maryland's Eastern Shore. Their belief in this mission, and in me, has carried me through the toughest years of my life," he adds.
Sponsorships are still available for the event. Registration information and sponsorship opportunities are available at wayfindersthf.org. Participants are limited, and registration will be available online on Sept. 18. Registration is non-refundable.
For further information, contact Andrew Dorbin at wayfindersthf@gmail.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a testicular cancer survivor raising awareness, providing education on early detection, and promoting health resources, making health the primary focus.

title: Wellness center offers support for mothers on the Shore
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Wellness center offers support for mothers on the Shore

 October 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 661
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center opened its doors last October to provide women on the Eastern Shore with a single, trusted source for various services.Samantha Basham Loza was inspired to create a space like this after having her first child in the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. She was astounded by the lack of resources, education and community she had during this time.
"I was so blindsided by the entire experience, and it was really frustrating because I consider myself a highly educated person that works hard to find the right resources," Loza said. "And the fact that I couldn't even find what I needed to help me at each stage of this process was just completely shocking."
The entire process of giving birth was scary for Loza. She was at a hospital in Anne Arundel County and was given an epidural that made her completely numb from her neck down, which she said caused her to have a panic attack.
Loza said her daughter was immediately transferred to the NICU after delivery.
Because she was was numb from the epidural, the baby was crowning without Loza realizing or feeling it, and none of the doctors or nurses noticed. This caused Loza's daughter to have meconium aspiration syndrome. According to John's Hopkins Medicine, meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in 5 to 10% of births.
"I was reflecting on that entire experience thinking like, 'How is this the standard?'" Loza said.
With her first child, Loza said she didn't have the knowledge base on the process of giving birth, breastfeeding or managing hormonal changes. She described the experience as isolating.
"We don't talk about pregnancy often enough, and how isolating it can be, and all the changes and all the sacrifices. We don't talk about fertility issues often enough. We don't talk about miscarriages enough. We don't teach any of it," Loza said.
She said her goal with the wellness center is to start these conversations and create community while doing so.
The center offers an array of classes and playgroups for children. There are courses for pregnant women and new moms, and the University of Maryland's obstetrics practice comes in to talk about fertility and prenatal care quarterly.
In addition, the wellness center has birth doulas, massage therapists, lactation consultants, a speech language pathologist, a pediatric nurse practitioner and a craniosacral therapist, who will be starting in November.
"A really big misconception about the name of the business, The Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center, is that holistic means crunchy and it doesn't," Loza said. "It just means we're considering you as a whole person."
Loza defined a doula as a non-medical support person who provides educational, physical and emotional support during pregnancy, birth and postpartum and also helps connect clients with resources.
The center recently received a grant from the Talbot County Health Department to fund the training of 18 new doulas, four of whom are bilingual and two of which whom exclusively speak Spanish. The grant is also assisting the doulas with Medicaid credentialing.
When Loza got pregnant with her second child, she decided to have a home birth midwife, one of the first contacts she made when looking into starting her business.
Loza said her pregnancy and birth with her son was a completely different experience than with her daughter.
"It was so personal. She knew exactly where I was coming from. She knew exactly what was happening with my mental state, and what I was eating and all the things. And she always had a recommendation for a book to read, or YouTube videos to watch or things like that," Loza said.
"Though she planned to deliver at home, she was transferred to the Easton Hospital because her son's heart rate was low. Her midwife stayed by her side and advocated for her throughout the process.
After having two very different birthing experiences, Loza has become passionate about educating pregnant women about the entirety of the process. She hopes to expand the centers services by opening a nonprofit arm in the near future. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a maternal wellness center offering health services, doula support, lactation consulting, and prenatal education, making health the primary theme, with education as a secondary aspect.

title: Broomsticks look to sweep away breast cancer
author: Staff Writer
content:
Broomsticks look to sweep away breast cancer

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines

 Read News Document

 Witches and warlocks paddled down the Miles River in costume Wednesday, combining Halloween spirit with breast cancer awareness and early detection education.The inaugural witch paddle at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel raised $28,200 for Breastcancer.org and Clark Comprehensive Breast Center. Dr. Drummey, of the University of Maryland Shore Medical Group, emphasized that routine mammograms should begin at age 40, or earlier for those with family history.
As UM Shore Regional Community Health outreach specialist Catalina Billings noted, self-examinations are crucial because "no one knows your body like you do."

title: Broomsticks battle breast cancer in first witch paddle
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Broomsticks battle breast cancer in first witch paddle

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Witches and warlocks floated down the Miles River on adorned paddle boards and kayaks for broomsticks and dressed in witches hats, wigs and costumes.The first ever witch paddle to support Breastcancer.org and Clark Comprehensive Breast Center took place at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel on Oct. 15 and raised $28,200, just shy of its $30,000 goal.
The event was a nice mix of Halloween fun and education on breast cancer awareness and early screening measures from doctors, volunteers and those who have experienced the disease firsthand.
As the witches paddled down the river at leisure, survivors and doctors spoke to attendees.
Chelsey Townsend, who is now one year cancer free, received the devastating news that she was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer in December 2023 at the age of 28.
Townsend got her diagnoses after genetic testing that revealed a breast cancer gene mutation, which prompted her to get an early mammogram. She credits her doctor, Audrey Drummey, for saving her life.
Drummey is a doctor in obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Group in Easton. During the event, Drummey highlighted the importance of proactive genetic evaluation and early detection, especially if the disease runs in the family.
She emphasized the importance of access to genetic testing in health care and leveraging available resources.
Drummy said routine mammograms should start at age 40 unless there is a family history of breast cancer in which earlier screening may be recommended and potentially covered by health insurance.
In addition, she said a healthy diet, regular exercise, intaking less than seven alcoholic drinks a week and breastfeeding are good preventative measures.
For Townsend who said she doesn't like to be vulnerable, it was important to reframe her vulnerability as a strength. As she told her story, she was nervous and emotional while recounting her experience as a breast cancer survivor.
She encouraged attendees to check in on their friends post-treatment saying that community is incredibly important because a diagnoses like this can instill fear and change your perspective entirely.
"People think that we go through this experience, and when it's over, that we're OK. And we are OK, we survived, but for your mental health it's still something where every little thing that goes wrong, there's still that fear," Townsend said.
Townsend does not want others to live in fear, which is why she encourages other women — like her two sisters — to do self breast exams and early screenings. UM Shore Regional Community Health outreach specialist Catalina Billings encourages self examinations because "no one knows your body like you do."

title: I don't come from political lineage
author: Kiersten Hacker; Capital News Service
content:
I don't come from political lineage

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kiersten Hacker; Capital News Service | Page: A4 | Section: News 
 
 600
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Gov. Wes Moore fended off questions Tuesday on whether he'll run in the 2024 Democratic presidential primary during an interview with global news organization Semafor, saying he had no interest in higher office and turning the subject to his nontraditional political background."I think it's really important for people to remember that I am probably the most improbable governor in this country," Moore said in answer to the first question from Semafor cofounder and Editor-at-large Steve Clemons. "I'm a person who has never come from a political lineage." Moore, an author, nonprofit executive and former Army officer, had not held political office before winning the governor's election in 2022.Moore turned his focus to Maryland, discussing plans to revive the state's economy through targeted investments in its assets and better serve constituents with a data-driven approach to policy changes.Moore often defines Maryland as "asset-rich and strategy-poor," and cites the contrast presented by the state's high concentration of prominent institutions of higher education, military facilities and government agencies, such as the National Security Agency, with its sluggish economic growth rate of.2% in the past 4 years. The current economic strategy of spreading funding across numerous projects "doesn't make sense," he said, explaining he'll use a more focused approach.In June, Moore established the Maryland Economic Council, charging it with creating economic recommendations by the next legislative session in January. After the General Assembly passed numerous measures to affect systemic budgetary changes during the last session, a report from the Department of Legislative Services predicted a $418 million structural deficit for fiscal year 2025.Moore said his administration will use data to drive policy decisions, especially when looking to minimize socioeconomic disparities, and he used environmental injustice in Baltimore as an example."You can't understand what these disparities look like if we aren't able to fully appreciate the measure of intentionality that very much existed in the creation of that and the lack of intentionality when it comes to how we're going to address it." The administration must consider the root causes of poverty, investing in transit, the public education system and programs to combat the teacher shortage, Moore said, to jumpstart economic growth.Creating new opportunities for young people to succeed in different areas will help fight juvenile crime and keep violence out of communities, Moore said. Using data and technology in innovative ways can also help ensure that solutions to crime are predictive rather than reactive.Increasing public safety is his top priority, Moore said, highlighting the need for "appropriate intensity, absolute integrity, and full accountability" in the policing system as well as a need for crisis intervention teams to shift the response of mental health calls away from police officers. Over $100 million was invested directly in behavioral health, Moore said.Moore noted that police officers respond to all situations, and many times they are met with circumstances they cannot fix.He called for change, saying that public safety is in part a matter of creating a better livelihood for people.Moore said his administration invested $122 million in local law enforcement, $17.5 million of which went to Baltimore City, where the police department has been under a federal agreement to make reforms since 2016.Moore also invested in intelligence sharing through the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center and organized crime units.In Baltimore, other reform means combating gun trafficking, filling the police shortage with well-trained officers, and developing more intentional solutions, said Moore, who places special importance on these issues as a Baltimore native."I love my state, all 24 jurisdictions. But I'm a Baltimorean," Moore said."That's who I am. Can't understand me if you don't understand Baltimore." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland Governor Wes Moore's policies, budget, and public safety initiatives, which are central to state-level governance, making 'Local Government' the most fitting category.

title: Caroline Commissioners OK reallocation bill
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Commissioners OK reallocation bill

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: B2 | Section: News 
 
 507
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Caroline County Commissioners passed legislation Tuesday, Sept. 12, to use funds originally intended for renovating the county detention center for additional county renovation projects.The commissioners reallocated a portion of the proceeds of the $34.2 million consolidated public improvement and refunding bonds of 2019 to pay for roof replacements for Federalsburg and Preston elementary schools and North Caroline High School, as well as HVAC in the Fretterd Center in Denton.The first reading of Bill 2023-002 took place Aug. 15. No public comments were offered at each of the three readings of the bill."Earlier this year it was identified that we have not used the proceeds of the 2019 bond issuance for renovation of the detention center. And as a result, the commissioners have directed us to reallocate the funding of the project," County Attorney Stewart Barroll said.In other business, the commissioners heard a proposal about a potential Hobbs Solar Project to be built on the capped landfill.Jack Martell, manager of business development, and Greg Werner, manager of Massachusetts-based Nexamp Solar, Inc. presented a slide show and answered questions from the commissioners about the proposed 5,000-panel solar project.The company proposed to "finance, build, own and maintain" solar facilities on 15 acres at the landfill at 26375 Hobbs Road and "extend the financial benefits of the generated electricity, land lease and tax revenue" to the county government and public schools.Nexamp Solar projected a total benefit of $121,152 at the end of the first year, and a total benefit at the end of its 20-year lifespan of nearly $2 million.The commissioners took no action on the proposal at this meeting.Also on the agenda was Susan Runnels, director of the Caroline Human Services Council, who discussed transportation needs and how they're currently being to serve two towns in the county."In my opinion, mobility on demand doesn't work in Caroline County," Runnels said.Few people used the service, which serves Greensboro and Federalsburg residents for in-county rides. Those towns qualify for state grant funding for transportation in lower income areas.For example, Runnels said the service, which uses Delmarva Community Transit, supplied 48 rides from Greensboro and 15 from Federalsburg from March through June. Many of those rides were called by the same persons, she said."I don't think this is feasible for us," she said. "But we need some kind of transportation in the county we'd be better off going back to taxi service." Runnels said she would prefer to take almost $27,000 in state grants that she has to return to the state and use those funds to help to pay for driver's education classes for teen drivers or vehicle repairs in the target communities."We can't have our dollars just sitting in a parking lot waiting for a call," she said. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Jack Martell, left, manager of business development, and Greg Werner, manager of Massachusetts-based Nexamp Solar, Inc. present a slide show and answer questions from the Caroline County Commissioners at their Sept. 12 meeting about a proposed solar project at the Hobbs landfill. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'It's going to carry us into the future' - U.S. Constitution celebrated at Talbot County Courthouse
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'It's going to carry us into the future' - U.S. Constitution celebrated at Talbot County Courthouse

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 531
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Star-Spangled Banner, performed by 35 students from Easton Middle School, resounded in the area surrounding the Talbot County Courthouse Saturday, Sept. 16.The band's rendition of the national anthem kicked off the second annual Constitution Day celebration in Easton. A crowd gathered to listen to speeches, enjoy Rita's Italian Ice and learn more about the Constitution of the United States.The event was hosted by the Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance.Along with speeches from an array of people - from elected officials to students - actor Darius Wallace performed a re-enactment of Frederick Douglass speaking about freedom and the Constitution.Wallace received a standing ovation for his performance.Easton resident John Miller was especially impressed with Wallace's performance."That took great appreciation of our freedoms and made us aware of how important our freedoms were and what slavery means and that there is still work to do," Miller said.Miller said it's important that the Constitution is still acknowledged today because it's "where our government gets its power." Speakers at the event, who talked about the importance of the Constitution, included Maryland State Sen. Johnny Mautz; Tarence Bailey Sr., founder and president of The Bailey-Groce Family Foundation; Joseph Prud'Homme, a professor in Religion, Politics, and Culture at Washington College; Zach Affeldt, a student at Washington College; William Fachet, a student at University of Maryland College Park; Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and Ron James, a Veterans of Foreign Wars member.Mautz talked about his experience delving into the Constitution at law school."Never did I think that the Constitution was fun or exciting until you start to talk about free speech," he said. "And then we're into the good stuff." Mautz said that without free speech protections in the Constitution, we wouldn't be standing here today.Bailey spoke about the Constitution being important for everyday life during his speech."I think it's very important, especially for youth, that they learn the Constitution, know what's in it and know what applies to them," he said.Michelle Ewing, co-director of the Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance, said the mission of the organization is to educate the public and raise awareness about the U.S Constitution. She said the group offers scholarships to graduating seniors and non-traditional students who want to go back to school."We want to get the youth involved and informed," she said.At the end of his speech, Mautz talked about the importance of the Constitution today."We have to go back to the Constitution and use the Constitution to fix the problems, not tear it apart," he said. "It's gotten us to where we are. It is going to carry us into the future." 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Actor Darius Wallace performing a re-enactment of Frederick Douglass in front of the Talbot County Courthouse for Constitution Day Sept. 16.
 
MA GGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Maryland State Sen. Johnny Mautz speaks at Constitution Day in front of the Talbot County Courthouse Sept. 16. "Never did I think that the Constitution was fun or exciting until you start to talk about free speech," he said. "And then we're into the good stuff."
 
MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Ron James, a Veterans of Foreign Wars member, plays "Taps" outside the Talbot County Courthouse for Constitution Day Sept. 16. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester County Local Appointed To Commission On Indian Affairs
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com
content:
Dorchester County Local Appointed To Commission On Indian Affairs

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Former Dorchester County Council Vice President and member of the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians Tom Bradshaw has been appointed to the Maryland Commission on Indian Affairs.Bradshaw said he was nominated for the position before the COVID-19 pandemic began.
"It was a whole myriad of things that just drew it out," he said. "So finally, with the new administration, everything got ironed out."
According to a news release from the Gov. Wes Moore's office, the appointments were made in partnership with tribal leaders and councils.
The news release states that Bradshaw has "lifelong ties to a range of cultural institutions and initiatives committed to supporting and promoting indigenous history."
Born in Cambridge, Bradshaw has spent his career in the agriculture, seafood and timber industries. He served on the Dorchester County Council, representing District 5, from 2014 through 2018. He served on the Maryland Heritage Areas Authority Board from 2016 to 2018.
Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott, of the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians, said that she, along with other members of the Nause-Waiwash, are excited to have Bradshaw representing them.
"He knows what our needs are and what our concerns are," Abbott said. "So we're happy to have him in that position."
When Bradshaw got the news of the appointment, Abbott was the first person he told.
"I'm a historian and I learned a lot of indigenous history from her predecessor," Bradshaw said.
In his new role, Bradshaw, along with eight other appointees, will be tasked with helping to obtain state and federal recognition for the state's indigenous tribes and communities, collecting data on the contributions of the Marylands's indigenous communities and promoting awareness of those contributions.
Bradshaw said that he looks forward to working with those in education "to teach them our history." He said he also looks forward to bringing attention to the needs of the tribal community.
"He will probably be working with different committees on hopefully getting the curriculum for the public schools system changed to include more of our history," Abbott said.
Bradshaw said he is excited to work with the other commissioners.
"I think we can accomplish some good things," he said.
"We've got a diverse representation of the tribal communities across the state." 
 
 Caption: HEART OF CHESAPEAKE CO UNTRY HERITAGE AREA

 Heritage Board Vice Chair Tom Bradshaw (left) and Pat Neild, president emeritus of the South Dorchester Folk Museum, after the Museum's award from the Chesapeake Country Heritage Area was announced in 2022. Bradshaw has been appointed to the Maryland Commission on Indian Affairs. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: A spacious and welcoming place - Central branch reopens main floor following a year of renovations
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
A spacious and welcoming place - Central branch reopens main floor following a year of renovations

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 986
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Following a year of renovating and redesigning, the central branch of the Caroline County Public Library at 100 Market Street in the county seat reopened its first floor space Dec. 18.The soft reopening is designed to help staff fine tune details as they welcome patrons and visitors. A grand opening celebration is planned when the new elevator is finished in spring 2024.
New carpet, neutral walls, fresh shelving and new furniture create welcoming decor in the more open spaces of the library's main floor. The main desk is bigger and moved away from the wall, making it easier for staff members to see most of the library's interior.
Bennett said she wanted people to experience the library as "bright, open and inviting."
"This is perfect," customer Romont Fletcher of Denton said Dec. 20 as he set up his laptop on the desk attached to an upholstered chair. He had not been in the library for a year and was surprised when he walked in. "This is a great renovation," he said.
"This is good space, and it's flexible space," Executive Director Debby Bennett said. "It's a well-built library." Bennett, who has been with the library since 1983, will retire in June 2024.
"In 1983, people came in, got their books and checked them out and went home," Bennett said. "Now people come to stay, whether it's work on our computer, hang out with their friends in the Teen Zone, a family comes in and spends time looking for materials and just spending time here, small meetings in the study room, research in the Maryland room."
The $2.1 million renovation project began Jan. 2, 2023. Bennett, the Caroline County Board of Library Trustees and library staff met their goal of reopening the first floor to the public before Christmas.
The central branch has experienced many changes in its 62-year history. Card catalogs and hand-stamping due dates have been computerized. Circulating books are still a staple, but today library card holders can check out a Cricut machine, sewing machines and even fishing poles.
The central branch has 13,739 card holders who can check out materials, but visitors can obtain guest passes to use the public computers.
As if to illustrate the changes, two days after reopening, four teenaged young men checked out software to play games on library Xboxes in the Teen Zone.
The renovation was funded mainly by two "highly competitive" State Library Capital Grants, Bennett said.
In addition to replacing the roof slates on the library's 1995 addition, the building underwent extensive first floor renovations.
Phase 2 includes improving the elevator in 2024.
The Phase 1 grant in fiscal year 2023 financed 79%, or $917,000 of the project.
The library board provided the local match of $244,000 from their John Hargreaves fund.
This phase included replacing three HVAC units at the end of their useful life, improving lighting, upgrading the emergency fire alarm system and phone system, enhancing electrical capacity for increased technology, removing the wall dividing the two children's rooms, providing a family bathroom adjacent to the children's areas, increasing seating capacity, improving sight lines and creating quiet areas. The improvements brought the library into compliance with ADA requirements.
The cost didn't include shelving, furniture and other additional costs that were incurred throughout the renovation, about $335,236. The library paid for those costs, except for $78,000 raised by the Friends of the Library for shelving for the adult, young adult and Maryland Room collections.
Phase 2 is being funded by a fiscal year 2024 State Library Capital Grant that pays for 78%, or $467,000, of the project, with the remaining $132,000 provided by the Caroline County Commissioners.
This phase includes replacing the elevator, which is "at the end of its useful life," Bennett said.
The new elevator will comply with ADA requirements and current codes.
The phase also includes replacing the addition's 4,000 square foot roof with artificial slate, which had deteriorated and become a "serious safety hazard," Bennett said.
The elevator provides access to public space, administrative offices and the third floor attic storage area.
"The (two-sided) main service desk is going to work a lot better for staff to both answer basic questions and check out items, and also to be able to work with people with more complex reference questions," Bennett said. "And also we have so much better visibility of the other desks and more areas of library to see who might need help (and) for security."
"Back in 1995 when we renovated and added on, we didn't have cell phones and laptops and iPads," Bennett said, adding that the internet was fairly new then.
"The MakerSpace used to be our reference area in 1995 with 7-foot shelves of reference books. Now, all the reference materials are online."
More square footage not taken up by books "frees up more people space," she said.
There's a lot to figure out," Bennett said. "Half our staff are new and didn't work down here. And for all the staff, it's a new layout. So it's a matter of figuring out procedures and ironing out all the little extra things. So opening like this without a big fanfare - and this is a quiet time of the year anyway - is giving us time to figure a lot so that things go smoothly for staff and customers."
"I've seen a lot of changes, but this library has always been innovative," Bennett said. "It's always been forward-thinking and also thinking: What does the community need? What does community need that they don't even know they need?" 
 
 Caption: From left are Caroline County Public Library central branch staff members Kelly Emory, Mitchell Downes, Executive Director Debby Bennett and Emerging Services Manager Vicki Burchfield.

 "This is perfect," says Romont Fletcher of Denton regarding the newly renovated central branch of Caroline County Public Library.

 The Market Street entrance of Caroline County Public Library's central branch in Denton faces the courthouse.

 New carpet, shelving and furniture add to the fresh look of the central branch.

 The Teen Zone is an inviting space for gaming and online work and research. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a county public library renovation, detailing funding, board decisions, and community services, which aligns most closely with local government activities.

title: Candidates file for May primary election
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Candidates file for May primary election

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 597
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Voters across the state and on the Mid-Shore will have a full slate of candidates to vote for in this year's upcoming elections.Although 2024 will be marked nationally by a presidential election, Maryland residents will be casting their ballots for a U.S. senator and congressional representative. Locally, Mid-Shore residents will be voting for new county Board of Education members.
Maryland's primary election will be held on Tuesday, May 14, from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Early primary voting will run from Thursday, May 2, to Thursday, May 9.
The general election is Tuesday, Nov. 5, from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Early voting runs from Thursday, Oct. 24, to Thursday, Oct. 31.
U.S. Senate
The race for the next U.S. senator is a crowded one — 10 Democrats and eight Republicans have filed to run for the seat being vacated by current U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin. Three candidates not affiliated with either party have filed to run.
Several candidates are previous or current elected officials.
Congressional District 1Incumbent Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican, is seeking to maintain his position representing the 1st District. He's not without challengers, though — four others have filed in the hopes of winning the seat.
Blane Miller and Blessing T. Oluwadare, both Democrats from Harford County, filed to run against Harris. Fellow Harford County resident Chris Bruneau Sr. is running in the race as a Republican.
Caroline County resident Michael Scott Lemon, a Republican, is hoping to win the seat.
Talbot County Board of EducationSeven candidates have filed to run in this year's election for the three open seats in District 2, District 5 and District 6 on the Talbot County Board of Education.
In District 2, incumbent Board of Education member and current Vice president Candace Henry is running for reelection to her seat. Residents Connie Loveland and Ann C. O'Connor also filed to run for the seat.
In District 5, current Board of Education member Anna Howie is running for her first full term on the board. Howie was appointed to the District 5 seat last October after former Board President Susan Delean-Botkin vacated the district seat.
Trappe resident Karla Wieland-Cherry is Howie's sole challenger in the District 5 race.
The Board's District 6 seat will be the only one definitely seeing a new face after this year's election — incumbent board member Mary Wheeler did not file to run again.
Easton residents Kerry Gunshenan and Cynthia Marrah Jurrius will face off for the District 6 seat.
Dorchester County Board of EducationEight candidates filed for the three open seats on the Dorchester County Board of Education. Incumbents from each district are running to maintain their seats on the board.
In Councilmanic District 1, current board President Michael Diaz Sr. is running for reelection. Diaz is being challenged by Brandy Dawson Cumberland and Lucas Thorpe.
In Councilmanic District 3, current board Vice President Susan V. Morgan is vying for reelection. Cambridge resident Christine LaMonica is seeking the seat as well.
Chris Wheedleton, the incumbent Councilmanic District 5 board member who was appointed to his seat last year, is running for a full term on the board in this year's election. Candidates Jerome J. Harris and Michael Hartford also are running for the open seat.
Caroline County Board of EducationAlthough the terms of three members of the five-member Caroline County Board of Education are ending this year, only two are up for election by the public: the District 1 and District 2 seats.
A third seat opening up this year will be filled by gubernatorial appointment.
No candidates have filed to run for the District 1 seat.
In District 2, Stefanie D. Johnson is the sole candidate seeking the open seat. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details candidate filings for primary elections and local Board of Education seats, which are primarily matters of local government and electoral processes.

title: Local lightning rods: Social media, national divisions changing local politics
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National enterprise editor
content:
Local lightning rods: Social media, national divisions changing local politics

 March 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National enterprise editor | Section: News 
 
 449
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Megan Cook, Russ Nelson and Ann Groves Lloyd are mayors of small towns in Maryland, Montana and Wisconsin.Nelson has been the mayor of Belgrade, Montana, for 20 years.
Karen Rose has been with Sarasota County Schools in Florida for more than three decades serving as a special education teacher, middle school principal and since 2020 on the local school board.
Over their tenures, the quartet and local officials across the country have seen the exponential growth of social media and its impacts on civil discourse, as well as the increasing intersections between divisive national politics and what's happening at the community level.
School board, city council and county commission meetings have all become venues for fights over controversial curriculums and books, COVID rules, drag shows at public libraries and national issues with advocates from the left and right looking for local debates on immigration, abortion and Israel's war in Gaza.
Rose said public comments at school board meetings can be very political and very partisan. "It's very organized," Rose said.
Social media, with its expansive reach, along with online meetings allow more residents and businesses to engage with and keep tabs on local governments and schools. That can also help bring more transparency to city halls, local law enforcement and school districts.
"The more information that we share with the public about what's happening in town, the better. We also have a live feed for all of our council, board and commission meetings. If residents aren't able to make it, they can always watch the recordings from our website," said Cook, mayor of Easton.
But social media also magnifies broader contemporary distrust of the media, government, politicians and other institutions. It can also bring rumor mills and coarse discourse.
"From a city perspective, we just wish people would pick up the phone and call us. We are constantly fighting the rumor mill," said Groves Lloyd, mayor of Lodi, Wisconsin (a small town near Madison).
Groves Lloyd identifies herself as a "progressive feminist" and "small town mayor" on her X/Twitter account where she is no fan of former president Donald Trump. But the Wisconsin mayor said she's pulled back on her progressive posts, especially on Facebook, because of the atmosphere of social media.
In Montana, Nelson, the mayor of Belgrade (which has a population approaching 13,000 people), worries all the political tensions at the local level discourages candidates for office and shortens tenures for staff and officeholders. He avoids social media altogether.
"I'm not on Facebook. I'm not on social media," said Nelson. "You can call me, or if you need me, you can text me. That's my technology."
For a more expansive look at the issue check out our story online and in our national e-edition on Monday, March 11. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mayors, city councils, and school board meetings, discussing how social media and national political divisions affect local governance and community decision‑making, making Local Government the most fitting category.

title: Talbot Council introduces 2025 budget
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot Council introduces 2025 budget

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, the Talbot County Council voted unanimously to introduce the proposed fiscal year 2025 general fund budget of $163,970,000.The budget will include an education increase of $3.65 million from the 2024 budget.
Talbot County Public Schools will receive $54.6 million in total funding, according to the proposed budget. This increase will go toward the capital project request for planned Chapel District Elementary School renovations and other capital projects.
The increase in the education budget is due, in part, to the implications of the Maryland Blueprint for Education plan. Blueprint is a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state by increasing education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years.
"Maryland Blueprint required local share funding to increase by $1.053 million for FY2025 budget," Martha Sparks, finance director for Talbot County, said at the Tuesday meeting. "In addition to the mandated funding, the county has included an additional appropriation of $2.6 million. Funding to support Talbot County Schools increased overall by $3.65 million above FY24 levels."
Education spending represents 37.7% of the county's total proposed budget. These numbers include Talbot County Public Schools, Chesapeake College and the Talbot County Free Library expenses.
The budget also allocates an additional $1.5 million in capital improvement project funding for Talbot County Public Schools to prioritize other projects.
The budget discussion included the option to expand the amendment of the 1-cent increase in property tax rates for public safety.
In November 2020, Talbot County voters approved an amendment allowing a 1-cent increase to the property tax rate to support public safety spending. This increase began in the FY2022 budget and will continue until the FY2026 budget.
Revenues from the 1-cent increase have been used to fund 26 new public safety positions across departments, such as deputies, paramedics, emergency medical technicians and 911 operators. The funds from the amendment have allowed for inclusion of sheriff's office, paramedics/EMTs and correctional officers in enhanced retirement programs for public safety employees.
Sparks noted that the county has used more than the funds provided by the 1-cent increase to public safety.
"The county has used more than the revenues generated from the 1 cent to enhance public safety personnel serving the citizens and visitors of Talbot County," she said.
The council has the option to allow county residents to extend the 1-cent increase beyond FY2026 through a ballot initiative for voters in the November 2024 general election.
Clay Stamp, county manager for Talbot County, expressed his admiration for the county's finance team for their work on the budget.
"There's a lot of hard work that went into drafting the FY 25 proposed balanced budget," Stamp said. "While we're here tonight, I want to thank the council for your cooperation and support over the last number of months."
Two public hearings will be held to gather community input before final approval.
A public hearing will be held on May 7 at 2 p.m. in the Talbot County Courthouse and at 7 p.m. in the Easton Elementary School cafeteria, located at 307 Glenwood Avenue.

title: Talbot County Council holds public hearings on budget
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot County Council holds public hearings on budget

 May 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday, the Talbot County Council reviewed the 2024-2025 county budget with a 4.76 cent increase in the property tax rate, a 6.4% increase.The council held two public hearings for the annual fiscal year budget Tuesday, the first at the Talbot County Courthouse and the second in the Easton Elementary School cafeteria.
Martha Sparks, finance director of Talbot County, said Talbot County has a conservative approach to proposed budgets that prioritizes public safety and education for the county.
The increase 4.76 cent property tax rate increase includes a 1-cent raise previously approved by voters to support public safety and a 4-cent "education supplement" to increase funding for Talbot County Public Schools.
The 2025 fiscal year budget allocates $54.6 million to Talbot County Public Schools. This is an increase of $3.65 million from last year's budget and $2.8 million above the required local share funding. The budget exceeds the state-mandated funding level for Talbot County Public Schools, which is proposed at 43.3% of the county's 2025 operating budget.
The Capital Improvement Project budget included funding for Talbot County Public Schools, which includes $16.9 million for capital projects. Capital projects included in the 2025 budget include an expansion of the Talbot County Free Library in St. Michaels and renovation of the Chapel District Elementary School in Cordova.
Sparks told the council that during a review by Moody's Investors Service of the county's budget, Talbot was given rave reviews. Sparks said Moody's Investors Service described the budget as "very strong, and the management team is generally conservative in its budgeting."
PUBLIC HEARINGDuring the public hearing, Dana Newman, director of the Talbot County Free Library, thanked the council for funding the expansion of the Talbot County Free Library and supporting education for the county.
"The St. Michaels library is just a wonderful place. I was there this morning, there were people from the Benedictine school, their staff were just making them laugh, it was a really joyful experience to see that. That happens in county libraries every day; we just have two libraries," Newman said. "... We just want to make sure that the spaces are adequate and that they serve the public in the best way possible."
Cliff Coppersmith, president of Chesapeake College, and Karen Smith, CFO of Chesapeake College, appeared before the council representing Chesapeake College. Coppersmith thanked the council for its support of the college in the 2025 budget.
"It's because of the support of you as leaders in our regional county setup that we have posted five county institution, the only one of its kind in the state of Maryland," Coppersmith said. "But we do appreciate the unanimous support we have from all of you, which I can say all of you have some connection to the college."
Susan Sherman, president of the Public County Library Board of Trustees, and Charles Yonkers, member of the Board of Trustees, spoke during the public hearing. Sherman began by thanking the council for its support.
"I want to thank you for your support of the St. Michael's expansion," Sherman said. "I think it's such a wonderful example of community involvement and responsibility as community members. So, thank you. I think your response to our community is just amazing, and it feels so much appreciated.
Further discussion on the 2025 budget will be held on May 14. The council will vote on the proposed budget on May 28. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a county council's public hearings and decisions about the municipal budget, property tax rates, and funding allocations, which is core local government coverage.

title: Talbot Council recognizes several organizations
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot Council recognizes several organizations

 May 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 288
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday afternoon, Talbot County Council recognized community leaders and organizations from various groups for their service to the community.Talbot County Council gave a certificate of recognition to Building African American Minds (BAAM) for the organization's 20 years of service to the Talbot County community and for providing services to over 1,200 African American students.
Located in Easton, the nonprofit provides scholarships, afterschool programing, summer camp, and more to empower at-risk youth in the community.
"I felt that it was very important, incredibly important to recognize the organization for the number of years that you've been in this community and serving the boys and girls in this community," Commissioner Keasha Haythe said.
The Talbot County Council unanimously approved a proclamation declaring May to be Motorcycle Safety and Awareness Month. The month will be dedicated to promoting safe driving techniques that help keep motorists, particularly motorcyclists, safe, such as using turn signals and avoiding distracted driving.
Ken Eaton, executive director of ABATE of Maryland, said he was thankful for the proclamation and the support the government has given in spreading motorcycle safety awareness. ABATE of Maryland is an organization dedicated to representing the rights of motorcyclists.
The Talbot County Council unanimously approved a proclamation for Correctional Officers and Employees Week from May 5 through May 11.
Joseph Hughes, deputy director of corrections for Talbot County, thanked the council for all the support it has provided over the last year.
Hughes then praised the correction officers, saying, "I've been in corrections for 30 years, and these are some of the best correction officers out there."
The Department of Corrections will celebrate Correctional Officers and Employees Week with a series of events for employees, thanking them for their service, the county said in a press release.

title: Caroline County commissioners discuss FY 2025 budget, years ahead
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Caroline County commissioners discuss FY 2025 budget, years ahead

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 878
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On May 7 the Caroline County Commissioners convened to present the fiscal year 2025 budget, but the budget discussion looked at what's to come in years ahead.Discussions featured two prominent, long-term issues — the county's revenue-generating landfill and the state-mandated Blueprint for Education program.
The budget overview also covered the operating budget, capital budgets, proposed tax rates and municipal real property tax differential rates.
Looking forward, Commissioner Larry Porter said The Mid-Shore II Regional Landfill will generate $420,000 a year in revenue if it stays in Caroline County.
In the late 1980s, due to new federal regulations, the counties had to close their landfills and replace them with new landfills. In response to this new regulation, Talbot, Caroline and Queen Anne's counties engaged with MES to form a partnership where each county would take turns hosting a landfill for a 20-year term. Kent County later joined that partnership.
Caroline County is hosting the current landfill and, under the original arrangement, would be off the hook at the end of 2030 when Queen Anne's County would take over the responsibility of host. However, the partnering counties have agreed to allow the landfill to stay in Caroline County for 12 years longer than initially planned.
Dan Fox, deputy administrator, said the county will receive a revenue increase of around $12.3 million over the duration of the extended agreement at a meeting held earlier on May 7. The counties agreed on a $3 per ton post fee until 2030. In 2031 it will rise to $6.
"Landfill is a revenue benefit to the county. Down the road, we will need this money," Porter said.
The other topic discussed by commissioners was the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a massive educational program that includes salary increases for teachers and more funding for early education.
The commissioners are concerned about its expense to the county.
While dramatically boosting state funding for public education over a decade, the Blueprint also asks local school districts — and taxpayers — to do their part.
In a letter to Gov. Wes Moore, the Maryland Association of Counties last November listed a litany of concerns. They said the Blueprint's cost estimates don't take into account the bottom-line local impact of several major spending items, including construction costs for additional classrooms needed under the plan's expansion of pre-K and the new minimum $60,000 teacher salary starting in 2026.
"It is a bad program and we have to figure out a way to pay for this," Porter said.
Education-related expenses made up the top expenditure for Caroline County in FY 2025. The Board of Education will receive about $17.1 million if the proposed budget is approved, about $2.3 million more than last year.
Rounding out the top four expenditures are the sheriff ($5,534,994), corrections ($5,889,769) and emergency medical services ($5,563,069).
The top three revenue generators for fiscal year 2025 are property taxes ($28,704,000), income taxes ($20,200,000) and a disparity grant from the state ($4,686,791).
Though commissioners voted to maintain the same tax rates as last year, the county will bring in more revenue from property taxes in FY 2025 due to an increase in the assessed value of properties in Caroline County.
Because of this increase, the state will provide less funding to the county in its annual disparity grant.
According to the Maryland Department of Legislative Services, the disparity grant is "where the local income tax is below 75% of the statewide average. Under the program each eligible jurisdiction receives a grant that enables the per capita local income tax revenues to reach 75% of the statewide average."
Deputy Administrator Dan Fox said that our state disparity grant is being funded at $615,525 less than last year.
"That is a state-driven formula that is based off of wealth. We changed in percentage there, which means we receive less money this year," Fox said.
The tax differential rate was discussed for various municipalities.
Porter described the tax differential as "revenue that the county does not collect. It is not money being taken from the towns or given to the towns. It does not affect town budgets in any way. It is money that the town does not collect."
Fox said, "The county is looking to maintain the property tax rate at 98 cents per 100 of all unincorporated areas as well as the towns that do not receive a differential," he said.
"This year we are looking provide Denton with the same tax rate as the prior year with 92 cents- a six cents differential to get you to 92 cent county tax rate. Federalsburg will have a county tax rate of 90 cents. Greensboro will remain at 92 cents. Preston would receive and remain at 97 cents and Ridgely would be at 93 cents," said Fox.
Commissioner Frank Bartz said they go through the budget line by line. And although there were some conversations, by and large they agreed on each item.
Two people Sue Simmons, interim director of Caroline County Arts Council and Dr. Cliff Coppersmith, President of Chesapeake College, both came up and stated how grateful they were for the county's support.
They had scheduled an hour and a half for this meeting, but it only took around 45 minutes. One commissioner, Travis Breeding, was "under the weather" and did not attend live.
The FY 2025 budget is scheduled for potential adoption during the Commissioners of Caroline County meeting on May 28. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Caroline County commissioners discussing the FY 2025 budget, tax rates, and local revenue sources, which are core functions of local government.

title: Ribbon cut for St. Michaels Community Center renovation
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Ribbon cut for St. Michaels Community Center renovation

 May 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 464
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — On Monday morning, many community members gathered for the ribbon cutting ceremony for an approximately $4.5 million renovation project to help serve the community of St. Michaels.The St. Michaels Community Center has been operating for over 30 years and has provided various supports through community pantries, events, senior and adult programs, youth programs and community gardens.
Lori Morris, the center's board chair, said she is excited to continue serving the community 2,500 meals a week and distributing groceries to neighbors in need.
"The outstanding center staff, both past and current, many of whom are here, not only provided ongoing input to the design and construction process but kept as many of our programs running as possible while we were out of the building," Morris said.
The approximately 5,700-square-foot building now houses a modern commercial kitchen, two classrooms, a technology center, a gallery and upstairs offices for staff. The main level of the building will serve multiple uses, including cafe seating, a space for speakers or performances and a place where people can pick up items from the center's community pantry.
The 800-square-foot commercial kitchen will serve the new Culinary Arts & Hospitality Workforce Development Program and the center's Community Cafe, which serves chef-made meals free of charge to anyone experiencing food insecurity.
The two classrooms on the other side of the gallery will be used primarily for children's programming but also for adult programs.
A technology center will have desks and computers for different organizations and nonprofits.
During the ribbon cutting ceremony, Morris praised her predecessor Langley Shook, former chair of the board of directors.
Morris said that Shook's leadership was the foundation of the project. The renovation was his vision, and he and his wife, Karen Shook, threw themselves into the fundraising, representing the committee before the town commissioners and the Historic District Committee.
Shook spoke about the work that many put into the project and thanked everyone involved in making the community center what it is today.
"The programs have been expanded, the staff has been strengthened," Shook said. "Our fundraising has made this platform possible and successful, and I think our greatest days are yet to come."
One of the speakers, State Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), requested that all people who had attended St. Michaels Middle or High School come to stand with him as he presented the St. Michaels Community Center board of directors a citation in recognition for the work that was put into the community project.
"Because we do citations and we do projects, and it's part of the government doing something, but this is the will of the people," Mautz said. "This is what the town needed. This is what the town wanted, and by golly, this is what the town was going to get. So it's a great day for everybody." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community center renovation funded and supported by local officials, mentions town commissioners and a state senator, and highlights community services, making Local Government the most fitting category.

title: Community Development Block Grant projects celebrated
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Community Development Block Grant projects celebrated

 May 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 573
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Friday morning, community members and partners gathered to celebrate two Community Development Block Grant recipients: Family Support Center and Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center's Community and Commercial Kitchen Space.The Community Development Block Grant Program assists in strengthening Maryland's communities by funding projects generally falling into three types: housing, public facilities and economic development projects.
Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development Assistant Secretary Carol Gilbert was also present for the tour.
Family Support Center, a recipient of the grant, held an open house for its Early Head Start center. This center offers year-round comprehensive early care, education and family support to children from birth to 3 years of age, as well as their families.
Mary Kay Verdery, grants administrator for Talbot County, gave opening remarks outside of the center.
Verdery told community members the renovated space, including classrooms for up to 65 infants and toddlers, office space, kitchen and laundry facilities for the program, was possible due to the grant the center received.
Maria Maguire, health officer for the Talbot County Health Department, gave a speech noting the significance of Head Start programs for the community, including research showing that children enrolled in Early Head Start programs have better social-emotional language and cognitive development.
"All babies and toddlers need positive early learning experiences to foster their intellectual, social and emotional development and to lay the foundation for later school success," Maguire said. "Talbot County Health Department's Early Head Start program offers daily, year-round services to families and young children in Talbot County. It provides a comprehensive array of services, including mental health, education, housing, referrals and linkages to health services."
Community partners and members were given a tour of the center, where they were greeted by staff and children enjoying the care and benefits of the program.
Afterward, people enjoyed refreshments and baked goods before heading to the next stop on the grant project tour, the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center Kitchen and Community Space.
This full restoration of a brick warehouse provides the resource center with a much-needed space for small groups, class opportunities and community gatherings.
Adding a full commercial kitchen will allow small food businesses to expand their economic impact on the community and provide an appropriate space to create meals and food options for the community.
Talbot County Councilmember Pete Lesher, vice president of the council, shared the council's enthusiasm and gratitude for the community space and renovations made by the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center.
"This is an organization that has an important mission to a growing part of our population in this community," Lesher said. "Thanks to all of you who are already doing that. Thanks to the rest of you who have helped to make this project possible."
Attendees were welcomed to a feast of Pakistani food created by Veronica Guevara, who used the kitchen to help launch her catering business. People enjoyed a delicious array of lentils, fresh strawberry salad, seasoned chicken and fluffy naan. Guevara explained each dish and showed the best way for attendees to eat it.
Matthew Peters, director of Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, described this project as a "labor of love."
"So we've got that whole new growth take, and all really thanks to having a little bit more space to breathe and to get people together like this provided to the community," Peters said. "And hopefully, we keep finding more and more of our clients that are those secret gems so that I can create an amazing mission to share. So thank you all." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
