title: Local agencies need money from ENOUGH Act now
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
Local agencies need money from ENOUGH Act now

 July 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 607
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Governor's Office on Children recently released information about the ENOUGH Act that was passed in this most recent legislative session. The goals of this legislation are right in line with what communities need eventually to address child poverty and program needs in significant ways but place the achievement of those goals a long way off for many jurisdictions and in particular the jurisdictions that are in the greatest need.The implementation plans for communities and nonprofit organizations expect that there are organizations in our communities that have strong leadership, possibly an executive director, an engaged board of directors, strong community support with volunteers and funding. There is an expectation that they are ready to take on a new initiative even while they are stretched to support their existing programs and goals.
As I have been on the grants committee for the Mid Shore Community Foundation and on the board of another foundation that gives out over $250,000 a year to programs supporting women and children, I understand that there are some programs that are not funded for a variety of reasons or receive minimal support. We need to find a way to support these start up organizations now rather than have them wait, possibly for years, if ever, before they can make the grade to be funded by the ENOUGH Act.
What the ENOUGH Act expects is that the money will go to those nonprofits that have their act together and meet all of the requirements that the Office on Children places on them. They are willing to help them develop and grow that capacity, but many of the groups doing great work in a community are small, understaffed and underfunded. As a result, they will take years, if ever, to become organized to be able to begin making a larger difference in their community for children and families.
I have encouraged a different manner of funding programs for children and families that would bring a funding stream of smaller amounts to communities that have high poverty rates and need programs for summer and after school or reading for children to help communities right now with the significant needs that exist, especially in rural areas.
The funding would come directly to a city, town, or county based on existing data about the needs in that community. The local town or county council or Local Management Board would identify good programs that are underfunded but making a difference in their community and, with the help of the Governor's Office on Children, collect data that will show what the outcomes are from the money that is being spent.
The city, town or county or a Local Management Board could be the data collector for reporting purposes to the Governor's Office. Providing the funding, which would not have to be that much, could help to help the community identify and build the kind of nonprofit infrastructure that would be able to apply for and be funded as the larger and better funded programs will be supported by the ENOUGH Act.
Without funding to jump start communities that do not now have the resources to successfully apply for ENOUGH Act funding or can apply for funds to develop a collaboration, some communities that desperately need this help will never receive it, and we will see even more children continue down a path that will limit their ability to achieve in school and have successful lives.
Sending the funding to the city, town or county or the LMB based on need and existing data will help now not years in the future, and now is when it is needed.
Stephen Rideout is mayor of Cambridge. Reach him at swrideout@aol.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state‑level act (ENOUGH Act) and proposes funding mechanisms that involve city, town, or county councils and local management boards, focusing on how local governments can allocate resources to address child poverty and community programs.

title: Books to be moved, stored during St. Michaels library renovation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Books to be moved, stored during St. Michaels library renovation

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 246
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST MICHAELS — The St. Michaels Branch of the Talbot County Free Library is preparing for a temporary move later this fall as it undergoes renovations. A request from the county's public works department to award funds for that temporary relocation was made to Talbot County Council on Tuesday.The request was to award Bates Moving and Storage Company the moving and storage contract for just over $100,000. Council members voted unanimously in favor of the request.
"Bates has a lot of experience with moving library collections. They've done a number of libraries on the Eastern Shore as well as media centers," Dana Newman, director of Talbot County Free Library, said. "And they have a special way of packing up library materials so that it's kept in order, and that it's stored in conditions that are okay for storing books over a long period of time."
Newman said the collections will be moved to a temporary location in St. Michaels as renovations are completed. "It does sound like a lot of funds needed for this, but it is a specialized process, if you can imagine trying to keep about 20,000-plus library materials in strict duodecimal order," Newman told the council.
The storage will last for around 15 months, during which they will not be available to be checked out. The move will begin around late October. Council members expressed support for the request.
"I'm excited that you're getting to the point that you're moving everything," Council Member Keasha Haythe said.

title: MACo and Talbot County Council discuss fiscal pressures facing state
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
MACo and Talbot County Council discuss fiscal pressures facing state

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 490
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When entering last year's General Assembly, the fiscal situation Maryland faced needed serious attention. In some ways, that fiscal pressure has increased since.Michael Sanderson, the executive director of the Maryland Association of Counties, briefed the Talbot County Council on those financial troubles and more during a special meeting Tuesday.
He told council members a budget shortfall of potentially $600 to $800 million could be facing lawmakers in Annapolis. Fixing that is "not easy, but not impossible," he said.
"There are a couple of years of that in our forecast, and then it gets really serious," Sanderson said.
When fiscal year 2028 arrives, Sanderson warned that the state will run out of money in its trust fund that's been used for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's expansive and optimistic education initiative.
Many counties have been under significant financial pressure due to state requirements stemming from Blueprint. Sanderson says the state will be feeling that level of pressure soon.
"The counties are feeling it now," he said. "The state doesn't really feel it for a couple years down the road, and that has been a meaningful disconnect."
Without significant timeline adjustments for Blueprint from the state, MACo feels there will continue to be that disconnect between the fiscal situation of the state versus the situation counties are facing. State funding for transportation, though, is already causing serious impacts, Sanderson said.
"The canary in the coal mine that's already chirping is in transportation," he told the council members. " … The conversation in the summer time is sometimes ambiguous and hazy and that sort of thing. But this year, not so much. They were just saying, 'If there aren't already shovels in the ground, we can't afford the next thing.'"
The Maryland Department of Transportation has been forced to delay many statewide projects amid a significant budget deficit. Earlier this month, the department released a draft plan that showed $1.3 billion in cuts from the state's six-year transportation plan.
Sanderson noted the "state's transportation challenge is not a function of the Key Bridge" rebuild, which is set to begin next year.
At the county level, council Vice President Pete Lesher said Talbot County is "finding itself in a slightly different place" than others.
"We are going through a number of capital construction projects, our health department, our sheriff's office, our 911 center," Lesher said, emphasizing some of those projects are receiving "pandemic-era related funds" from the federal government.
"The pinch that a lot of counties are feeling right now, the income tax, is not yet being felt in Talbot County," Lesher said. "We can look around at our neighbors and see what is coming, even though we are not yet in that position now."
Lesher thanked Sanderson and MACo President Johnny Olszewski Jr. for their work to represent the counties at the state level year-round.
"We know that we are stronger together in Annapolis," Lesher said. "And we see every year what a powerful voice MACo is for all of us jointly." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a county council meeting discussing state fiscal pressures, budget shortfalls, and impacts on local services, which aligns most closely with the Local Government topic.

title: Cambridge candidates talk local issues at candidate forum
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge candidates talk local issues at candidate forum

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 936
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge City Council candidates and the city's residents flowed in and out of the Chesapeake Grove Intergenerational Center Saturday afternoon for a nearly five-hour candidate forum conducted by the League of Women Voters.Ten of the 14 commissioner and mayoral candidates running in the Oct. 19 election were at the forum.
The forum was split into three sessions for the different races. Ryan Anthony of the Cambridge Spy, Sharon Smith of the Cambridge Association of Neighborhoods, Jim Johnson of the Dorchester Star and Jim Brady of WHCP moderated the forum.
Ward 2 candidate Jenna LeCompte, Ward 4 candidate Dave Cannon, Ward 3 candidate Frank Stout and Ward 5 candidate Brian Roche — who is running uncontested — were not at the event.
In an email to WHCP on Friday, LeCompte said she is "taking a step back" from her campaign and would not be at the event. She did not respond to requests for clarification from the Star Democrat on what that means.
MAYORAL FORUM
Sandwiched between two commissioner candidate sessions, the mayoral forum gave candidates Lajan Cephas, Andrew Bradshaw and La-Shon Banks-Foster the opportunity to share their perspectives on an array of Cambridge issues, from the waterfront, to revitalizing the city's downtown, to race relations.
During the session, candidates were asked whether the city should get more involved in Dorchester County Public Schools, which is one of Maryland's lowest ranked school systems.
Bradshaw said he would like to implement a mentorship program, which would reach across racial and socioeconomic lines, and encourage the Board of Education to implement a charter school program. He said charter schools across the state tend to perform at the state average, which is "significantly better" than Dorchester schools.
"And they are only located in counties and jurisdictions with poor performance," he said, "so there's corollaries where they can succeed in places like Cambridge."
Foster, who attended the forum virtually, said every graduate from Dorchester County high schools is a county resident and could be a Cambridge resident.
"We cannot ignore the fact that whoever graduates from either of the schools that I mentioned can and will impact the City of Cambridge, and we must have an active role," she said.
Cephas said it is important for the city to be "extremely supportive" of the county, but there is no need to "reinvent the wheel." She said there are nonprofits already in place to address education concerns.
"So it's extremely important that we understand what's already in place, support those nonprofits that are already in place, and each of us just pick up a book and read to someone," she said.
COMMISSIONER FORUMS
The seven commissioner candidates at the forum were split into two groups. All commissioner candidates were asked the same questions from the moderators.
Kicking off the event were Ward 1 candidates Brett Summers and Laurel Atkiss, as well as Ward 3 candidate Gary Gordy. Ward 2 candidates Jermaine Anderson, Shay Lewis-Sisco and Nancy Jackson, as well as Ward 4 candidate Sputty Cephas, closed out the event.
When asked about code enforcement and overall housing quality in the city, Summers said hiring tenant advocates to promote a tenants bill of rights would be beneficial.
"Because if the tenants feel like they can contact the city inspector and have them come out without fear of getting evicted or some other kind of retribution, then the tenants are empowered to improve our housing stock," he said.
Atkiss said the city has implemented a software system to make it easier to enforce things like building code violations. She said Cambridge is doing city-wide building inspections and recently hired a new code enforcement officer.
"We've invested money, we've invested time," she said, "and now we're going to invest the manpower, and we're going to start to see some results that I hope everybody's going to be really happy with."
Lewis-Sisco said code enforcement should strategically target houses where renters are living in deplorable conditions. She said community engagement should also be a focus.
"So that when code enforcement officers go out to a homeowner or a property, they are able to offer those additional supports or let them know what additional resources exist," she said.
The issue of addressing crime in Cambridge was also brought up during the forum.
Gordy said improved lighting, more cameras and more monitoring of those cameras are needed in the city's "hot spots" in order to lower crime rates. When talking about monitoring cameras, he brought up a shooting that occurred over the weekend.
"Because last night police got there so fast, but they couldn't see who it was," he said about the need for 24-hour camera monitoring.
Jackson said addressing the issue of crime in Cambridge might start with more than detaining people. She said she would work to help resolve those problems if elected.
"There is something deep where this person is committing these acts," she said. "It could be the home life or it could be the environment."
Cephas said strengthening the police department's community policing division is important. He talked about programming for youth to attract "local and diverse talent" as another solution.
"Let's do a cadet program to get some of these young people before they get out into the community and do wrong things or bad things," he said.
Anderson said these problems have existed for a long time and won't be a quick fix. He stressed the importance of being proactive and communicating.
When asked about the greatest threat to the city, both Atkiss and Anderson talked about the city standing in it's own way.
"But the biggest opportunity is imagine if we get out of our own way," Anderson said. "Think about the opportunity that would pose for this city ... how much of a difference that would make." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a city council and mayoral candidate forum, focusing on local policy issues, making Local Government the most fitting category.

title: Caroline Commissioners hear from county workers, discuss school budget
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Commissioners hear from county workers, discuss school budget

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners convened on Tuesday and several topics were discussed, including the Employee Advisory Board's desire to attract and retain workers, approving changes to the fiscal year 2024 Caroline Board of Education budget and a restructuring of the Department of Public Works.BOARD OF EDUCATION BUDGETDerek Simmons, superintendent of Caroline County Public Schools, and Jill Hignutt, CFO of The Caroline Board of Education, requested amendments to the Board of Education's 2024 budget.
"We are here to share where the budget adjustments needed to take place in the operating budget and align those with the actuals at the end of the fiscal year," Simmons said.
Hignett gave the commissioners a copy of her short presentation, then began detailing the request.
"Starting with prescriptive revenues, there is a change of $6,389,071 related to our grant funding. Many of our grants cross fiscal years, so we must adjust the revenues to match the expenditures that were actually seen at year end," Hignutt said.
Then she shifted the attention to expenditures like driver salaries for transportation. Between fuel costs and bus driver salaries, the school system overspent about $39,000. She also mentioned parking lot repavement projects and classroom renovations.
There was a $5,782,498 surplus noted in the total budgeted revenues. According to Daniel Fox, deputy county administrator, the excess of revenue over expenditures is retained by the Board of Education to go to its fund balance.
The commissioners approved the amended budget.
EMPLOYEE ADVISORY BOARDNext up was the Employee Advisory Board, an authority that overlooks the corrections, emergency services, planning and codes, public works, recreation and parks, and administration departments. There is also a non-voting member department, the Department of Human Resources.
Todd Lord, chairman of the Advisory Board for Caroline County, thanked the commissioners for improving pensions for retirees and achieving competitive pay increases to help with recruitment and retention.
The board also wants cost of living adjustments due to the inflation following the pandemic.
Lord proposed an initiative to go forward as he hears from staff about pay and salaries.
"We recommend merit pay increases annually for step based off of employee evaluations. We want to get away from the bunching of salaries. Health care plans for retirees, that is another one of our initiatives being discussed heavily in departments," Lord said.
He said the goal was to increase retention and have attraction for the employees under the board's care.
"Right now we want to provide a health care plan that employees can take into retirement," Lord said. "Having their pension in retirement would be a huge benefit in retention for our staff."
Commissioner Frank Bartz responded, "Health care for retirees, that is a hard undertaking for the county."
Another commissioner said the same.
Porter said, "I don't foresee that we are going to be able to do health care benefits for people who are retiring at 55. The same inflation figures that you are using, we are facing as well."
President Travis Breeding said, "We have to find that balance — taking care of our employees and taking care of our tax payers and the constituents of the county."
PUBLIC WORKS REORGANIZATIONRobin Eaton, director of the Department of Public Works, asked the commissioners for the authority to reorganize the department to create a project manager position. He spoke of maintaining the 80 miles of dirt roads in the county.
"Our original structure had three crew leaders, so doing away with one of those crew leader positions and creating a project inspector slash utility locator," Eaton said.
"It is actually three crews. Two under crew leaders and one dirt road crew with four employees under the road superintendent," Kathleen Freeman, county administrator, said.
The commissioners approved the reorganization. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a county commissioners meeting covering budget approvals, employee advisory board issues, and public works reorganization, all core functions of local government, making it the best match despite the education budget component.

title: Legislators talk state budget before heading back to Annapolis in January
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Legislators talk state budget before heading back to Annapolis in January

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The state of the state's budget took up a large part of the conversation at a Dorchester Chamber of Commerce luncheon with state legislators on Dec. 4.The Lower Shore delegation answered questions from chamber members regarding concerns about Maryland's fiscal health, with a looming $2.7 billion state budget deficit predicted in fiscal year 2026.
"The reality is that if you continue to do the things that have gotten us into this deficit, it's only going to take us back there again," Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "There needs to be a structural, fundamental change."
Mautz and Dels. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico), Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) all spoke at the chamber lunch. They, along with the rest of the state's legislators, will head back to Annapolis in January for the 447th session of the Maryland General Assembly.
In talking about the state's budget, Mautz also said there should be incentives in place to try to drive state agencies to save money.
Sample-Hughes said the state should do its fiscal homework and find out what it "really (has) to work with."
"But I do believe that we can still address and attack some of these goals that we have, whether it's education, whether it's climate, whether it's criminal justice," she said. "We can do it in a pragmatic way."
Adams said to solve the budget problem, the state has to leverage and grow its private sector.
"You do not do what we've done for the past two years," he said. He said the state and its leadership need to stop spending so much, own up to the problem and stop blaming it on COVID-19.
Hutchinson expressed his concerns with the transportation budget and the lack of funding for many infrastructure projects across the state.
"We've got to pay attention to our transportation budget," he said.
BLUEPRINTThe legislators also talked about the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state through increasing education funding by $3.8 billion over a 10-year period.
Sample-Hughes said although Blueprint's goals are important, the General Assembly's decision to pass the plan has contributed to the state's budget deficit. She later advocated for giving more resources to the nonprofits that already serve 3 and 4 year olds, rather than putting money toward expanding early childhood education in the state's public school systems.
Mautz said he thinks the project needs to be paused so that the plan's strengths and weaknesses can be better evaluated.
JUVENILE CRIMEThe legislators also talked about the state of juvenile crime in Maryland, with Sample-Hughes calling for the removal of Department of Juvenile Services Secretary Vincent Schiraldi.
Hutchinson said that with recent juvenile justice reforms going into effect Nov. 1, he doesn't think a lot of legislators are going to want to discuss juvenile crime this upcoming session.
"Because they'll say, 'We just put that in place. We haven't even been able to see the results,'" he said.
Adams said law enforcement is needed now more than ever and officers need to be able to do their jobs.
"If you want a society, if you want a City of Cambridge, if you want an Eastern Shore (or) State of Maryland, if you want a United States that is civil, there have to be consequences," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on state legislators discussing the Maryland budget, fiscal deficit, and upcoming legislative session, which are core topics of local (state) government news. Economic implications are prominent, but the primary focus is governmental budgeting and policy.

title: County Council introduces bills to improve auditorium lights, athletic fields
author: Konner Metz
content:
County Council introduces bills to improve auditorium lights, athletic fields

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council introduced three pieces of capital-enabling legislation during Tuesday's meeting that would dedicate funds for school improvements.Bills 1580, 1581 and 1582 were introduced by all five council members. If passed at a future meeting, they will approve a combined $1.5 million in funding for three projects: new auditorium lights at Easton High School ($817,321), light replacements at St. Michaels Middle High School ($556,000) and athletic field improvements across the district ($116,679).
The fiscal year 2025 budget already accounted for the capital costs, County Manager Clay Stamp noted. The three bills would simply authorize the usage of funds for those three projects, respectively.
Talbot County Public Schools Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said Easton High's auditorium lights date back to the school's renovation in 1997.
Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher said he's noticed "how desperately needed this lighting system is."
"In order to put on some of the really quality student productions that we've seen at Easton High School, I believe that some of the lighting directors have been bringing equipment in from … the University of Maryland, Baltimore County and other places to supplement the antiquated equipment that the auditorium itself has," Lesher said.
"We've moved into an era of LED lighting, which didn't exist back in 1997," Lesher added. "This is going to be a huge leap forward."
Shafer said the light replacements and improvements at St. Michaels Middle High School will complete the ongoing LED conversion product across the entire St. Michaels campus. Grant funding allowed for new side lights at St. Michaels Elementary, Shafer said.
The $117,000 for athletic field improvements will help the district move forward with its grass field upgrades.
"Generally speaking, the athletic field improvements are going to be surrounding the current fields that we have, grass fields," Shafer said. "(We are) doing some longstanding improvements related to some issues or concerns that came up."
A public hearing on the three bills will be held during Talbot County Council's Feb. 11 meeting at 5:30 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on County Council legislation allocating funds for school facility upgrades, focusing on the actions of a local governing body.

title: Caroline County commissioners offer legislative session updates
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub
content:
Caroline County commissioners offer legislative session updates

 January 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub | Section: News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At the Caroline County Commissioners meeting Tuesday, officials discussed bills working their way through the General Assembly.Commission Vice President Larry Porter led the discussion about the legislative session. He highlighted two proposed bills that the county commissioners are concerned about.
Senate Bill 0189 prohibits counties and the state from taking preserved farm or conservation land via eminent domain and Senate Bill 0724 would mandate seatbelts on all school buses.
SCHOOL BUS SEATBELTSThis isn't the first time seatbelt requirements on school busses has been proposed in the General Assembly. Similar bills have been filed for many years and have not passed, with counties largely complaining about the cost of implementation.
This year's bill would mandate that every school bus made, brought or built after 2027 must have a seatbelt installed on every seat.
The county commissioners said they would have a conversation with Caroline County Public Schools about the bill, but they expressed concerns about the potential cost of enacting it.
"I don't think I'm interested in testifying," Larry Porter said about a request he received to oppose the legislation. "But I think we could probably reach out to the superintendent because there were some concerns from their transportation department about it."
The concerns for the County Commissioners have been the same every time this measure has been proposed — the cost of installing seat belts on every school bus, who is liable if the kids don't put seatbelts on and how the school bus drivers will enforce seatbelt wearing.
"We have the same concerns that we had before," Porter said at the Tuesday meeting.
In an interview, Commission President Travis Breeding mentioned but he believes the design of the seats on the bus helps keep students safe without seatbelts.
EMINENT DOMAINThe county is more receptive to eminent domain bill, but they want to see some revisions before it's passed.
"The eminent domain bill was prohibiting the state or county from taking land by eminent domain in areas that were preservation areas," Porter said. "In the beginning, that sounds like that's something we would absolutely support."
The county recently had a situation at Long Swamp Bridge that made the commissioners feel revisions needed to be made to the measure. The county needed more space for the construction of a new bridge at the site, and it brought some preserved land from a owner to make more space.
If the eminent domain bill was enacted it would have been way more trouble for the county to go through that process of buying the land, Breeding said. It could have caused a lane closure.
"We didn't use eminent domain, but because (of) the landowner. It was in preservation land, and he negotiated," Breeding said.
They commissioners suggest maybe revising the bill to make it easier to work out future land preservation problems. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on actions and concerns of county commissioners, a local government body, regarding legislation affecting land use and school bus safety.

title: Caroline Cares connects community with services at Resource Day
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Cares connects community with services at Resource Day

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Multiple vendors at Caroline Cares Community Resource Day Wednesday were reminded how amazing it is to do community work and help others.His Hope Ministries Youth Director Desiree Jefferson distributed winter clothes at the event. She was one of many vendors who had previously attended the event not to distribute resources, but to receive them.
"It's really refreshing to be able to give back," Jefferson said. "Just a couple years ago, I was somebody that was coming through the doors and receiving services myself, so it's good to see that we can help families in need."
The Caroline Cares Community Resource Day featured around 40 vendors providing information, help and food to the community.
"This is what it's all about," said Stephanie Johnson, His Hope Ministries' executive director and board member for Resources Day. "Just getting all the resources in one building so that it can be kind of an easily accessible for those who need them the most. Being able to bring those providers under one roof, on a specific day, to get those services out to everybody who needs them is huge."
One of the main focuses for Resource Day is providing many different types of help for many different people.
Some attendees face expenses they can't afford or are just in a bad financial situation, and some people are homeless. Resources Day helped with a variety of situations.
Directors expect 100 to 150 county residents experiencing homelessness to attend Resources Day every year, and they have a plan to make sure homeless residents can find shelter.
"With this particular event, they have access to walk around, talk to the vendors and see what exactly what their services are that they provide," Johnson said. "However, like when it comes to those who are actually experiencing homelessness, we have a separate room set aside for them to really dig into what their needs are and see how we can connect them with services."
Caroline County Public Schools officials attended, providing information for children on enrollment in school and many different resources for mental and physical health. United4Caroline provided free diapers for families with infants.
Chesapeake College's nursing program provided free blood pressure checks for all people in attendance. Nursing students gained experience and enjoyed serving the community.
"Oh, I love this, and I'm actually from Denton myself, so to give back to the community is amazing," Katie Reuwer, an assistant professor at Chesapeake College, said. "It's a great experience for the students to really learn about community service and helping others. I've already had some really good feedback from the students about how much they enjoy it."
Staff from Studio 107 Hair Salon in Kent Island and Edwards All Star Barbershop in Denton enjoyed providing free haircuts and styles at Resource Day, something both shops provide every year.
"There's no better feeling," Lisa Milligan, owner of Studio 107, said. "You're helping people that are maybe down on their luck or they're just getting out of jail or they're just going for jobs. It's every aspect, older people that can't afford to get their hair cut especially in this economy. So it's great to give back." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a community resource day organized by local agencies and nonprofits, featuring services like school enrollment info, health checks, and assistance for homeless residents, which aligns most closely with local government/community services.

title: Sen. Van Hollen talks federal grants pause with Eastern Shore legislators
author: Konner Metz
content:
Sen. Van Hollen talks federal grants pause with Eastern Shore legislators

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 758
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While speaking with Eastern Shore legislators Friday morning, Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) said a short-lived pause of federal funding earlier this week had impacts on local organizations such as fire stations and law enforcement agencies.Monday, President Donald Trump's budget office issued a memorandum ordering a pause on federal grants and loans. A U.S. district judge temporarily blocked the pause Tuesday before the White House rescinded the memo the following day.
"Because of the public outcry, they did pull back on this overall freeze," Van Hollen said. "But there's still a whole lot of uncertainty and confusion. So if you are hearing from folks on the Eastern Shore that are recipients of federal programs that are being disrupted, please let us know."
At the weekly Eastern Shore Delegation meeting, Del. Steven Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) asked Van Hollen to elaborate on his perspective of what happened.
Van Hollen said the memo from the Office of Management and Budget brought forth confusion for government agencies. The senator heard from thousands that were impacted, he said in an email newsletter.
"It was very broadly worded and very ambiguous," Van Hollen said. "Federal agencies interpreted this based on what it said. Essentially, they did freeze a lot of ongoing payments to organizations that do important community work."
Arentz said some of the spending that was paused could be viewed as "questionable" in the first place.
"I think that's the point that was being made about that," Arentz said. "I keep getting questions on it, because it does look like when you portray it in one way, it looks bad, but in the other way, you look at some spending that people would have questions on. And I think that's part of the explanation I try to give."
"The way the memo was worded and the reason it was retracted was because it was so broad that it appeared to impact everybody," Van Hollen responded.
Sen. Angela Alsobrooks (D-Md.) also attended Friday's Eastern Shore Delegation meeting. She explained to state senators and delegates her line of thinking when voting to confirm recent political appointees, emphasizing that she is prepared to vote on "qualified" candidates across party lines.
"My primary interest and sole interest, really, is making sure that I protect the interests of Maryland," Alsobrooks said.
SUPERINTENDENTSEastern Shore superintendents gathered at the meeting Friday to provide legislative requests and recommendations.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons, president of the Eastern Shore of Maryland Educational Consortium superintendents' group, framed Friday's discussion around The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education funding initiative.
It comes as Gov. Wes Moore (D) and the state legislature attempt to balance a $3 billion state deficit, in part by making cuts to education funding.
Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson explained the importance for districts to attract a diverse and qualified teacher workforce. However, state requirements, such as teacher salary minimums, sometimes bring about challenges.
"It is not good for a district, especially like mine, since we don't have the funding that other districts have," Thompson said.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools Superintendent Patty Saelens said the Eastern Shore superintendents don't support Moore's proposed funding cuts to teacher collaborative time (out-of-classroom time to grade and plan) and community school initiatives.
"Our number one priority right now that we just can't support is literal cuts to our budget, specifically as it relates to the collaborative time and the community schools," Saelens said. "Those are two major things that will negatively impact our overall state support."
EDUCATIONRepresentatives from colleges and universities attended Friday's meeting, including Chesapeake College President Clifford Coppersmith and Washington College President Mike Sosulski.
Sosulski provided an update on Washington College's Innovation Plant Project, which is a project the institution is collaborating with Chesapeake College on.
"In the year-and-a-half of its development, it's already garnered $3 million in public and private funding to support it," Sosulski said.
Sosulski added that he hopes the Maryland Sellinger Grant Program, which provides independent colleges and universities with state funding, isn't slashed.
"I can't tell you how important Sellinger has been to making a Washington College education affordable and accessible to all Maryland residents," he said. "It is really, and quite literally, the difference for many, many of our students and their ability to achieve the kind of education that we can provide."
Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico) asked about whether universities are considering raising tuition due to potential state funding cuts.
"We fully understand the need for the governor to cut the budget," said University of Maryland Eastern Shore President Heidi Anderson. "We will not be looking at increasing tuition for our students, and we will abide by that." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a meeting of local legislators discussing the federal grant pause and its impact on local agencies, budget decisions, and community services, which aligns most closely with the Local Government topic.

title: From crushes to banning cell phones — Maryland lawmakers propose new legislation covering range of issues
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
From crushes to banning cell phones — Maryland lawmakers propose new legislation covering range of issues

 February 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland state senators and delegates have introduced a variety of bills in the 2024 legislative session, addressing issues ranging from state symbols and education mandates to law enforcement policy and budget concerns.State Symbols and Utility RegulationsState Sen. Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) has introduced Senate Bill 562, which would designate the original Maryland Orange Crush as the state cocktail. The bill is co-sponsored by Sens. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester).
Hershey also sponsored Senate Bill 561, which, along with House Bill 227 sponsored by Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), would allow electric cooperatives to use unclaimed funds only to assist cooperative members or donate to nonprofit organizations, rather than treating them as abandoned property.
Additionally, Hershey introduced Senate Bill 355, seeking to delay the implementation of the Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program by two years.
Energy and Education LegislationDel. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) is behind two bills on solar energy regulation: House Bill 739 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 478) and House Bill 742. One bill would prohibit the use of eminent domain for solar siting, while the other would return control over solar development to county governments.
Ghrist also introduced House Bill 736, which seeks to remove the mandate requiring local school systems to offer pre-kindergarten for three-year-olds. Another provision in the bill would increase state funding to help Kent County construct a new middle school.
On law enforcement, Ghrist is supporting a bill — potentially House Bill 122 — that would require the removal of unfounded complaints from police personnel files.
Nursing, Historic Preservation, and Cemetery ProtectionsDel. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) has proposed House Bill 602 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 407), directing the State Board of Nursing to negotiate reciprocity agreements with neighboring states for advanced practice nursing licensure. Another measure, House Bill 616 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 421), would extend the statute of limitations for crimes related to cemetery destruction and prohibit damaging cemetery landscaping. The bill is co-sponsored by Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-Dorchester, Wicomico).
Hutchinson is also behind House Bill 760, which would establish a local appeals process for Maryland Historic Trust decisions.
Budget Deficit Shifts to CountiesGov. Wes Moore's proposed budget shifts some of the state's structural deficit onto county governments. Ghrist criticized the move, stating that counties did not contribute to the deficit but are now being forced to compensate for state overspending.
"For my district, $720,000 will be shifted to Caroline County on top of an additional $1.8 million more that the county will have to add to education under Kirwan mandates," Ghrist stated. He cited similar financial burdens for other Eastern Shore counties, including Cecil, Kent, and Queen Anne's.
"This will stifle economic growth because people will be sending more of their hard-earned money to the government rather than spending it in their local economies," Ghrist added.
Law Enforcement and Traffic StopsA controversial proposal, Senate Bill 292, has drawn strong opposition from law enforcement officials, including Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker. The bill would reclassify certain primary traffic offenses as secondary offenses, preventing law enforcement from stopping drivers solely for those violations.
"These minor traffic violations could actually lead to catching suspects that have committed serious felonies, recovering firearms, and stopping drug-related crimes," Baker said. A hearing on the bill is scheduled before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
Other Bills of Local InterestHouse Bill 28, sponsored by Del. Josh Bouchat (R-Carroll, Frederick), proposes a constitutional amendment requiring all Maryland counties to adopt a charter government structure.
House Bill 278, also from Bouchat, would provide an income tax subtraction modification for enhanced agricultural management equipment to support sustainable farming practices.
House Bill 192, introduced by Del. Nino Mangione (R-Baltimore County), aims to curb student cell phone use in schools under the proposed "No Distracted Learning Act."
As these bills move through the legislature, local officials and residents will have the opportunity to voice their support or concerns during committee hearings and public forums. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details multiple bills introduced by state legislators affecting local governance, budgets, and county responsibilities, making local government the most fitting primary category.

title: Mid-Shore crews clean roads quickly after heavy snowfall
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore crews clean roads quickly after heavy snowfall

 February 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 427
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The National Weather Service recorded nine inches of snow in Easton on Wednesday, which was more than expected six to eight inches forecasted earlier this week.The weather service recorded 8.5 inches of snow in Denton and eight inches of snow in Cambridge.
As a result of heavy snow, conditions on roads throughout the Mid-Shore were expected to be bad. After having battled another large snowfall just a month prior, road crews and first responders were prepared.
Caroline, Talbot and Dorchester counties responded to the snow fast and were able to clear roads in a timely manner, allowing many government offices to open Wednesday.
"Our Public Works team was ready for the winter weather that hit Tuesday afternoon," Kathleen Freeman, Caroline County administrator, said. "Crews came in at 4 p.m., and with the rising temperatures, they quickly cleared the roads and made sure all county buildings were accessible."
"By 10 a.m. Wednesday, everything was set for a delayed start," she said. "I want to thank our road crews and all essential staff for their hard work in making this event go as smoothly as possible. Their quick response kept everything running with minimal disruption for our community."
Caroline County opened their offices at 10 a.m. Wednesday morning, as did Talbot County and the towns of Easton and Denton.
Talbot County could not be reached for comment, but the county decided to open up their offices at 10 a.m. Wednesday morning.
Dorchester County's offices were open during regular business hours Wednesday, though non-essential employees were given the option to work from home if they could, according to a Facebook post from the county government.
"We had a great night. Snow slacked up earlier than expected. It was great experience," Dorchester County Manager Jerry Jones said. "Folks stayed off the road. It was good Mother Nature is helping us. The window was bigger (than with the last snow) to get everything. Emergency responders were great as well."
Schools decided to keep campuses closed Wednesday because of the snowfall, but several districts had students attend class virtually.
Talbot County Public Schools conducted its first virtual learning day since 2020, and district officials were pleased with the results, according to TCPS Directer of Communications Debbie Gardner.
"The feedback from school principals has been positive," Gardner said Wednesday afternoon. "Student attendance has been better than we anticipated, and our teachers have done a fantastic job."
Dorchester County Public Schools conducted a virtual learning day as well, but could not be reached for comment.
Caroline County Public Schools did not have students attend class virtually, but the district plans to open on time Thursday. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on county road crews, public works teams, and government office operations responding to heavy snowfall, which aligns with Local Government. Secondary mentions of school closures and virtual learning introduce Education, while the mention of emergency responders touches on Public Safety.

title: Dorchester County and DCPS working to reduce FY26 budget deficits
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County and DCPS working to reduce FY26 budget deficits

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 573
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Manager Jerry Jones considers the fiscal year 2026 budget a moving target."There are a lot of things that are changing," he said about predicted state funding during a Dorchester County Council budget work session Thursday. "This is not a weekly thing, but almost a daily thing. ... We just don't know how this is going to unfold."
County staff has been going through the operating and capital budgets line by line to find efficiencies, Jones said.
"We are constantly working on solutions," he said. "We're finding those efficiencies. We have made substantial changes already."
During the work session, Jones detailed estimated revenue and expenditures for fiscal year 2026. According to Jones' presentation, preliminary projections for the budget show a deficit of $6.2 million, with $87.7 million in estimated revenue and $93.9 million in estimated expenditures.
Jones outlined a list of mandates from the state that contribute to the county's deficit. These include reductions in grant funding, losses from proposed property tax deductions, an increase in state education maintenance of effort costs and increased financial responsibilities for things like teacher retirement.
Both Jones and County Council members said the budget would look a lot different without these mandates. Jones said that without the mandates, the county would not be facing a deficit. He said he county would instead have had $200,812 more in revenue than expenditures.
The council and county manager also talked about significant budget cuts made two years ago. Council Vice President Mike Detmer said the fat had already been trimmed from the budget at that time.
"At this point, we're trying to keep the ship from sinking," he said.
Council President Lenny Pfeffer said he and Detmer have plans to go to Annapolis to testify in front of the Maryland General Assembly on legislation that would negatively affect the county's budget.
EDUCATION FUNDING
Detmer said the decrease in state funding and increase in the county's fiscal responsibility is largely driven by the state's goal to meet its financial obligation to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a state plan that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education.
Dorchester County Public Schools, which has its own budget separate from the county, also is facing a deficit. The deficit, which was estimated to be $10.19 million in January, is now estimated to be $5.59 million.
During a Dorchester County Board of Education budget work session also held Thursday, Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson shared refinements the district has made to the budget since the board's work session in January.
He said the $4.6 million in additional cuts to to reduce the deficit were made through reductions to alternative education programming, supplies costs, travel costs, contracted services and fixed charges as well as expanding the district's understanding of Blueprint guidance to better match funding with expenses.
"We are taking it serious, and we are trying to make the changes we can to reduce our budget in a smart way," Thompson said.
At the County Council work session, council member Ricky Travers said other counties are having the same budget problems.
"Rural Maryland is the worst right now because the bigger counties, you just add another zero to it, but they've got a little bit more ability to garnish more money per penny (on taxes)," he said. "But this big number is astronomical."
Jones said the county will play it by ear on when it holds its next budget work session. He said when it is held will be announced to the public.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Dorchester County's budget deficits, council and county manager actions, and fiscal planning, which are core local government issues, with education funding mentioned as a component of the budget.

title: Talbot County OKs funding for Easton High auditorium lights, other projects
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County OKs funding for Easton High auditorium lights, other projects

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 238
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Funding to replace Easton High School's auditorium lights was approved by the Talbot County Council at its Tuesday meeting.The auditorium's current lights date back to the school's renovation in 1997. County officials say they've heard for years about the need for new lights.
The project will cost $817,000, just over half of a total $1.5 million to be pulled from the county's capital projects fund. Talbot County's fiscal year 2025 budget has already accounted for the costs.
"That's huge for the auditorium," County Council President Chuck Callahan said. "So I'm glad that went through. That's going to be big for the school."
Council members also unanimously approved $556,000 for light replacements at St. Michaels Middle High School and $116,000 for athletic field improvements across the district.
Following those approvals, the County Council passed a bill permitting the county's sale of bonds to borrow $26.9 million for Chapel District Elementary School renovations. That funding from the county spans both fiscal years 2025 and 2026.
The renovation project, which broke ground last August, will upgrade the existing building and add on an additional 16,000 square feet. Chapel Elementary was last renovated in 1994.
Callahan said Talbot County Public Schools Director of Operations Kevin Shafer has done a "phenomenal job" leading renovation efforts.
"You've done excellent keeping us up to speed and everything, and trying to keep everything on budget," Callahan said. "We really, really appreciate it. It's huge for the community down there too."

title: Talbot County provides first look at draft budget for FY26
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County provides first look at draft budget for FY26

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Manager Clay Stamp said one aspect was clear when drafting the county's fiscal year 2026 budget: it needed to remain flat.Speaking with the Talbot County Council at a workshop Tuesday, county employees presented a balanced draft budget coming in at $163.3 million. It comes in slightly below last year's budget of $163.8 million.
The county's total budget has ballooned in recent years. In fiscal year 2023, it was $112 million, and one year later, it rose to $128 million. It took a sharper jump to the $163 million mark last year.
Stamp said the increases were for good cause. "You've made incredible and important investments in public safety and education," he told council members.
But Stamp emphasized that given federal uncertainties, state cost shifts and recurring county costs, it is important to curb that recent upward trend.
"That was a mandate as we put this budget together," Stamp said of the belt-tightening.
Stamp said the draft fiscal year 2026 budget currently proposes no additional job positions. The county's capital improvement plan is also trimmed back, he said. He hopes the county can focus on finishing projects already underway, such as Chapel District Elementary School renovations and a new EMS station in Cordova.
When drafting the budget, Stamp and Finance Director Martha Sparks said they initially came in $6 million over their target. To remedy that, they're proposing delayed payments for postemployment benefits and correctional officers' retirements, respectively — the latter of which is to be expected to be included in fiscal year 2027.
Sparks mentioned that tax hikes proposed at the state level for wealthy individuals may have an impact on Talbot County revenues. Sparks said last time a similar tax increase was levied in 2009, it made a significant dent, partly due to the recession.
"We had an exodus of the wealthy in our county as a result of that," Sparks said. "And it took us approximately 10 years to recover."
Sparks added, however, that the county looks OK for fiscal year 2026 in terms of those tax proposals. She said she's "not sure what that will look like for us moving forward."
As for policy and funding shifts at the federal level, Stamp said "it's reasonable" to expect impacts will trickle down to Talbot County.
"We are cognizant of that," Stamp said. "Radars are up, antennas are up. We're watching closely."
The draft budget shows $55 million in funding for the Talbot Board of Education. Stamp said the county must contribute that mark since it's required by state funding formulas. Any additional education funding is left for the County Council to consider in the coming weeks.
Council members and staff will hold a number of workshops this month and in April before a budget proposal is officially introduced April 15.
Public budget hearings are scheduled for May 6, and the County Council is expected to enact a budget ordinance May 27. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the county's draft budget, fiscal planning, and council processes, which are core functions of local government.

title: Counties approve Chesapeake College budget request, shift cost of tech center
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Counties approve Chesapeake College budget request, shift cost of tech center

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — In a joint meeting Thursday, officials across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties approved a shift in county cost shares for Chesapeake College's new technical building.During the meeting, which was held at the college's main campus in Queen Anne's County, the five counties approved a total $9.02 million budget request made by the college for fiscal year 2026. The school's budget is $1.31 million higher than its fiscal year 2025 budget.
Part of the $9.02 million budget request included a $952,560 request for the design of a new technical building. Chesapeake College Vice President for Administrative Services Karen Smith said the new building will have areas for a variety of programs, including agriculture, electrical, welding and fabrication, construction trades and advanced manufacturing. She said the cost for the design phase could be lower depending on state approval.
Although the five counties approved the request for funding for the design, the decision came with a shift in contributions toward the project.
Dorchester County's share of costs for the design phase will be taken on by Queen Anne's County. This means Queen Anne's County's responsibility for the project will jump from 28.9%, or an estimated $275,290, to 47.8%, or an estimated $455,324.
During the meeting, Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer and Vice President Mike Detmer outlined their council's concerns regarding paying for the project.
Although other counties hope to use the new technical building for career and technical education at the high school level, Dorchester County has a career and technology center it is still paying off, they said.
Through its budget process, Dorchester County has struggled to eliminate an estimated $6.2 million deficit.
Pfeffer said Dorchester County takes in about $45 million in property and income taxes and will have to give Dorchester County Public Schools $26.6 million for fiscal year 2026.
"So we're trying to run the rest of the county on half of that," he said. "So while in conceptual context, we believe in the project, fiscally our citizens and our staff are saying we don't know how we're going to be able to participate."
At the Chesapeake College meeting, Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jack Wilson Jr. shared his county's decision to cover Dorchester County for the project design costs.
"We all know what happens if we let this money go back to the state," Wilson said. "It's going to go somewhere else in this state, and it's not going to be here. We got this far. And Lenny, listen, I feel for you guys. I know what you're going through. But I think we just need to keep it on the rails at least through the design phase and see what the state's going to help with."
According to documents from the meeting, the state will support 75% of project costs, and the counties will support the remaining 25%.
After the counties voted to approve the amended capital budget, Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian said he understands the position Dorchester County is in, mentioning the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and "unfunded mandates" by the state.
"I think we all understand any one of us could be in your same position very easily," Fithian told the Dorchester County Council members. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on county officials approving and reallocating budget funds for a college technical building, highlighting inter‑county cost‑sharing decisions and fiscal constraints, which is primarily a local government matter, though it also involves education and budgetary economics.

title: Straightforward and good listener
author: Staff Writer
content:
Straightforward and good listener

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 195
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I have followed the proceedings of the Easton Town Council closely over the past five years. Don Abbatiello brings an impressive record of decades of public service to the race for president of the Easton Town Council.His 27 years teaching our young men and women is noteworthy by itself, but in addition, he has worked 16 years as part of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, both in the field and in administrative decisions. That kind of experience explains why he approaches even the toughest issues with an open mind and works hard to find agreement on the best solution for Easton.
In my dealings with him, he has been straightforward and a good listener — qualities that are too rare today. No ideologue, he focuses on the facts and not all the excitement around him. He does his homework and explains his reasoning.
Easton faces some tough challenges over the next few years, including adopting a revised Comprehensive Plan, mitigating the shortage of affordable housing and keeping Easton a vibrant community. Having the right person as council president lead the debates that will resolve those difficult problems is essential. Don Abbatiello is the right person.
Tom Ledvina
Easton

title: 70 children attend flashlight Easter egg hunt in Caroline County
author: AHMAD GARNETT
content:
70 children attend flashlight Easter egg hunt in Caroline County

 April 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT | Section: News 
 
 336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Kids enjoyed fun and special prizes at Denton Elementary Thursday for Caroline County Parks and Recreation's flashlight Easter egg hunt.Although the event was postponed from the week prior due to rain, Parks and Recreation program specialist Lynn Davis doesn't think the attendance was affected. Seventy kids aged 3 to 10 participated in the egg hunt, which Caroline County has been hosting the past 10 years.
"We love this. This is what we do it for," Davis said about having kids out for the event.
While traditional Easter egg hunts take place in the daylight, the Caroline County event has an added obstacle for egg hunters — darkness. The annual hunt takes place at dusk, and children use flashlights to help locate eggs on the elementary school's lawn.
Each age group had a special egg to look for. For ages 3 and 4, it was a soccer egg. For ages 5 to 7, it was a camouflage egg, and for ages 8 to 10, it was a football egg.
Each group had a separate time slot to capture the most eggs they could and go after the special egg. When a child found the special egg, they received a special prize, an Easter basket.
The event is fun for the children, but Parks and Recreation employees have fun as well.
"I found different patches of taller grass, leaves, branches and twigs," Parks and Recreations employee Liam Wallace said about hiding the eggs. "I kind of just hid it within those."
"It was just crazy. I wanted to see how happy they were out here, no elbows, no shoving, so safe fun," Halie Readores, another employee, said.
Lynn Zepp, a mother of two, brought her son, Weston, and daughter, Willow, to the egg hunt for their first year of participation.
"It was exciting," Lynn Zepp said. "We just got done with a baseball game, and we rushed over here because we wanted to try out the flashlight egg hunt."
When Weston and Willow were asked if they enjoyed the event, they said they had fun. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester County makes its way through grueling budget process
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County makes its way through grueling budget process

 April 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Over the past four months, an atmosphere of concern, frustration and, at times, despair has colored budget meetings in Dorchester County.In mid-April, the Dorchester County Council introduced a $91.96 million proposed operating budget for fiscal year 2026 with proposals to increase taxes. The introduction came after months of work by county staff to eliminate an estimated $6.2 million deficit.
At the same time, Dorchester County Public Schools has been working to eliminate a multi-million dollar deficit of its own. At an April budget work session, DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district is still $5.59 million in the hole. The district hopes to eliminate the deficit by the Board of Education's May meeting.
To balance and pass these budgets, difficult decisions — like the school district canceling summer school for 2025 and the county increasing 911 fees from $1.50 to $4.25 — have already been made.
"We hate to have to put any of this on the backs of our citizens, but these are state laws that are being passed down as a bandaid for us to pay," County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said in an interview with The Star Democrat. "And unfortunately we're having to pass it down onto our citizens because we have no other revenue to pay these bills."
WHAT MAKES FY26 DIFFERENT
Dorchester County's proposed operating budget is $10 million more than the fiscal year 2025 budget passed last May. County Manager Jerry Jones said the increases are in part due to new education requirements from the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education plan.
Jones said another reason the county has had to increase spending include cost shifts from the state to the county for things like teacher pensions.
In an effort to lessen budget costs, the county sought a waiver for the maintenance of effort for education, which is a law that requires counties to provide as much funding per pupil as was provided in the previous fiscal year. But with a narrow window between the state passing a budget and the waiver's due date, the county had to ask for an extension, which was denied.
"It's disappointing," Jones said. "But at the end of the day, we've got to keep moving forward."
Thompson said Blueprint requirements, like increasing teacher starting salaries, are part of the reason why the school district's budget — which is separate from the county's — has been difficult to balance this year. He said inflation and recurring program costs have also hindered the process.
"No decision is easy," he said. "But I think we're all trying to make the best decision for our students."
Both Jones and Thompson said they don't see the annual budget process getting easier any time soon. Jones said he doesn't see things getting easier unless change is made at the state level.
"I don't see (the budget) easing up in years to come unless some big changes are considered at the general assembly and future sessions," he said. "We'll see how it plays out."
TAX DIFFERENTIALS
One of the proposed changes to balance the county's budget is to remove the tax differential, or lower property tax rate, for Cambridge and Hurlock. This would mean Cambridge and Hurlock residents would have to pay the full property tax rate.
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas said although the county is trying its best to balance the budget, she believes this measure is unfair to Cambridge residents. She said the tax differential essentially returns money to tax payers for "duplicated" services.
Cephas also said Cambridge is growing, which will increase the tax base and bring in more revenue for the county. She said the county should instead look into raising taxes in unincorporated areas that are "a little bit better off."
Jones said he doesn't know what the final budget will look like, but said the council welcomes input.
"We want people to come forward and contribute to this conversation," he said.
Adoption of Dorchester County's budget is slated for May 20. The county's first public budget hearing will be held May 6.
Thompson said the Dorchester County Board of Education has to pass the budget by the end of June, but he hopes the board will pass the budget in May to give staff time to make necessary preparations. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Dorchester County's budget process, council decisions, tax changes, and public hearings, which are core aspects of local government operations, with secondary references to school district finances.

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 419
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are the 10 stories that attracted the most page views on The Star Democrat's website this week. The stories are ranked in order of number of page views as of Wednesday evening.1. Easton Planning Commission approves Zaxbys on Route 50
The planning commission approved new designs for a Zaxbys being build on Route 50.
2. Easton council rejects Gunsallus' proposal to delay introduction of campaign finance law
Town Council members held a heated discussion Monday on a proposed ordinance mandating campaign finance reporting in town elections.
Before the opening Pledge of Allegiance and prayer, council President Frank Gunsallus moved to remove the campaign finance law's introduction from Monday's meeting agenda. The remaining council members voted to proceed with the introduction.
3. Dorchester County proposes tax increases to balance FY26 budget
In an effort to address a $6.2 million deficit, the Dorchester County Council introduced a draft fiscal year 2026 budget that raised taxes.
The $91.96 million proposed operating budget presented Tuesday includes proposals to increase property taxes, remove the municipal tax differential, increase local income tax and eliminate tax rebates offered to municipalities.
4. TCPS announces leadership changes for coming school year
Talbot County schools will have several new principals and vice principals next school year.
5. With crab season open, Talbot watermen tracking weather and economy
As Maryland's blue crab season begins, local watermen have their eyes on the weather and the economy.
Jeff Harrison, president of the Talbot Watermen Association, said last week that he's expecting this year's crabbing outlook to be fair, perhaps slightly better than last year.
6. Counties approve Chesapeake College budget request, shift cost of tech center
In a joint meeting Thursday, officials across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties approved a shift in county cost shares for Chesapeake College's new technical building.
7. Easton house fire causes $1.5 million in damages
Forty-seven firefighters responded to a house fire on Locust Grove Road that caused $1.5 million in damages, according to the state fire marshal. No injuries were reported.
8. Talbot County introduces $161M budget with a focus on conservatism
Talbot County officials introduced a $161 million budget proposal, emphasizing their intention to flatten spending after multiple years of significant increases.
9. Fire marshal: Pool intentionally set on fire
A pool at a vacant property was intentionally set on fire, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.
10. Point-in-time count shows Mid-Shore homelessness is up
A point-in-time count conducted in January showed a 50% rise in people experiencing homelessness on the Mid-Shore since last year, according to results released earlier this month.
