title: Bill seeks to provide online protection for children
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Bill seeks to provide online protection for children

 April 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 367
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland legislators are heading a nation-leading effort to protect children and their data online.The Maryland Kids Code — a bill sent to the governor's desk after unanimous votes from the House and Senate on its third reading — seeks to afford protections to children from all online products they are likely to access.
The bill states that entities that develop and provide online services and products that children are reasonably likely to access shall ensure the best interests of children when designing, developing and providing those products.
Currently, 75% of the top social media platforms use AI to recommend children's profiles to strangers, according to the Maryland Kids Code Coalition's website. One in three of the top 100 free apps on the Google Play store have banner ads, including ads for adult content, the website says.
According to the Pew Research Center, in 2022, 97% of American teenagers aged 13–17 used the internet every day, with 46% responding they used the internet almost constantly.
Del. C. T. Wilson (D-Charles) was one of the sponsors of the bill.
"Tonight's vote is a landmark moment for Maryland kids and families working toward a better, safer online world," said Todd Minor Sr. and Mia Minor, parent advocates from Accokeek who founded the Matthew E. Minor Awareness Foundation. "We've worked hard for this moment, and we're super proud our legislators had the courage and determination to stand up to the Big Tech lobbyists in the hope that other families will never have to suffer pain like ours has endured."
The Matthew E. Minor Awareness Foundation was created after Matthew Minor died at 12 years old as a result of the "choking/black-out" challenge that had been circulating on social media and other internet platforms.
"Today's vote shows support for the Kids Code model's safety-by-design and privacy-by-default principles that transcends political divides, reflecting growing public recognition of the urgent need for smart, effective policy solutions to protect kids online," Maryland Kids Code Coalition spokeswoman Marisa Shea of St. Mary's County said.
The bill has wide-reaching support, with organizations like the Digital Harbor Foundation, the Free State PTA, the Maryland Association of School Health Nurses, the Maryland Coalition of Families and the Maryland State Education Association testifying in favor of it. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a legislative effort to protect children’s online data and safety, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns, though education and child health aspects are also mentioned.

title: Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For Warning Coordinator Meteorologist for the National Weather Service, Sarah Johnson, discussing weather's not just typical small talk.She deals in tornados, hail, high winds and severe storms all the time. As Marylanders escape winter weather, hopefully, there's a pause in the storm seasons.
June is considered the beginning of hurricane season and Johnson mentioned some things to stay alert to on the Eastern Shore.
At the Kent County Public Library on March 21, she introduced her audience to their program: SKYWARN.
She's looking for more and more people to become a spotter, who look out for the basics of thunderstorm development, storm structure and severe weather features, then report the information accurately.
"The main mission of the spotter is to be aware of the rapidly changing conditions of the weather," Johnson replied.
And it's sorely needed too.
Johnson said last year they reported the second most severe thunderstorms.
The third most for tornado warnings.
And the fourth most in flash flood warnings.
Unperturbed by the smaller audience in attendance, she was concise and enthusiastic while walking through the process of what to look out for.
For instance, people tend to be on high alert when they get something on their phone saying "tornado warning." Not so much when they get a "severe thunderstorm warning."
"That's a mistake to think one's worse than the other," Johnson commented.
Especially when water can be more harmful than wind in most cases, she said.
"When we look at the fatalities, 75% in the United States are due to water in some way; 50% of those are those are due to storm surge; 25% freshwater heavy rain flooding. Keep that in mind. Don't think, 'Oh, it's just a tropical storm.' No, you still need to pay attention and see what the hazards are."
Severe storms should not be treated much differently than a tornado.
She then pointed out the difference between a storm watch and a storm warning. A watch means to keep an eye on the weather pattern.
A warning means, don't just watch — get prepared.
A severe storm warning means, gather up some candles for light, or buy extra gas for the back-up generator and do things that will prepare your family and yourself for a potential hazard.
As hurricanes emerge from the North Atlantic ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, Johnson reminded her audience how to categorize them and what that exactly means.
Hurricanes, big or small, she indicated, can create problems, such as tornados.
The uninformed, she added, might hear about a category 1 hurricane and think it's not much of a problem. They'll see it as a little rain and wind. Very minimal damage.
The savvy spotter though, will see that even a category 1 hurricane can create big problems, such as a tornado. The spotter will know category 1, simply describes the wind of the hurricane. Nothing else. It does not highlight the possibility of it creating tornados or other adverse weather conditions.
And those who think tornados are only a threat in Kansas are in for a rude awakening.
Tornados hit everywhere, Johnson pointed out. Even in our backyard.
She said Hurricane Ida was a remnant tropical system that produced a lot of tornados in 2020.
Hurricane Isaias was a destructive Category 1 hurricane, producing the longest tracked tornado in Delaware history.
Tornados in Cecil County and Southern Delaware — resulted in fatalities last year.
"That's why we need you all," she said, encouraging her audience to report their observations to their nearest national weather station.
To become a spotter, adults are invited to complete the SKYWARN training.
Those who finish the course join a volunteer program with between 350,000 and 400,000 trained severe weather spotters.
Individuals affiliated with hospitals, schools, churches and nursing homes or who have a responsibility for protecting others are encouraged to become a spotter.
"There can be no finer reward than to know that your efforts have given your family and neighbors the precious gift of time—minutes that can help save lives," as stated by the NWS.
And as the movie "Twisters," the sequel to the original from 1996, comes out in theaters shortly, Johnson jokes that she's preparing to field a lot more questions about tornados.
She discouraged the crowd on becoming storm chasers like sensationalist Hollywood actors and actresses, but rather to become informed citizens who save lives. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a workshop that trains volunteers to report severe weather, emphasizing preparedness and life‑saving actions, which aligns most closely with public safety rather than purely educational or governmental topics.

title: Caroline County residents show support for child abuse prevention with pinwheels
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Caroline County residents show support for child abuse prevention with pinwheels

 April 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 606
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Four years since the first Pinwheels for Prevention planting ceremony in Caroline County, the number of shiny blue and silver pinwheels twirling in the breeze has grown.For the event, hosted by CASA of Caroline every year, the pinwheels are placed on lawns and in gardens throughout the county to spread awareness of child abuse and promote its prevention. CASA of Caroline Executive Director Amy Horne said the blue in the pinwheels represents the color of bruises, and the pinwheels themselves "represent the whimsical, carefree childhood that all kids deserve."
At the annual planting ceremony on Fourth Street in Denton on April 10, Horne said participation has grown throughout the county in the past four years.
"My gosh, go up to the Town of Ridgely," she said in an interview. "They have an amazing display."
CASA of Caroline is a nonprofit organization that advocates for and helps find homes for abused and neglected children.
On the nonprofit's website, there is a virtual garden that shows where many of the pinwheels have been planted this year. Horn said hundreds of pinwheels have been planted.
In the 20 years the organization has been around, it has advocated for more than 100 children in the county, Horne said.
"People may think (that because) we're a close-knit county, that it doesn't happen here, but it does," she said about child abuse. "With the tremendous outpouring of support — as you can see here, and that we receive all over the county — it's obvious that Caroline County is really committed to being a safe place for children and families."
CASA of Caroline Board President Keith Johnson talked about the different agencies and organizations that are involved when children experience abuse.
"We have representatives from Denton Police Department and the (Caroline County) Sheriff's Office here," he said. "A lot of times, those cases start with their work. But as those children progress, they go to social service and then our advocates, which serve each one of those children."
Caroline County Circuit Court Judge Heather Price said in an interview that CASA reports offer an important perspective to judges.
"They give me a different angle than what the attorneys representing the parents would say or the attorneys representing the department," she said. "Here you have the voice of the child that's speaking through an advocate."
Before attendees of the ceremony fanned out to plant pinwheels, citations and awards were handed out. Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) presented CASA of Caroline with a citation in recognition of the Pinwheels for Prevention campaign.
Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-36, Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline), who was also in attendance at the event, talked about the importance of the services CASA of Caroline offers children.
"In order to be able to connect them with that one person that they can trust, it takes a community to do that," he said. "It takes CASA to do that."
At the event, CASA of Caroline awarded the Caroline Career and Technology Center for the having highest participation across Caroline County Public Schools in coloring pinwheels to inspire hope from children experiencing abuse. Horn said 40% of CCTC students colored pinwheels. She said they will receive a Kona Ice party as their prize.
Career center Principal Courtney Handte said it means a lot to her and the center's staff that their students showed support for National Child Abuse Prevention Month, which is April.
"It's important for all students to know what is out there and available to them, and that they are not alone," Handte said. "Caroline County is a small community, but we are mighty. And we will surround them with the support and love that they need during challenging times." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community event raising awareness and preventing child abuse, involving police, sheriff, courts, and social services, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: A rough road: Students see bad choice consequences in mock crash
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
A rough road: Students see bad choice consequences in mock crash

 April 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 579
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A statewide initiative to curb road fatalities continues to send a sobering message to Maryland's newest drivers.What began nationwide decades ago as a lesson in the dangers of blending alcohol with driving now includes in its scenario the sad consequences of not wearing seatbelts or allowing diversions such as cellphones and conversations to take a driver's attention away from the road.
Public high schools in Calvert County have annually been the venue for mock crashes. This year three of the high schools participated in crash scenarios with the aid and supervision of emergency responders and police.
Last week's mock crash at Northern High began with the pretend scenario of a 17-year-old male, hosting a party at his home, hearing the sound of a two-vehicle crash down the fog-shrouded road leading from the house.
"I know them, they were just at my house," he tells 911.
According to the scenario a female driving a truck is ejected and is soon pronounced dead at the scene.
A smaller vehicle involved in the crash was operated by a young male who only suffers bruises but is later deemed impaired by alcohol and marijuana. A front seat passenger was not wearing a seatbelt and crews must extricate her from the vehicle. A rear seat passenger is assessed as unhurt but traumatized.
"Driving is a responsibility," Christy Nizer, Maryland's motor vehicle administrator, told the large group of Northern High students gathered around a back parking lot at the Owings school. "You need to give your full attention to driving."
Nizer warned students that Maryland roads aren't getting any safer with all the distractions adding to the mix of things that can go wrong while traveling.
"We lost 600 people in motor vehicle crashes," Nizer said of Maryland's 2023 death toll. The number represents a 6% increase from the 2022 total.
Many high school juniors are starting the transition from holding a learner's permit to being licensed to drive in Maryland.
Nizer and two other speakers — Christy Bliss, director of training for the Chesapeake Region Safety Council, and Calvert County Sheriff Ricky Cox (R) — acknowledged during remarks prior to the mock crash that many celebrations, including proms, graduations and parties will be taking place.
"You are the one behind the wheel," Bliss said, adding that she wanted students to think about, "what it means to be distracted. What it means to not wear your seatbelt. We want you to make better thought choices. We want to see you in your senior year."
"I've had to make notifications to parents that their child won't be coming home tonight," Cox said.
On the subject of impairment, Nizer that there are "new consequences" for all drivers that are cited for impaired driving. Legislation passed this year by the Maryland General Assembly expands the state's ignition interlock system program to include those granted probation before judgement for impairment while transporting minors under the age of 16.
Motorists with court-ordered ignition interlock systems in a vehicle blow into a device in order to get a vehicle to start.
In addition to the Calvert County Sheriff's Office and the Maryland State Police, volunteers from local fire and rescue also provided a demonstration of procedures in responding to vehicle crashes. Narration of the crash scenario was provided by Joe DellaCamera, a Metropolitan Police officer, volunteer firefighter and former chief of the Prince Frederick Volunteer Fire Department.
Coordination of the local mock crashes was done by Debbie Jennings, a Calvert County resident who serves as the region safety council's director of highway safety and special projects. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a mock crash program in high schools aimed at teaching students about road safety, emergency response, and preventing injuries, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Local program celebrates 10th summer of free swim lessons for kids
author: Staff Writer
content:
Local program celebrates 10th summer of free swim lessons for kids

 June 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Free swimming lessons are being offered for the 10th summer via the SOS Sink or Swim program.'SOS Sink or Swim offers three sessions of swimming lessons, each lasting for two weeks, at the George Murphy Pool in Easton and the Bay Hundred Pool in St. Michaels. This year's session start dates are June 17, July 8, and July 22. All children from age 18 months to 18 years are eligible to register for lessons," according a release from the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, which helps support the program.
The SOS program has provided swimming lessons to 8,000 local kids since its founding 2014.
"Swimming is an essential life skill for all ages, and it is critical for all children on the Eastern Shore to know how to swim and be safe in the water," said SOS Sink or Swim President Libby Moose.
The program is run through the Talbot County Department of Parks & Recreation and partners with CBMM and other local nonprofits such as BAAM (Building African American Minds) and Critchlow Adkins Children Centers.
"We are so proud to have been providing this service for ten years now," Moose said. "Each year, our generous community steps up to make these swimming lessons possible, and each year, we watch as children learn these crucial life skills. We look forward to many more years of teaching our children to save their own lives."
Registration remains open for the 2024 swim season. Those wishing to register can visit sossinkorswim.org/register. These free lessons are made possible by charitable donations. A gift of $50 can provide two weeks of lessons for a local child. To learn more or donate, visit sossinkorswim.org.

title: 'He snapped': Maryland teacher sentenced to probation for assaulting doorbell pranksters
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
'He snapped': Maryland teacher sentenced to probation for assaulting doorbell pranksters

 June 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Rising Sun High School teacher who has served as an educator for 30 years received a suspended six-month sentence and was placed on 15 months of supervised probation Wednesday, after pleading guilty to assaulting a 13-year-old boy after the child and a friend pranked him at his residence.The defendant, Dylan M. Aiman, 54, of Rising Sun, pleaded guilty to second-degree assault, a misdemeanor that is punishable by up to 10 years in prison. In exchange, prosecutors dismissed related charges of reckless endangerment and false imprisonment.
Cecil County District Court Administrative Judge Bonnie G. Schneider rejected a defense request to grant Aiman probation-before-judgement, commonly known as a PBJ — a verdict in which the presiding judge finds the defendant guilty and then sets aside the conviction, meaning the conviction will not appear on that person's record.
A PBJ reportedly would have been more favorable for Aiman when the Cecil County Public Schools administration decides on his future employment.
Assistant State's Attorney Joseph Verratti told the judge that he would not object to Aiman receiving a PBJ.
Aiman's defense lawyer, Thomas C. Morrow of Towson, told the judge that Aiman is on administrative leave, a status that school officials assigned Aiman shortly after a Rising Sun Police Department officer filed criminal charges against him in the wake of the early-May incident.
Joseph Buckley, who is the CCPS associate superintendent for administrative services, told the Cecil Whig on Thursday, "We are aware of the legal matter that's facing one of our employees and we're going to follow all of our human resources processes to access the situation to address the matter. We'll be working with the employee to address the matter. Other than that, at this point, we really have no further comment."
Buckley noted that CCPS officials are not at liberty to release specific information concerning personnel matters.
From the bench, Schneider opined Wednesday that a PBJ verdict would not be appropriate because, according to information provided by the prosecution, Aiman was convicted of failure to obey a peace order in 2012, some 12 years ago. (Aiman reportedly had been granted a PBJ in that 2012 case, which stemmed from a dispute with a neighbor, and he violated the peace order when he entered his neighbor's yard to retrieve as Nerf lawn dart that his son had shot onto that property.)
Electing to still accept the plea deal, knowing that the judge would not grant him a PBJ, Aiman pleaded guilty to second-degree assault. Then, after Verratti read aloud the statement of facts, Schneider found Aiman guilty of that offense and imposed a suspended six-month sentence on him. (Verratti had recommended a suspended one-year sentence, one year of supervised probation, an anger management class and no contact with the victims in the proffered plea agreement.)
In addition, the judge ordered Aiman to serve 15 months of supervised probation. Schneider acknowledged that Aiman already had successfully completed an anger management class since the incident occurred. The judge, however, ordered Aiman to take another anger management course if his probation officer deems that it is necessary.
The judge also ordered Aiman to have no contact with the two victims, one of whom turned 14 about three weeks after the incident.
Moments before sentencing, Aiman stood at the defense table, reflected on the incident and told the judge, "I clearly way overreacted."
His words echoed ones uttered moments earlier by Morrow, who reported that Aiman has an unblemished employment record during his 30 years as an educator, the last 24 of which in Cecil County, and that he is a RSHS biology teacher, one who teaches predominantly honors classes, in addition to that subject at other levels.
Morrow advocated for an outcome in the criminal case that might result in the "salvaging of his (Aiman's) career."
THE INCIDENT
Aiman chased the two boys in the early evening of May 4, which was a Saturday, after they rang the doorbell at his residence in the 200 block of Turtleneck Court and ran away — a prank known as "ding dong ditch."
After catching the teens across the street from his home, Aiman forced them back to his front porch, where he made the boys wait for police officers to respond after calling authorities and making a harassment complaint, according to court records.
RSPD Pfc. Cunningham and Patrolman Moore responded to the scene at 7:32 p.m., and Aiman told them that he "gripped one up," referring to one of the teens. Aiman maintained that he gave chase after the second time that the ding-dong-ditch prank had been pulled at his residence that evening.
In the courtroom Wednesday, the prosecutor reported that Aiman grabbed one of the boys by his sweatshirt, lifted him up by the garment and kneed him in the ribs. Verratti also reported that Aiman handled the situation in "an aggressive manner," which included him yelling at the boys.
Cunningham informed Aiman that "he could not put his hands on juveniles and that it does classify as an assault," according to court records.
"(Aiman) did not seem to understand, asking what he was supposed to do — let them run away. (Aiman) continually stated that he just held the kids on his front porch until the police arrived," court records show.
Aiman did not know the boys, who live in his neighborhood, according to the defense.
Investigators filed charges of second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and false imprisonment against Aiman on May 5, a day after the incident, and served him the criminal summons on May 6, court records show. He was released on personal recognizance.
'HE SNAPPED'
Morrow maintained that the incident was an aberration.
He reported that Aiman served as a soccer coach for RSHS boys and girls teams and as a coach for Cecil County Department of Parks and Recreation youth soccer teams, in addition to his 30-year career as a teacher, and that he received no official complaints.
The defense lawyer also told the judge that Aiman and his family have been the target of harassment in the Rising Sun community by unknown people for an unspecified long time, with encroachments including people hurling eggs at the Aiman house — which required professional cleaning — and cars and placing "anonymous threats in his mailbox.".
Aiman reported those incidents to police "multiple times" in the past, but nothing was done, Morrow said. Officers told Aiman that it would be difficult for law enforcement to take action unless he was able to identify the culprit or culprits, he added.
(Speculating on why Aiman was harassed, Morrow told the judge that Aiman is "a good teacher" who teaches biology at a high level, which can be difficult and frustrating for students. Aside from the two boys who admitted to playing the May 4 ding-dong-ditch prank at Aiman's home, however, no one has been identified as a perpetrator of the previous purported pranks and harassment directed at him and his family.)
Aiman caught the teens and held them on his porch until officers arrived because he wanted parents and authorities involved, according to Morrow.
"It was not his intent to injure anyone," Morrow said, stressing that Aiman told one of the boys, "I want you to call your father right now," after escorting the teens to his porch.
"His only intent was to get some kind of parental involvement to end this trend of harassment," Morrow said.
The defense lawyer also emphasized that Aiman is "facing potential dismissal and the loss of his teaching certificate" after 30 years as an educator.
Aiman's wife spoke on his behalf, telling the judge that her husband's action on May 4 was uncharacteristic. She blamed his response on the frustration and weariness of enduring pranks and various types of harassment over the years. She and Aiman have been married for 24 years.
She opined that a family's home should feel like "a safe place," one that provides "peace, a respite," before maintaining that the prolonged harassment had eroded her family's sense of tranquility and that the ding-dong-ditch prank on May 4 pushed her husband to his limit.
"He snapped. He had enough," Aiman's wife said.
She commented, "He's a great man, a loving father and a great husband . . . He's remorseful and sick about it (the incident)."
Aiman, who has six children, apologized to the two victims, their families, his own family, the school system and county parks and recreation moments before sentencing.
"I let all of them down, including myself," Aiman said. "I worked with kids to give them a positive experience in the classroom and on the soccer field."
He also alluded to the question hanging over his career in education, remarking, "Teaching is very important to me."
A LEVEL OF LEADERSHIP
The father of the boy whom Aiman picked up and kneed in the ribs told the judge that he was surprised when he learned that Aiman was a teacher.
"He's trained to deal with kids, to show a level of leadership. He should be someone to look up to," the father said. "It's concerning to me that this man is employed by the school."
The mother of the other boy also addressed the judge. She acknowledged that, although Aiman did not aggressively touch her son to the level that he did to her son's friend, the interaction with Aiman negatively impacted her son. She contended that Aiman yelled threateningly.
According to the woman, her son was afraid to walked into a store by himself one day after the incident. "I'm concerned how quickly he went into anger," she said of Aiman. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a criminal assault case involving a teacher, detailing the legal proceedings and sentencing, which aligns most closely with Public Safety. Education is a close secondary theme due to the teacher's employment context.

title: American Legion Post 77 donates $40,000 to local organizations and in scholarships
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
American Legion Post 77 donates $40,000 to local organizations and in scholarships

 July 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 299
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Approximately $40,000 was donated in scholarships and to local organizations — including local volunteer fire companies, children's organizations and churches — on Saturday morning by American Legion Post 77.Post 77 Judge Advocate Walter Black said Post 77 feels proud to be able to donate this money.
"It's consistent with our mission of assisting veterans and their families, and children and youth, and the community at large," he said. "We feel very good about that."
Black said making these donations addresses the needs of the community, living up to the Post 77's responsibilities as an American Legion organization. He said a lot of the money for these donations, which Post 77 makes annually, is raised through the slot machines located at the post.
Donations were made to volunteer fire departments in Talbot County, nearly 20 churches and a variety of other organizations, such as the Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers, the Talbot Senior Center, the Frederick Douglass Honor Society and the Neighborhood Service Center.
Representatives from these organizations came out Saturday morning to the American Legion to accept the donations.
Black said the event was wonderful and all the recipients were "very pleased."
According to a statement from one recipient organization, Channel Marker, which offers mental health and wellness support, this donation will help improve the wellbeing of its clients' lives.
Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers Executive Director Cristy Morrell said the event Saturday was "lovely."
"They support such amazing organizations in our community," she said. "And they're not always organizations that I think people are aware of. And so, that they include us in with those organizations is very humbling and we're very honored."
Morrell said the "generous" donation will be used for enrichment programming and tuition assistance at the Children's Center's Trappe and Easton locations.
"I'm just honored that they consider us a worthwhile cause," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Elkton High School deploying weapons detection system for football games, sports events
author: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com
content:
Elkton High School deploying weapons detection system for football games, sports events

 September 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As part of efforts to keep students safe, attendees of Elkton High School football games this fall will have to pass through a weapon detection system before entering the stadium.According to Leitgeb, the system is designed primarily to scan for 'mass casualty style' weapons, including guns and large knives, and will allow attendees to keep their belongings on them so as to not slow down entrance to the stadium. School officials noted that EHS football games average roughly 1,200 attendees, and other fall sports games can bring in 300 to 400.
"We are introducing the CEIA OPENGATE weapons detection system to enhance the security measures and safety for our students, staff, and community alike," Elkton High School Principal Dr. James Leitgeb wrote in a letter to EHS parents and guardians. "This advanced security technology is a walk-through detection system designed to identify and prevent unauthorized or potentially harmful items from being brought onto our campus."
The new system is consistent with Elkton High School's strict policy banning weapons on school grounds for any reason.
Leitgeb noted that the system is portable, and the school plans to make use of it beyond the fall sports season.
"We are doing this for our fall events, and eventually we do plan on using [the system] for our indoor winter games," said Leitgeb.
The OPENGATE system is comprised of two upright detectors that will be placed at the entrance to the stadium, which will likely look familiar to those who have gone to a professional sports game or concert recently. CEIA, an Ohio-based metal detector manufacturer, touts that the system scans bags and backpacks automatically, allowing lines to proceed through the gates faster.
"This system is highly effective yet minimally intrusive, allowing students, staff, and visitors to enter school premises without significant delays or disruptions," Leitgeb said.
The implementation of the system is part of a partnership between EHS and Elkton Police Department. According to Leitgeb, EHS staff will man the gates and, in the event of any alerts from the system, EPD officers and the School Resource Officer will be on hand to help handle the situation.
"One of my highest priorities as principal is the safety of our students and guests," Leitgeb said. "This is true not only during the school day, but at night time events as well."
Leitgeb also noted that the purchase of the system is part of a grant-funded pilot program and, if successful, other schools in Cecil County will make use of similar systems.
The detection system was slated to make its debut at Elkton's home football opener on Sept. 6 at the school's stadium. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the implementation of a weapons detection system to protect students and attendees at high‑school sports events, emphasizing security measures rather than the sports themselves or educational curriculum.

title: Assault at Easton High School sends student to hospital
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Assault at Easton High School sends student to hospital

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating the circumstances surrounding an assault that took place at Easton High School, located on the 700 block of Mecklenburg Avenue, on Sep. 10.At approximately 12:06 p.m., the deputy assigned as the school resource officer at Easton High School was alerted to an assault occurring inside of the school.
Deputies initiated an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the assault, in conjunction with the Easton High School administrative staff and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office.
Pursuant to the investigation, two juveniles, who are students at the school, were identified and arrested in relation to the assault. Deputies were also able to identify two victims of the assault. One of the victims is an Easton High School staff member and the second victim is a juvenile student at the school.
The juvenile victim was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.
The juvenile suspects were transported to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office for booking and processing. They were charged with first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and several other charges relating to the incident.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office will be contacting the Department of Juvenile Services to obtain a release disposition for both suspects.
Easton High School was placed on a brief lockdown during this event.
If anyone has information they are requested to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff or on our website at talbotsheriff.org.

title: Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Crime 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Videos showing the Tuesday assault at Easton High School have been circulating online. The incident involved three students and one staff member and ended with a student being transported to a hospital for non-life-threatening injuries.According to a press release released by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the assault happened on Tuesday afternoon. The videos paint a picture of the incident, though no further official statement has been released by law enforcement on the assault.
In the videos, a group of students are circling around the three students involved in the assault. Seconds into the video, one student in a black hoodie moves toward a student in a red hoodie and assaults him. The student in red falls to the floor. Immediately following, an additional student in a gray hoodie proceeds to join in the assault.
In the video, a male staff member in a white shirt attempts to protect the student that is being assaulted and physically puts his body on top of the student, seemingly to act as a barrier between the students.
The other two students seemingly continue to assault the student in red and begin to also assault the staff member. Soon after, other staff members intervene and separate the students and defuse the situation. The incident lasted around 30 seconds.
Deputies were able to identify two victims of the assault, one was an Easton High School staff member and the second was a student of the school. No identities have been released, and the incident is currently under investigation.
The assault resulted in one student being transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via Talbot County Department of Emergency Services to be treated for non-life-threatening injuries, police said.
The two other students in the video were identified and arrested in relation to the assault.
According to a statement from Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, the event is being evaluated and those involved will face appropriate disciplinary action.
"The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority. We are grateful for our partnership with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the presence of School Resource Officers in our schools," the statement said. "Deputy Horseman, along with several other Sheriff's deputies and members of the Easton High staff responded quickly to contain the incident. The students involved will face appropriate disciplinary action, and we are continuously evaluating safety measures to prevent or mitigate incidents of this nature." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a violent assault at a high school, focusing on the incident, police involvement, and safety measures, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: UPDATED: Social media post 'not a threat' to Easton schools, TCPS says
author: Tom McCall
content:
UPDATED: Social media post 'not a threat' to Easton schools, TCPS says

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students in Talbot County Public Schools were put in a modified lockdown after a threatening social media post was made Friday morning. According to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.A message sent to families in the district later that morning stated that the Talbot County Sheriff's Office confirmed the incident was "not a threat to our schools or community."
"They are continuing to investigate and will notify us if any additional information is received," the message said. "Thank you for your support in keeping our students and staff safe."
"We got a notification from Easton, Pennsylvania that they got the same exact notice," said Talbot County Sheriff's Office Public Information Officer John Bollinger. "It is all over and it is Friday the 13th and somebody felt like having some fun. From what we can tell so far, the threat originated from out of the country."
An initial message sent to parents of TCPS students Friday morning said, "We have increased police presence at schools this morning as a precautionary measure."
"The kids aren't outside," Bollinger said. "There have been some very generic threats, nothing specific, so we are just going above and beyond."
"... They are not letting anyone out doing outside activities and limiting kids in the hallway," he said.
Easton Police Department is assisting the sheriff's office in investigating the situation and monitoring the school.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After a threatening social media post on Friday was determined to not be a threat to Easton schools, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating another threat that has been circulating on social media.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, is not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. He said the threat is a photo of a "clearly" photoshopped Instagram message that includes the 410 area code.
"We're taking it very seriously, as we do every threat," Gamble said, adding that, through investigation, the Sheriff's Office doesn't think there is "any viable threat to the safety" of TCPS students.
According to a letter from the district addressed to TCPS families, the district is "closely monitoring the situation" and working with local authorities. The letter says that school operations will continue as normal.
Gamble said a criminal investigation by the Sheriff's Office is underway. He said all school resource officers in the district are aware of the threat, and extra deputies are patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
Gamble said the Sheriff's officer is aware of jurisdictions in other states that "have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats."
"It's happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear," he said.
Gamble said that a few years back, the district experienced something similar where about half a dozen non-specific threats were made during the course of the school year. He said he would expect to see more of these threats this year.
"This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a sheriff's office investigating a social‑media threat to schools, emphasizing safety measures and law‑enforcement response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat

UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 EASTON — Students and staff at Easton High School are evacuating after a bomb threat made Monday afternoon, according to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.At 2:57 p.m., the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said in a release posted to Facebook that deputies are on scene at the school. Students and staff were evacuated into the stadium and are safe, police say.
Police say students who are car riders are being picked up at the Easton Elks Lodge, students who are bus riders are riding buses and students who are walkers can walk home.
As of 3:01 p.m., "all buses (were) being loaded and released from EHS," according to police. All after-school activities are canceled.
Talbot County Public Schools sent EHS families a message at around 2:15 p.m. on Monday.
"Easton High has received a Bomb threat. At this time the school is on lockdown," the message stated. "We are waiting further direction from law enforcement."
"This is an ongoing investigation and Deputies will be on scene for several hours," Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated. "Please avoid the area and obey police detours. We will be sure to release additional information as soon as it becomes available."
Earlier on Monday, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said it was investigating a threat made on social media.
Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, was not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. It was not immediately shared by law enforcement if the Easton High lockdown resulted from this threat or from a separate threat.
On Monday morning, Gamble said all school resource officers in the district were aware of the threat, and extra deputies were patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
This report will be updated.

title: Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A 17-year-old suspect has been charged in connection with a bomb threat that forced an evacuation at Easton High School Monday.In a social media post on Facebook, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office announced detectives located the residence of a 17-year-old female and charged her with "making a threat of mass violence." Police say she is not enrolled in the Talbot County Public Schools system.
Students and staff were evacuated out of EHS on Monday afternoon after the threat was made just after 2 p.m. Police say a caller contacted the front desk and "advised that there was a bomb inside of the school and hung up."
"The caller re-contacted the front desk staff a few minutes later and asked when dismissal was," the Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated.
Police stated EHS staff immediately notified the school resource officer of the threat, leading to a quick evacuation from the building. The sheriff's office said all students and staff were safely evacuated as of Monday afternoon.
Deputies responded to the school, and bomb-detecting K-9 teams searched the building and surrounding property. Once cleared, staff returned to the school building.
"I am so grateful for the outstanding work our Talbot Deputies, Easton Police Officers, and our Talbot County Department of Emergency Services Dispatchers performed today to identify the caller of the bomb threat," Sheriff Joe Gamble said in a release.
"Within two hours the suspect was identified, located and charged," he said. "The teachers and staff at Easton High worked tirelessly with law enforcement to make sure everyone was safe. We are so fortunate to have such dedicated professionals in our community who work very hard to keep our children safe."
Deputies are working with the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office and "will be seeking additional charges if applicable," the sheriff's office said.
At Monday's Easton Town Council meeting, Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello thanked staff and first responders who handled the situation on Monday.
"I want to offer my sincere thanks to the teachers and the staff, and the first responders who attended the bomb threat today at Easton High School," Abbatiello said. "You all were professional in caring for our children and put them first. In this day and age, you cannot be too careful."
Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 4-H kids donate police vests to K-9's
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
4-H kids donate police vests to K-9's

 September 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 388
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Every first and third Wednesday, the Kent County Sheriff's Office K-9 unit, cooperating with law enforcement in Talbot, Dorchester and Caroline counties, train their dogs.On Wednesday, Sept. 18, they trained at Geno's Automotive in Kent County. After that, the K-9 units were invited to the Kent County Middle School to receive something special.
In a gesture of police support, the Kent Puppy Pals 4-H Dog Club donated a Line of fire Defense Street Fighter vest to Addy, a German Shepherd, handled by Dfc. Craig Lewis of the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office.
Going through Kent County Sheriff's Office Sgt. Scott Lockerman's organization, the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, the Puppy Pals donated a check for $300 in June.
Club Leader of Puppy Pals Kim Montooth explained each year they do a service project. Last year, for instance, they raised money for the Humane Society. This year was exciting for the kids and something different, Montooth said.
Molly's Place also donated $1,000 in a vest for Waylon, a K-9 black lab handled by Pfc. Nick Lang of the Easton Police Department.
In front of about 20 people, the dogs modeled the vests, which are lightweight enough yet specially designed to protect their vital organs.
Then the Puppy Pals kids and their families gathered around to pet the dogs.
After the children met with the dogs and 4-H mom Karri Bryant had a playful tug of war with Addy, they were invited into the school where they witnessed a live demonstration of how Addy sniffs out controlled substances.
Controlled substances were stashed in two classrooms. Led by Lewis, sniffing desks and drawers, Addy alerted to the controlled substance in both rooms in about 30 seconds.
Trainer Mark Carr of Tidewater Strategic Services said the dog doesn't go right to the spot because of the nature of scent itself. The K-9 moves around the perimeter of the room, getting the entire scent. Once she gets a complete picture, she can hone in.
President of the club Trenton Montooth was impressed. At 14 years of age, he has decided he wants to be a K-9 officer.
Lockerman thanked the Puppy Pals and Molly's Place, expressing the importance of their giving by showing the positive impact K-9 dogs make.
"K-9's make the community safer with their presence. Crime rates go down. Schools are much safer. Even the town's property values go up," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a police K-9 unit, safety demonstrations, and community protection efforts, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Talbot County Social Services educates on preventing child abuse
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County Social Services educates on preventing child abuse

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 333
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Department of Social Services hosted a child safety presentation Monday evening at the Talbot County Free Library to educate adults and children ages 3 to 12 on best practices to avoid child abuse.Paris Quillet, special projects coordinator for the department, presented the "Empower Me!" presentation, based on resources from the Jacob Wetterling Resource Center, a program that works to prevent child sexual abuse.
The county receives around 400 reports of child sexual abuse, physical abuse or neglect each year, she said.
"We want to talk about safety for our bodies the same way that we talk about fire drills and active shooter safety and bike safety," Quillet said.
Quillet emphasized to parents that the program avoids "stranger danger" terminology since over 90% of child sexual abuse nationwide is perpetrated by someone who the child knows. Instead, the program keys on the behavior aspect.
"We really want to make sure that we're giving these clear (messages) to children to focus on the behavior and how somebody makes us feel or what they're asking us to do, as opposed to the relationship," Quillet said.
In the children's portion of the program, children were encouraged to identify five trusted adults. Quillet encouraged parents and guardians to "be comfortable that (they) might not be the person that (children) come to for everything."
Having trusted adults in different spaces is important not just for young children but also teenagers, Quillet noted. With the dangers of technology and the internet, she said the 12- to 17-year-old age range is "more vulnerable than ever."
"We see a lot of things locally that revolve around technology and often used as a grooming practice," she said.
At the end of the hourlong presentation, Quillet said parents should stay involved in their children's activities and choose caregivers carefully.
"There should never be a time where I'm not allowed to have access to my children or I'm not allowed to watch them," she said. "… Screen all your caregivers carefully. Ask for references, definitely do unannounced visits." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a child safety presentation by a county social services department, focusing on preventing abuse and protecting children, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Bus driver likely to face charges after abandoning students at the wrong stop
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Bus driver likely to face charges after abandoning students at the wrong stop

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 733
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A bus driver for Newark Charter School in Delaware is expected to face charges after 10 elementary school students were abandoned at the wrong bus stop.The incident happened Tuesday afternoon as Bus #28 was driving the students home for the day. School officials called police at approximately 4:15 p.m. to report the incident, according to Sgt. Joseph Conover, a spokesman for the Newark Police Department.
The driver made the students — ranging from kindergarten to fifth grade — get off the bus at a stop in Robscott Manor, which is not their normal stop, Conover said.
A parent waiting for her child at that stop realized that extra students exited the bus and called the school and police to report the incident.
School officials and officers from the Newark and New Castle County police departments all rushed to Robscott Manor, where they found the students safe.
"The cooperative efforts between Newark Charter School, the Newark Police Department and its law enforcement partners ensured the safe reunification of all of the students with their guardians," Conover said.
State troopers tracked down the bus and confirmed that there were no more students aboard.
Conover said Newark's school resource officers are still interviewing students and families but he expects the driver to be arrested and charged with multiple offenses.
Police are still trying to figure out exactly why the students were told to get out in Robscott Manor. The neighborhood is on the bus route, but some of those students live a significant distance away from where they were dropped off, Conover said.
The mother of one of the affected students told the Newark Post she was waiting for her child to come home and was tracking the bus via an app that parents have access to. She began to get concerned when the bus was late and she saw on the GPS tracking app that the bus was going in the wrong direction.
She then got a call from the parent who witnessed the kids get kicked off the bus, and she went to Robscott to pick up her child.
She started to piece together what happened by talking to her son.
"He said they were at a stop, and the bus driver said 'Everybody get off the bus. Get your stuff and get off,'" recounted the mother, who asked not to be identified out of concern for her child's safety.
Some of the children were confused and scared and refused to get off, she added. At the next stop on the same street, the driver again told them it's the last stop and they had to get off, and the remaining students eventually complied.
She said she told her son she was proud of him for helping his younger classmates.
"It's just a crazy thing, but I do feel like the kids really stuck together and they kind of took care of each other," she said. "I think that made a lot of the parents feel better."
She also praised school officials for reacting quickly to ensure the students were safe.
The mother said she has decided to let her child continue to ride the bus, but she will be more alert about knowing who is driving her child.
"You don't really think about who is it that's driving the bus," she said. "You don't really see them a whole lot. You just kind of let your kid get on, and there they are."
The incident has taught her to be more vigilant about talking to her child about what happens during bus rides.
"A big takeaway with all the parents is just to kind of watch out a little bit more and try to notice if things do seem strange and having your kid be able to tell you if things seem off," she said.
The driver, whose name has not yet been made public, is an employee of Advanced Student Transportation, the bus company Newark Charter has contracted with since the school opened 23 years ago.
"Yesterday's incident was unfortunate and we are tremendously disappointed that it occurred," Head of School Sam Golder wrote in a letter to parents. "The bus driver will no longer be driving for Newark Charter School."
Golder assured parents the school is fully cooperating with the police investigation.
"Student safety is, and will continue to be, our number one priority at Newark Charter School," he said. "I personally have three children of my own and I would not have tolerated yesterday's behavior, had my children been riding this bus." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a safety incident involving a school bus driver, police involvement, and potential criminal charges, making Public Safety the most relevant category, with Education as a secondary match.

title: Queen Anne's County High School gets school security grant
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's County High School gets school security grant

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County High School has recently been awarded $70,000 to pursue the hiring of the district's first School Security Employee (SSE), according to Joe Saboury, coordinator of school safety and security.As of August, the district received funding from the Maryland Center for School Safety School Resource Officer (SRO) Adequate Coverage Grant under the 2018 Maryland Safe to Learn Act, Saboury said.
This funding allows school districts to hire an employee to serve as a supplement to the SRO already in place, he said. Resource officers already serving the school district fall under the direction and budget of the county sheriff's office.
The statewide grant funding assists in supplementing law enforcement coverage for public schools with $10 to 15 million in FY26 and $20 million in FY27 and each year thereafter, he said.
As school security is considered a top state priority, a minimum three years of funding following this year is secured, according to Saboury.
"So really that's putting additional eyes and ears in our schools, which is a wonderful thing," he said.
As a member of the district, the SSE works more closely with school leaders on safety measures, often outside law enforcement scopes, and are more closely involved with student behavior, support and providing intervention to mitigate and prevent harm, he said.
As district employees, QACPS has the flexibility to utilize SSEs for after school sporting events or field trips Saboury said.
"It's a great resource that the school district has never had before," he said.
SSEs are held to the same standards and certification programs through the Maryland for School Safety Model training as SROs.
Training, uniforms, equipment and overtime are all budgeted into the grant with no cost the district, he said.
With the potential for increased funding down the road, Saboury was hopeful to be able to build the program and continually create a safe learning environment for students. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester high schooler commended for efforts to get crosswalk installed
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester high schooler commended for efforts to get crosswalk installed

 November 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 380
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A North Dorchester High School student was celebrated at a Dorchester County Council meeting for her efforts to make the road near her school safer for pedestrians.During a Nov. 19 meeting, Aubrey Wanex received a commendation for submitting recommendations to the county's Traffic Safety Committee to improve the school zone on Cloverdale Road. Her recommendations included reducing the speed limit and putting in a crosswalk and extra signage.
"Her proactive approach to avoid a potential hazard and commitment to create (a) safe environment is essential in reducing traffic-related incidents," the commendation read.
Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said he received a call from Wanex, who told him there was no safe crosswalk at the high school for students who walk home from school.
Pfeffer said he was surprised by what Wanex told him because he knows there are students who walk home from school.
"So we had people look into it," he said.
With the help of Dorchester County Sheriff's Deputy Steve Mills and county staff, they were able to get the issue resolved, Pfeffer said.
"Thanks to Aubrey here, there's now a safe crosswalk," he said.
Pfeffer and the County Council weren't the only ones who thanked Wanex during the meeting. Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson congratulated Wanex and said her actions are a testament to the good things that many Dorchester County students do for the community.
"This is just one example of Aubrey doing a great job for the community and her school," he said. "I thank you and commend you myself. Keep up the good work at North Dorchester High School."
Wanex told those at the meeting that when she made the decision to reach out to the county about the issue, she was thinking about the future kids that will have to walk home from school. She said she had an experience where she nearly got hit by a car on Cloverdale Road.
"And I was just kind of upset about the fact that there was no crosswalk for kids that walk," she said.
Pfeffer thanked Wanex for reaching out to him and encouraged other young people to do the same if they have issues or concerns.
"We don't bite," he said about the County Council. "We love to hear from you. I mean, you are the future of this county." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Ground broken for state-of-the-art first responder training facility in Easton
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Ground broken for state-of-the-art first responder training facility in Easton

 December 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — First responders, along with local and state officials, broke ground Monday on a state-of-the-art emergency services training facility in Easton.The A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus is being constructed on Mistletoe Drive. The 7,200-square-foot facility is intended to allow for cross-training between emergency responders and reduce long commutes for first responders in training.
Brett Whitehead, president of the Friends of Easton Volunteer Fire Department, co-led the fundraising campaign for the facility with his partner, Ed Forte. Whitehead said on Monday that the campus will be in a world of its own as far as allowing firefighters, police officers, EMS workers and others to train together.
"There's no place that I know of … in the Mid-Shore where three of the legs, if you will, of emergency services can practice together," Whitehead said.
The closest training facilities are in Princess Anne and Centreville, Whitehead noted. Whitehead believes the Easton facility can be the premier cross-training facility in the region.
"We want to be the Taj Mahal," he said. "We want to be the mecca of education for all emergency services as it relates to what we do."
The campus will have a public safety building and an educational building with classrooms, as well as a 1,500-square-foot concrete pad for car fire and extrication training. Hostage rescues, ladder climbs and traffic safety situations are other ways in which the facilities will be used.
Leaders from across public safety agencies attended Monday's groundbreaking, including Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey and Talbot County Director of Emergency Services Brian LeCates.
LeCates said the facility will be a "more professional setting" for collaborating and training to take place. That setting could end up saving lives, he said.
"We all know that every second counts," LeCates said. "In real emergencies, lives are at stake, and the difference between success and failure often comes to how we train before the disaster occurs."
"At least 90% of the calls that we go on involve all three groups," Whitehead said. " … It allows us to all hone our skills together. And that's the magic of what we're trying to get done. Hopefully in 12 months, we'll have this facility built."
FUNDRAISINGThus far, around $4 million of the $5 million goal has been raised for the A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus.
As the name indicates, the A. James & Alice B. Clark Foundation and its Board Chair Courtney Clark Pastrick were fundamental in that fundraising success. Last September, the foundation gave $1 million to the fundraising efforts for the training campus. In total, the foundation has contributed $1.9 million to the project.
"I don't think I've ever encountered someone as professional and, as my wife reminds me, gracious, as Courtney Clark Pastrick," Whitehead said.
Clark Pastrick said she knew the project was a "perfect fit," something her late father, A. James Clark, would be immensely proud of. She thanked all the community members and sponsors who donated to the project in tandem with the foundation.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said the state House and Senate chambers each contributed $150,000 to the project, a charge led by Jeannie Haddaway-Riccio, a former Republican legislator and Department of Natural Resources secretary.
Former Easton Mayor Bob Willey attended the groundbreaking event, adorned with his fellow firefighters in Easton Volunteer Fire Department gear. Mautz, Whitehead and Mayor Megan Cook each thanked Willey for having the original vision to bring a project like this to life.
"This is going to go so far as to improving our fire service, but most importantly, to make it safer, so more people will join the fire service," Mautz said.
"And it is no surprise to me that our very own 62-year veteran of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, Mayor Willey, was the one who sparked this idea. Mayor Willey, we owe you an incredible debt of gratitude," he said.
This report has been updated to correct the name of the training facility. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the construction of an emergency services training campus for firefighters, police, and EMS, highlighting cross‑training and public safety preparedness, making Public Safety the most relevant category.

title: Winter Weather Closures
author: Staff Writer
content:
Winter Weather Closures

 January 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 688
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The National Weather Service forecast calls for snow on the Eastern Shore beginning Sunday evening, Jan. 5, throughout Monday with possible accumulation between 5 and 10 inches. Schools, businesses and other agencies have announced closures.SCHOOL CLOSINGS, Monday, Jan. 6
Caroline County Public Schools.
Dorchester County Public Schools.
Kent County Public Schools.
Queen Annes's County Public Schools.
Talbot County Public Schools.
TOWN OF EASTON
Due to the incoming snowstorm, government offices for the Town of Easton will be closed on Monday, Jan. 6. Essential public safety, public works and facilities maintenance employees will still report to work to ensure the town's safety and necessary operations. Any further closures will be evaluated as the situation develops.
The Town Council meeting scheduled for Monday, Jan. 6, will be canceled. The next Town Council meeting will take place on Tuesday, Jan. 21.
SHORE REGIONAL HEALTH
The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health following outpatient services will be closed on Monday.
All Shore Medical Group Practice doctor's offices.
All outpatient laboratory locations.
All outpatient imaging locations.
All outpatient rehab locations.
All cardiac rehabilitation locations.
Outpatient behavioral health.
UM Sore Ambulatory Surgery Center on Caulk Lane.
UM Shore Ambulatory Surgery Center in Cambridge.
UM Shore Cancer Center in Easton.
Clark Comprehensive Breast Center in Easton.
Leh Women's Center in Chestertown.
DORCHESTER COUNTY
Due to the pending winter storm, Dorchester County faces a threat of danger to residents, food, water, livestock and property due to associated snow, ice and other significant hazards. As a result, the Dorchester County Council implemented a snow emergency declaration effective at 5 p.m. Sunday until further notice.
Dorchester County offices, including all landfills and transfer stations, will be closed Monday.
As a reminder, during this emergency period, the use, operation, driving and parking of vehicles on Dorchester County roads and streets will be affected as follows:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on a county road or street during the time a snow emergency declaration is in effect.The Dorchester County Sheriff's Office shall have the authority to take possession of, issue citations for removal, tow away and impound any vehicle parked, stalled, incapable of proceeding under its own power or left unattended upon any county road or street while a snow emergency is in effect.Before the owner of thereof may obtain possession of such vehicle, they shall pay the cost of removing such vehicle and any storage charges.It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle on any County road or street while a snow emergency is in effect without chains or adequate snow tires on two-wheel drive vehicles, should such vehicle become stalled or incapable of proceeding under its own power.Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this snow emergency declaration, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.
More information will be provided on any additional cancellations, delays or closures as the weather continues to be monitored.
YMCA OF THE CHESAPEAKE
Due to forecasted weather conditions, all branches of the YMCA of the Chesapeake will delay opening Monday. The snowfall will be assessed first thing in the morning and opening hours and any cancellations will be announced. Road conditions will be monitored throughout the day to determine if early closures will be necessary for the safety of staff and members.
Before you head out, check the YMCA app, Facebook page or the website, or call to confirm what time your branch will open.
The safety of members, staff and community is the top priority.
ST. MICHAELS TRASH SERVICE
Due to the anticipated winter storm, Republic Services has postponed regular trash pickup for St. Michaels on Monday, Jan. 6. We will update you once we hear more.
The St. Michaels Public Works Department will be working diligently to clean up after this storm. Please call the St. Michaels Police Department with any water or other emergencies at 410-745-9500.
For regular trash questions, please contact Dominic Fulginiti with Republic Services at dfulginiti@republicservices.com or by calling 800.492.5999.
This story has been updated and will continue to be updated as additional closings are announced.

title: Icy roads, school closures continue into Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com

Icy roads, school closures continue into Thursday

 January 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Snow has covered the roads of the Eastern Shore since Monday. The counties of Eastern Shore believe they have a plan to get the roads clear by Thursday.Town of Easton crews are working to salt all back roads in town, according to town engineer Rick Van Emburgh.
Van Emburgh said Wednesday afternoon that emergency roads, such as those leading to the hospital, had been the priority. At that point, back roads had been plowed twice and now they focus is salting to prevent from freezing.
Mark Chandler, superintendent of public works for the town of Denton, said as of Wednesday afternoon all roads in town were passable, but he encourage residents to drive with caution.

With schools closed for at least three days this week, Mid-Shore residents have raised questions of whether student will be required to make up missed instructional time.
Talbot County Public Schools will remain closed on Thursday "due to the continued treacherous road conditions in some parts of the county," according to the district's website. TCPS has four days built into the 2024-25 calendar for inclement weather, according to district officials. This means the four days missed will not affect the end of school date for the school year.
Dorchester County Public Schools announced Wednesday evening that Thursday would be a virtual day of instruction for students. Students have been provided with electronic devices to allow them to access classroom instruction. According to the DCPS website, DCPS has three inclement weather days built into its calendar, meaning the three days missed earlier this week will not affect the end of school date for the year.
Caroline County Public School will also be closed Thursday, according to the district website. CCPS has four snow days built into the calendar for inclement weather, meaning the days missed will not affect the end of school date.
