title: Easton ICE arrest not school-related, official says
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton ICE arrest not school-related, official says

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An arrest made by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, in Easton last week was not school-related, according to Talbot County Public Schools.According to police, an ICE arrest happened on Glenwood Avenue near Easton Elementary School Thursday. In an email to The Star Democrat, the district said the arrest did not take place at the school.
School and police officials say rumors of a parent being detained while dropping off a child at the elementary school are false.
Representatives of the Easton Police Department added that the arrest was made due to outstanding warrants for an individual in town and not as a result of any directive from the new presidential administration. EPD officers were not involved in the arrest, but the department contacted the Department of Homeland Security following the incident as rumors began to circulate.
As of Monday, the Talbot school district had not communicated with families regarding the rumors, though counseling and mental health support for students, families and staff has been made available. TCPS' Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said in an email that the district has reviewed its existing protocols around "actions or inquiries by law enforcement."
Last week, State Superintendent Carey Wright sent a letter to Maryland superintendents outlining the practices school employees should take if immigration authorities enter schools.
"If federal immigration officials or law enforcement enter a school building seeking access to students (for interviews and/or questioning), school personnel should contact the local superintendent immediately for guidance," Wright wrote on Jan. 23.
"School personnel should not argue or debate with immigration enforcement officials but should direct them to the local superintendent or designated administrator for further action," the letter read.
Wright's letter comes as Donald Trump's immigration initiatives have brought sweeping policy changes since the inauguration last Monday.
A directive last week from the Trump administration reversed a policy that established places such as schools, churches and shelters as "protected areas." That policy discouraged immigration enforcement agents from conducting arrests in those areas.
"Criminals will no longer be able to hide in America's schools and churches to avoid arrest," Department of Homeland Security spokesperson Benjamine Huffman stated. "The Trump Administration will not tie the hands of our brave law enforcement, and instead trusts them to use common sense."
In her letter, Wright said that if immigration officials request student records, local schools should consult with their attorneys.
"Personnel should immediately notify the student's parent or guardian if an immigration official or law enforcement officer requests or gains access to a student for immigration-enforcement purposes," Wright stated, "unless such access was following a judicial warrant or subpoena that restricts the disclosure of the information to the parent or guardian."
In a statement, Talbot County Public Schools said that superintendents across the state had a meeting with Wright, as well as the Maryland ICE director. The district is following guidance from the Maryland Department of Education on immigration enforcement actions.
Regarding the Easton arrest, a spokesperson for Enforcement and Removal Operations' Baltimore field office did not provide specific information on the arrest or if other arrests in the area have occurred in the past week. Enforcement and Removal Operations is a directorate of ICE.
"ERO Baltimore works daily to prioritize public safety by arresting and removing undocumented alien offenders who pose the greatest threat to our communities, to include those with serious criminal convictions who have violated our nation's immigration laws," an email statement read. "By focusing on these high-priority cases, we aim to uphold the integrity of our immigration system while promoting the safety and security of Maryland's residents." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kent ham radio club tests emergency communications skills
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent ham radio club tests emergency communications skills

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON — As wildfire recovery begins in southern California and a lengthy reconstruction effort continues after Hurricane Helene devastated the Appalachian area, emergency preparation is getting attention.In Kent, that conversation and training is happening among amateur radio operators prepared for potential disasters on the Eastern Shore.
Starting at 3 p.m. Saturday, over 24 hours, the Kent Amateur Radio Society club set up satellite and radio equipment in the Kent County High School parking lot. Using emergency power from generators and solar panels, they communicated with 145 stations — 18 were amateur radio satellites.
With a refurbished school bus and a camper, they operated from five stations, classified as mobile, including the emergency trailer EMCOMM 1, which contained equipment from the school's ham radio classes taught by WKHS station manager Chris Singleton, a KARS member for 30 years.
EMCOMM 1 serves as backup when regular emergency dispatch fails.
This was part of the American Radio Relay League's Winter Field Day training exercise. Radio operators set up field operations in remote locations "with the aim to improve their preparedness for disasters, enhancing their operational abilities in adverse conditions."
For KARS members, ham radio is a lifelong passion, but disaster preparation remains the priority.
KARS President Chris Cote cited Hurricane Irma in September 2017, when 7.5 million homes lost electricity. Ham radio could become the only communication mode in such situations.
Inside Cote's bus, three stations operate off a 12-volt battery charging from a solar array — two radio with VHF/UHF capabilities and one satellite communications. They reached operators nationwide without external power all weekend.
The event reached young people when Singleton's KCHS broadcasting students operated the ham radio. Junior, Jordana Capp, in her second year of broadcasting, contacted Washington state over a Russian satellite connection.
Junior, Aidan Maxey, also in his second broadcasting year, made contact with New York. He plans to pursue media studies at Syracuse, impressed with ther program.
Senior, Alayna Brown, featured on Radio World's Jan. 1 cover, contacted Tennessee. Brown, already certified by the Society of Broadcast Engineers, was recently accepted to Belmont in Nashville, where she plans to work with multitrack recording systems, live stage and master tapes.
All three students became interested in ham radio certification after attending the ARRL School Round up on Oct. 21. Brown had communicated with Russia during that event.
Singleton celebrated his students' interest in this vital skill. He had worked for 15 years to engage youth in ham radio, noting that combining broadcasting skills, live audio, music production and SBE certification opens many career paths.
"They are amazed," Singleton said. "They don't get many opportunities to work with this very specialized equipment. It is a rare opportunity."
KARS members continue generating youth interest in ham radio by teaching them radio operating skills and attending the Winter Field Day Contest. They anticipate the ARRL School Club Roundup Contest Feb. 10-14 as well.
On Sunday, as Cote's drone photographed their stations, KARS member Bobby Kelley helped newest member Alberto Larotonda dismantle his homemade antenna built from a ski pole, copper pipes and a drywall mud bucket.
"My little setup just shows anybody can do this with enough imagination," said Larotonda, who joined two months ago.
Cote said while no one wants to think disasters like those in California or North Carolina will strike locally, testing equipment in harsh conditions benefits the county; ensuring first responders that it is battle-tested.
For more information about KARS, visit k3ars.org/kars/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 6 to 8 inches of snow expected in Tuesday evening winter storm
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
6 to 8 inches of snow expected in Tuesday evening winter storm

 February 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The National Weather Service have declared a winter storm warning in Easton and other Mid-Shore towns from Tuesday at 1 p.m. to Wednesday at 7 a.m.The weather service expects Easton and Cambridge to get about six to eight inches of snow.
After the snow, temperatures are expected to rise into the 40s, with a wintry snow and rain mix until 4 p.m. and rain lasting until Wednesday evening.
Due to the incoming snow Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester counties have taken precautions to prepare roadways and winter weather crews.
Talbot County Emergency Services started planning with the National Weather services on Sunday.
"We also know that our local roads department, as well as our state highway partners, are working on pre-treating the roads now and then," Geneva Schaffle, Emergency Management Division chief for Talbot County, said. "We'll have crews working to clear the roads tomorrow through Wednesday."
Talbot County will be sharing alerts through Facebook and its alerts system.
Caroline County Emergency Services said it would have a meeting Monday to discuss its plans for the snow with the state and the National Weather Service.
County emergency officials encourages motorists to stay off the roads for all unessential travel Tuesday night and Wednesday morning while crews work to combat wintery conditions.
Dorchester County Emergency Services could not be reached for comment Monday.
Talbot County Public Schools will be operating on a half day early dismissal schedule on Tuesday, with students leaving campus at noon.
In case the winter storm weather leaks into Wednesday, Talbot County Public schools sent home devices with students on Monday to conduct a virtual learning day on Wednesday if needed.
Caroline and Dorchester County Public Schools will also be operating on half day early dismissal schedules Tuesday. Students in these districts will also return home at noon.
If any changes are made, the districts will update students and parents via social media and county websites.

title: Court docs: Delaware middle school teacher spent months grooming student online with sexual messages
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Court docs: Delaware middle school teacher spent months grooming student online with sexual messages

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Delaware court documents released Tuesday shed new light on how a Kirk Middle School teacher allegedly spent months grooming one of his students by sending her sexual messages and fantasies through an online chat application.Ultimately, the inappropriate behavior expanded to school grounds, where David DiFilippo would spend time alone with the 13-year-old girl in his classroom, making sexual comments to her and, on one occasion, touching her legs, court records allege.
DiFilippo's actions "are clearly and reasonably indicative of an adult grooming and enticing a minor for the purpose of sexual contact and/or a sexual experience," Detective Marc Conway, of the Delaware State Police, wrote in court documents, adding that DiFilippo was trying to build up trust with the girl to "ultimately entice and arouse her sexually."
DiFilippo's alleged behavior took place between September 2023 and February 2024, when DiFilippo was 43 and 44 years old.
During that six-month period, DiFilippo and the girl chatted nearly every day over Discord, a messaging app. The messages were "flirtatious and sexual in nature," and DiFilippo suggested sexual acts with the girl, made comments about her body and clothing and referred to her as "babe" and "baby," court records show.
He sent her several stories detailing explicit sexual fantasies involving her engaging in sexual intercourse, masturbation and oral sex. He would then ask the girl "if the writings were good enough that she could picture them in her mind and if reading them made her feel a certain way," court documents allege.
One story involved a teacher and a student having sexual relations on a school bus during a field trip, and DiFilippo then told the girl he was planing a field trip and asked if she would like to sit with him on the bus, court records indicate.
DiFilippo would delete the messages after the girl read them, but she kept screenshots of the messages on her phone.
DiFilippo's behavior eventually extended into in-person encounters, and he would allow the girl to skip class to hang out with him alone in his classroom during his planning period when he did not have a class to teach. Other times, she would stay in his classroom after class ended and the other students left.
On one occasion, DiFilippo told the girl he liked her "milky white thighs" and said seeing them made him feel "like an animal ready to attack his prey," court documents allege. Another time, he suggested they go into a closet to kiss, but the girl refused. On a different day, the girl brought DiFilippo an assortment of snack food and asked him which he liked best, to which he replied he liked "the snack in the dress," presumably referring to her.
Court records describe one incident in which DiFilippo's behavior turned physical. The girl was sitting on a counter near his desk, and DiFilippo allegedly knelt down and rubbed her legs. The girl told him to stop, which he did.
It's not clear why DiFilippo's behavior ended in February 2024. Court records indicate that the girl told her therapist about it in August 2024, sparking a police investigation.
The girl provided police with screenshots of DiFilippo's Discord messages, and detectives later subpoenaed Discord for a transcript of the messages sent from his account. Investigators interviewed the girl with help from the Child Advocacy Center in Wilmington.
DiFilippo turned himself in to police in February after the months-long investigation.
He was charged with sexual solicitation of a child, enticement for purposes of sexual conduct, dangerous crime against a minor, promoting sexual solicitation of a child, providing obscenity material to a child, sexual abuse of a child by a person of trust and offensive touching. He was released after posting $65,500 secured bond.
Police asked anyone with information or who may be a victim to contact Conway at 302-365-8411.
According to a brief biography posted on Kirk's website, DiFilippo taught in the gifted and talented program and has been a teacher for approximately 15 years. He wrote that his favorite part of the job is "forming strong bonds and relationships with my students."
A spokesperson for the Christina School District did not respond to a request for comment. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal investigation, police involvement, and court charges related to a teacher's sexual grooming of a student, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety category.

title: Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy
author: Konner Metz
content:
Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students in grades 10 through 12 graduated from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office inaugural citizens police academy Tuesday night.In a 10-week course that met every Tuesday, officers provided students an inside look at the law enforcement field, teaching topics such as crisis response, bleeding emergencies and traffic stops.
Saints Peter & Paul sophomore Carson Tyree said the academy changed his perspective of police work.
"What stood out is how these guys work. It's not all fun and games," Tyree said. " … When they go into a situation, there's a lot of thinking behind it because they can't violate procedure. If they violate procedure, they can't be a police officer."
Junior Canin Parks said he took the academy to learn more about law enforcement since he is considering entering the field. His favorite week was the virtual reality simulator, during which students were posed with the virtual task of helping people in distress.
Jules Stepp, a Saints Peter & Paul junior, most enjoyed learning about Talbot County's crisis response unit, or SWAT team. Students were shown the inside of a SWAT van and learned about the materials and techniques used in situations that call for crisis response.
"It was like we were there with them," Stepp said. "We got to live vicariously through them."
Stepp said she recommends the academy to anyone interested. The academy made it clear the extreme level of detail that policing requires, she said.
"I was surprised how much detail went into every little thing, and how one little thing can cause a problem so they had to backtrack and think about what the consequences could be," she said. "And how they have to go through so many processes to get grants, peace orders, protective orders and all that type of stuff."
Following Tuesday's 10th and final class, Maj. Steve Elliott thanked the students and called them a "great group" for the first ever citizens police academy. Lt. J.R Dobson said it was a fun 10 weeks.
"I think from day one — when (Sheriff Joe Gamble) was giving you guys a lesson on when the first sheriff of Talbot County was — until now, I've seen you all loosen up," Dobson said.
Gamble thanked Lori Stepp, the grants administrator for the Sheriff's Office, for procuring a grant to make the police academy possible.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is now fielding applications for its second citizens police academy. This round is open to county residents 18 and older. Classes are held every Tuesday for 10 weeks beginning April 8. Applications are open until March 31.
Graduates of the inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office citizens police academy:
Yvonne Herrera Hernandez, North Caroline High School.
Ian Knopp, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Eric Loredo, Easton High School.
Sofia Miller, St. Michaels Middle High School.
Canin Parks, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Jules Stepp, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Carson Tyree, Saints Peter & Paul High School.
Evelio Urdaneta Delgado, Easton High School. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: It takes a village: QA CARE Center goes blue in recognition of Child Abuse Awareness Month
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
It takes a village: QA CARE Center goes blue in recognition of Child Abuse Awareness Month

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 275
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Highlighting April as Child Abuse Awareness Month, Queen Anne's County Child Advocacy and Resource Center welcomed community partners for an open house April 8.Formed in 2011, the CARE Center is a non-profit program formed through a partnership with the Queen Anne's County Department of Social Services, the State's Attorney Office, local law enforcement and mental health professionals.
A place to coordinate investigative, medical, mental health and legal services, the CARE Center provides a warm, child-friendly environment for collaborative services surrounding child abuse as well as providing family advocacy support for non-offending caregivers.
"It's important to celebrate the partnerships who work hard for the children in the community," said Child Advocacy Center advocate Carole Friend.
Using this collaborative multi-disciplinary approach, the CARE Center brings key professionals together under one roof to work on behalf of the best interests of the child.
The center brings all necessary officials to one place and children only have to tell their story once, Alex Sweetak, Center assistant director said.
The center is also home to wellness activities to support mindfulness and reduce anxieties, educational resources, and a family room where advocates like Friend, can meet with children in a safe, friendly environment.
From ages nine months to 17, the center works with schools to provide outreach and information and provides referrals to community agencies, she said. Even after the interviews, the Center continues to work with children and families as much as they need, according to Friend.
"It definitely makes a difference for the children in our community," said Friend.
Officials noted child advocacy has come a long way over the years and the Center stands at the forefront of allowing conversations and erasing stigma. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a child advocacy center that coordinates law enforcement, social services, and mental health professionals to address child abuse, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Easton High School graduate dies in car crash
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton High School graduate dies in car crash

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Easton community is mourning the death of recent high school graduate Darren Foxwell.Foxwell, 18, died following injuries sustained as a passenger in a single-vehicle car crash just outside Trappe on Tuesday morning. He was transported to Shock Trauma in Baltimore for treatment of life-threatening injuries. He died on Wednesday afternoon, his family said on Facebook Thursday.
In a Facebook post on Wednesday, Darren's father, Len Foxwell, wrote that the family is "eternally grateful for everyone who has sent their love and support, for those who have stepped up with profound gestures of support, and for Darren's friends who drove here from Easton yesterday to say goodbye to their childhood buddy."
"Each of you have been a lifeline and have honored Darren in your own special way," Len Foxwell wrote.
His father added that the team at Shock Trauma in Baltimore "fought like a tiger to keep Darren comfortable, preserve his dignity and provide solace for a family that has been destroyed."
A member of Easton High School's wrestling and lacrosse teams, Foxwell graduated last month. He planned to attend Bethany College in West Virginia this fall and play lacrosse for the Bison.
Foxwell played the last two years for Easton as a backup defenseman. Easton High boys head lacrosse coach Dennis Keenan said he was popular among his teammates and had a "bright future."
"I think he was funnier than he actually thought he was," Keenan said. "The things he would say would just crack me up. He was getting better each day. You could see flashes of brilliance."
Foxwell wrestled for three years at Easton, including under head coach Jason Biringer during his senior year. Biringer said Foxwell had an "infectious" personality.
Early this past season, Foxwell stepped away from the wrestling team. But after speaking with his coach, he returned and started at the 167-pound weight class for the Warriors.
After returning to the team, Biringer made Foxwell a team captain because of Foxwell's work ethic and focus.
"The other wrestlers looked up to him," Biringer said. "He has such a good, gentle demeanor that he was just very well liked."
"He just had one of those infectious smiles that you're like, 'It's always good to see Darren,'" Biringer added.
Family said on Thursday that arrangements for funeral services and a celebration of life are being made and will be announced soon. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a fatal car crash involving a recent high school graduate, focusing on the accident and its consequences, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Ham it up: Queen Anne’s Amateur Radio Club has a 'Field Day'
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Ham it up: Queen Anne’s Amateur Radio Club has a 'Field Day'

 July 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 647
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE — Showcasing amateur radios are a versatile means of communication, adaptable and reliable in a pinch, the Queen Anne's Amateur Radio Club welcomed the public to its temporary transmitting stations as it hosted its annual Field Day at Tuckahoe State Park June 28 and 29.In addition to inviting everyone to check out amateur or "ham" radios and communication capabilities, the annual field day provides a great opportunity for members to practice skills and equipment closely to real emergency situations, Club President Corey Ruth said.
Easily the biggest annual ham radio event of the year, across North America, Field Day brings in the participation of 40,000 skilled "hams," to publicly demonstrate amateur radio's science and services, particularly for emergency situations, Ruth said.
Many members of Club are also part of Queen Anne's County Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service that support the Queen Anne's County Department of Emergency Services and provide communications for first responders and emergency personnel in disaster situations, he said.
"It's a great opportunity to practice our technical skills in a simulated emergency environment and have fun doing it. We also love getting to introduce new people to the hobby at such a high-profile event," Ruth said.
With what is essentially the equivalent of a single lightbulb and no permanent infrastructure, ham radio operators can talk to people around the world.
"It's definitely important to have that as a backup and maintain that knowledge of how to use it, " Ruth said.
The public event helps serve as validation to the numerous ham radio volunteers who spend countless hours providing emergency communications, public service work and other benefits throughout the community and region, Ruth said.
This year's event was also notable as the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted a more active hurricane season than normal and saw the first named storm of the season already, he said.
While incredibly important and useful, smartphone technology is often taken for granted and relies on a multi billion dollar infrastructure that, whether storms or computer glitches, doesn't take a lot to knock down, he said.
Radios are more than just an old fashioned means of communication, according to Ruth, with new technologies and capabilities always being added that can function on older equipment.
"It doesn't always have to be the latest and greatest equipment," he said.
The club recently introduced a program called WinLink Global Radio Email that, by connecting to pathways, essentially allows emails to be sent through ham radio, he said.
The area in Tuckahoe the field day event operated in was essentially a cell phone dead zone and a highlight of the event is showcasing to visiting groups including Scouts how the radios can connect with other operators across the country.
"Their eyes light up," Ruth said.
The Radio Club is a nonprofit organization dedicated to the promotion of amateur radio and service to the community and provides communications support to other local non-profit groups during public events.
Further supporting emergency preparedness education, the group also recently donated handheld Family Radio Service radios and tabletop weather radios to Homeland Security classes at Kent Island High School and Queen Anne's County High School, as well as sponsoring an Enrichment, Extension and Intervention class at Stevensville Middle School.
These classes are part of a broader initiative offering the Community Emergency Response Team program to students, in partnership with Queen Anne's County Department of Emergency Services.
The donated radios will be used to help provide hand-on experience for students to become familiar with radio communications, a vital component of public safety and emergency response training, Ruth said.
Donations were made possible through a grant by the Amateur Radio Relay League Foundation to promote knowledge and interest in ham radio among youths.
Happy to welcome anyone curious about ham radios, the Queen Anne's Amateur Radio Club meets monthly and regularly provides demonstrations at community events including all weeklong at the upcoming Queen Anne's County Fair.
More information can be found by contacting qso@qaarc.org or visiting qaarc.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on amateur radio's role in emergency communications, support for first responders, and public safety training in schools, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

Caroline County Sheriffs Office holds 2nd school supply drive

 July 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 DENTON — The Caroline County Sheriff's Office will be conducting its second annual school supply drive from July 28 to Aug. 18.The drive will collect supplies to donate to students in Caroline County Public Schools. The Sheriff's Office said the drive was born out of a partnership between the schools and the law enforcement agency.
"We have a very good, close working relationship with the Caroline County Public School System," Sheriff Donald Baker said. The Sheriff's Office is requesting new and unused school supplies for the drive. Drop off locations are at The Caroline County Sheriff's Office headquarters, the Ridgely Town Office, the Preston Town Office and the Federalsburg Police Department during business hours.

title: Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Newsletters 
 
 187
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Local police and emergency medical professionals took part in a serious training of the utmost importance in Easton on Thursday.Active shooter situations in elementary and secondary schools caused 328 deaths from 2000 to 2022, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.
That's why before every school year, local first responders have made it a habit to complete active shooter trainings. This year's training brought Talbot and Caroline sheriff's deputies, Easton police, local EMTs and paramedics, and others to The Country School.
Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull led a drill Thursday afternoon, showing me just how critical it is that first responders from different counties to work together cohesively under stress.
And the results were enlightening: officers and EMTs didn't always make the correct decision every split-second, but they did confer with each other on what steps to take during the next drill, learning how to get better along the way.
To learn more about the training, read my story below. Also in today's newsletter: Talbot Mentors helps local students achieve their goals, a conservation easement will become a public park in Dorchester County and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Konner Metz 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Seconds count: The Country School hosts active shooter training for law enforcement, EMS
author: Konner Metz
content:
Seconds count: The Country School hosts active shooter training for law enforcement, EMS

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With schools starting back up next month, police and first responders gathered at The Country School in Easton on Thursday to partake in active shooter training.Four separate drills took place Thursday. Officers entered the school to take down a mock shooter. They joined with paramedics and EMTs to locate mock students in classrooms, assess their injuries and evacuate them from the building in a safe manner.
Responders often communicated with one another on how to follow the proper incident command tactics, at times acknowledging the improvements they could make to their decisions during the drill. Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull said the drills will help improve all aspects of emergency response if a school shooting occurs on the Mid-Shore.
"It's a learning experience for everyone," Tull said.
In previous years, active shooter training took place at schools in Talbot and Caroline counties.
Recently, the drills have included a team of both law enforcement and EMS personnel called the Rescue Task Force. Once a hallway or area is cleared, officers will protect unarmed EMTs and paramedics in "warm zones," where danger may still exist even if the main threat is eliminated.
That practice is life-saving in a real situation, Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
"Before, (EMS personnel) didn't go in until the building got cleared, which caused more deaths," he said. "The quicker we can get treatment for people, the quicker we can get paramedics in there with us, the more people that hopefully will survive."
Still, the top priority is eliminating the shooter or main threat.
"The initial driving force is stop the killing, because the statistics will show you that an assailant can kill more people than you can treat," Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said.
"Their driving force is stop the dying," Lowrey said of EMTs and paramedics. "You toggle between those two driving forces."
Gamble said first responders have taken FEMA-required incident command training, which serves as a common baseline for members of different agencies.
"A lot of this stuff spawned out of 9/11, getting fire, police, paramedics everybody on the same page. Square up communications," Gamble said.
Having so many agencies on hand Thursday was an opportunity for first responders to acclimate with one another and become more comfortable working together during an emergency response, agency leaders said.
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker emphasized that local agencies already share a solid rapport.
"You'd be surprised how much there is interaction between counties and agencies," Baker said.
Plus, the geography of Mid-Shore counties sometimes means Caroline County police may be first on the scene to a Talbot County emergency, or vice versa.
"For something that happens at Preston Elementary, Talbot County will be the first ones there," Talbot County Maj. Steve Elliott said. "If something happens at Chapel Elementary, Caroline County will be the first ones there."
Tina Kintop, EMS division chief for the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, said it's most important for EMTs and paramedics to be disciplined and properly trained to participate in the rescue task force with police.
On Thursday, the drills didn't stop when the mock shooter went down. First responders secured students, assessed the severity of their injuries and evacuated them from the building. The job doesn't end there, Kintop said.
Police and EMS focus on locating a site for reunification of families. Gamble said different schools already have plans in place for reunification spots, some of which have been used for fire drills or bomb threats in the past.
By practicing these processes Thursday, agencies worked to create a streamlined plan they hope they will never have to use.
"It's all about organization and accountability," Kintop said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on active shooter training for police, EMS, and other first responders, emphasizing emergency response and safety protocols, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Sheriff warns of rising scams targeting local businesses, residents
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Sheriff warns of rising scams targeting local businesses, residents

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Headlines 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce welcomed Sheriff Gary Hofmann on July 30 as part of its ongoing seminar series, where he provided an in-depth look at the latest scams affecting businesses and individuals — and the steps they can take to protect themselves.Speaking at the Kent Island Library, Hofmann emphasized the importance of awareness and vigilance in a county he described as "very trusting and generous," where numerous worthwhile charities and nonprofits operate.
"Benefactors should always verify the legitimacy of an organization before donating," he said.
Hofmann outlined how small businesses, which often lack training and robust IT resources, are frequently targeted. Scammers may use stolen credit cards to place large orders, leaving businesses unaware until it is too late. To reduce risk, Hofmann recommended printing invoices and verifying identification when fulfilling pickup orders.
He also warned of phishing emails and fake invoices that can appear legitimate but include malicious links or fraudulent payment requests.
"If you find something out of the ordinary or that looks suspicious, take a breath," Hofmann said. "Scammers often use fear or urgency tactics — like threatening to cut off power — to compel quick action. It's important to slow down."
One common scam involves demands for payment via prepaid gift cards. In other cases, scammers impersonate tech support, offering to fix nonexisting issues in exchange for access to personal data.
Hofmann said data harvesting can occur almost anywhere. Fake job postings often request personal information or payment for background checks. "Check washing" is also on the rise — criminals steal checks from mailboxes and alter them to commit fraud. Hofmann advised residents to walk checks directly into the post office to minimize risk.
"Using secure payment methods and monitoring accounts regularly is key," he said. "Set up alerts for check clearances and large withdrawals, and implement internal controls like requiring two signatures."
When writing checks, Hofmann recommended pressing firmly into the paper to make alterations more difficult. He also urged residents to shred sensitive documents before disposal to avoid "dumpster identity theft."
"We don't think about how much information we're putting out there when we throw things away," he said.
With the rise of contactless payments, Hofmann encouraged people to cover the front of their credit cards at checkout to prevent nearby cameras from capturing card numbers. He also warned about credit card skimmers — devices that mimic real readers and can steal information from magnetic strips using hidden cameras or overlays.
Other scams include:
Overpayment scams, where fraudsters send more than the owed amount and request a refund before the original check bounces.Malicious QR codes that direct users to phishing sites or install malware.Tax scammers impersonating government agencies.Ransomware attacks that encrypt a victim's data until payment is made.
Hofmann stressed that education and prevention are the best tools to stay ahead of increasingly sophisticated criminals. Staff training, multi-factor authentication, and careful scrutiny of digital communications are essential.
"Taking the extra time to assess and validate links is imperative," he said. "Multi-factor authentication might be inconvenient, but it can save you a lot of headaches down the line."
He also encouraged reporting suspicious activity. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a sheriff warning residents and businesses about scams, focusing on crime prevention and safety measures, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Two students arrested after fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Two students arrested after fights at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Two students from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School were arrested on the second day of school after multiple fights broke out, Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said.The school resource deputy alerted the Sheriff's Office that a student was assaulting the school safety monitor. Before it was over, Phillips said several deputies and school staff were assaulted, and one staff member was taken to the hospital. Phillips did not disclose the extent of their injuries, but he said that everyone was going to be OK.
The school safety monitor received multiple blows to the head and was held down on the floor, and three deputies were spat on by students, Phillips said.
"That's a biological thing, you just don't know what you're dealing with, now they have to get tests done," Phillips said.
Phillips said the incident was prompted by something that happened outside of school. He did not provide further details on what incited the fighting.
The response from law enforcement was substantial, including 10 Cambridge police officers, seven sheriff's deputies and five state troopers.
"A majority of law enforcement in our small geographical area was at C-SD," Phillips said.
Public details are limited due to the involvement of juveniles, but a 15-year-old was arrested and charged with five counts of second-degree assault, resisting arrest, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school activities, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office press release.
The second student arrested was 14 years old. The student was charged with one count of second-degree assault, disorderly conduct, failure to obey a reasonable and lawful order, disturbing the peace, disrupting school operations, obstructing and hindering, and affray, according to the press release.
"The crowd was actually larger than that (the two arrests). A lot of onlookers with their cameras and stuff," Phillips said.
The two juveniles were taken to the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, then released to their guardians with referrals made to the Department of Juvenile Services, according to the press release.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Elementary school shut down after nerf gun scare
author: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com
content:
Elementary school shut down after nerf gun scare

 September 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 212
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 12-year-old boy outdoors with a nerf gun caused an elementary school to be briefly shut down near the end of the school day on Tuesday, Sept. 2.Deputies from the St. Mary's County Sheriff's Office responded to the area around Leonardtown Elementary School on Sept. 2 for a report of suspicious activity.
When they arrived, they discovered the activity "involved a juvenile wearing a Nerf mask and carrying a Nerf toy gun while walking on the sidewalk adjacent to the campus," a release from the sheriff's office said. "No injuries were reported."
Deputies were dispatched to the area at about 3:20 p.m. after a 911 caller reported seeing a person near the school wearing a mask and possibly carrying a gun.
Upon arrival, deputies "immediately secured the school property, while school administrators initiated safety protocols," according to the release.
Deputies determined the juvenile, who was 12 years old, did not make any threats and appeared unaware of the concern caused by wearing the mask and carrying a toy gun close to the school.
The juvenile was released to guardians and no charges were filed.
"School safety remains a top priority with the St. Mary's County Sheriff's Office, and the prompt report of suspicious activity allowed deputies to resolve the situation quickly and safely," according to the release.

title: Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary
author: Konner Metz
content:
Woman charged for graffiti acts at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A woman is being held at the Talbot County Detention Center after being accused of spray-painting graffiti around town, including at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary School.Sian Radaskiewicz-King, 32, was arrested Friday by Easton police on charges of malicious destruction of property and use of a hate symbol. She was later charged with defacing religious property and disturbing school operations, among other counts.
According to court documents, King allegedly spray-painted the transgender symbol on dumpsters, the sidewalk and a step outside the Catholic school off of Route 50. Other spray-painted symbols were found on a fence at the Hampton Inn next to the school, per court records.
The symbols were found elsewhere in town, including outside East End Liquors, The Market at Dover Station and other businesses. The transgender symbol, often used to encourage gender inclusivity, is a combination of the male and female signs.
At an unusually crowded bail hearing on Monday afternoon, Talbot County District Court Judge Karen Ketterman ordered King to be held without bond in the Detention Center. A trial is scheduled for Oct. 28.
Many parents and school officials from Sts. Peter and Paul filled the courtroom. School Board Chair Peggy Wilson asked Ketterman to not approve King's release. Wilson cited the Aug. 27 shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis, which killed two children and injured 18 people, as a reason why the school community is concerned for the safety of students.
"Our fear is not the symbol itself, but the possibility of a copycat situation," Wilson said.
King, according to public legal representation, is transgender. She previously attended Sts. Peter and Paul School.
The Minneapolis shooter, Robin Westman, was referred to as transgender by federal officials. Westman's gender identity wasn't clear, according to The Associated Press.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said in a statement this weekend that the graffiti incidents are "especially painful" given the Minneapolis Catholic school shooting.
"It reminds us of the responsibility we all share to ensure our children's safety and well-being," Cook wrote. "We condemn such acts of intimidation, they have no place in our community."
In a statement Sunday, the Delmarva Pride Center condemned the graffiti acts as a "misuse" of the international transgender symbol.
"We are deeply troubled that an LGBTQIA+ symbol was misused in a way that could be construed as hateful," the statement read. "Symbols such as the Transgender Symbol exist to affirm identity, celebrate diversity, and foster belonging — not to spread fear or division.
"This incident occurs at a time when Transgender people continue to face targeted attacks in society. We call on our neighbors, allies, and community members to stand together, to reject hate in all its forms, and to embrace the values of acceptance, compassion, and love."
On Monday, Easton Police Deputy Chief Greg Wright said the agency will increase patrol this week at Sts. Peter and Paul School and other schools in town. He said police "have no reason to believe that there was any attempt or desire to harm anyone."
BOND DECISION
Bridgette Lane, an assistant at the Talbot County public defender's office, argued in court on Monday that King should be granted release based on the low severity of charges, an otherwise clean criminal record and the Detention Center's recommendation.
Lane said King has "expressed remorse" and understands "she can't be acting out in these ways."
King, who is listed as having a Baltimore address, was recently staying in Easton with her mother, Lane said. If released, the expectation was for King to stay with her mother.
Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the graffiti incident is concerning due to the context of the Minneapolis shooting last month, as well as the fact that King's mother's house is close to the school.
"Here we have this clear warning sign," Coale said. " ... We don't know if the defendant is capable of carrying out something worse. But the state doesn't want to find out."
Ketterman said both sides made good points, but she hammered home that there are "no conditions of release" that would ensure the safety of the community. The judge said she's concerned about the location of the graffiti and King's documented mental health diagnoses, which include bipolar disorder and PTSD.
"I don't think the court has another choice," Ketterman said after ruling no bond and ordering the defendant complete a mental health evaluation.
Information from The Associated Press contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a criminal graffiti incident, police involvement, court actions, and community safety concerns, which best aligns with the Public Safety topic.

title: First responders learn about silo and grain rescues
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
First responders learn about silo and grain rescues

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENNEDYVILLE — City firefighters have to deal with issues that rural counties usually do not. For example, there are very few high rises in Kent County.That works both ways though.
City firefighters do not typically have to go into grain or corn silos for rescues. But Kent County firefighters may have to.
And they have the equipment to do it. They are called grain rescue devices and because of a grant, Kennedyville Volunteer Fire Department now has one in addition to the devices already at fire departments in Millington and Rock Hall.
"Kent County, Maryland, is noted for a few things," retired firefighter Larry Slagle said, speaking for the Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company.
"Among those, is our agricultural interests. We have any number of farmers whose primary interest is growing and processing grain products," he said. "And for efficiency, these farmers maintain grain bins, aka silos, on their farms."
Slagle said that occasionally, especially during grain harvest season, personnel may have to enter the silo, perhaps to clear a blockage or discern what the problem may be.
"This is one of the most dangerous things they will ever do," he added.
Slagle's post indicated that that the suction of the grain material as it's being unloaded at the bottom, is as dangerous as the riptide or undertow at the ocean.
"Across the United States and even the entire world, many farm workers have entered this environmen … and lost their lives."
Fire official experts concur with Slagle and Chestertown fire company, saying that about 55 grain bin entrapment events happen around the United States, many in Midwest states. Farmers and workers can get caught in equipment, submerged in grain or experience a medical event while working.
That is why the training with the equipment was instrumental for local firefighters.
On July 21, Slagle reported that fire companies from Chestertown, Galena, Betterton, Chestertown, Millington, Rock Hall and Marydel attended a regional training program, hosted by the Kennedyville Volunteer Fire Company with the topic: "Grain bin emergencies and how to safely mitigate them."
Classes were conducted by members of the National Education Center for Agricultural Safety.
Slagle said, "This training is especially invaluable to us, as sometimes emergency responders are sometimes the victims themselves."
After a period of classroom discussion, the activity transitioned outside to the training trailer.
Through specialized engineering, a grain bin was fashioned, and the "suction" phenomenon duplicated, in a safe manner, he pointed out.
Former member of the Kennedyville firefighter, farmer and owner of Philips Trucking, Josh Philips said that the equipment is a series of 6-8 aluminum panels, interconnected tubes with an auger, a spiral tool used to drill.
During the training, the tube was placed around the mock accident victim and the auger extracted the grain that was simulating suffocating them.
First responders practiced methods like ropes; confined space operations; patient care and packaging.
"At any time during the exercise, should something with the training go sideways, instructors could terminate the process and drain away the grain product," Slagle pointed out.
Everything was conducted safely and first responders left with a sense of confidence in the training, he added.
Kennedyville Assistant Chief Mark Dixon thanked Philips who had nominated Kennedyville for the grant to make the equipment possible.
Slagle said, "In the fire service, we have a mantra. 'It is not acceptable for anyone to be injured, or even die, because of training. It's the purpose of training to prevent that very serious, even tragic outcome … during a real emergency.'" 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on fire department personnel receiving specialized training to handle grain bin emergencies, highlighting safety procedures for first responders, which aligns most closely with Public Safety, while also touching on agricultural contexts and training aspects.

title: Sheriff: Youth justice laws add to crime
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Sheriff: Youth justice laws add to crime

 September 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Crime 
 
 539
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In the past week, there have been three juvenile arrests related to violent crimes in the City of Cambridge.Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips said this level of violent crime is "not normal" and officers feel their hands are tied by the current juvenile justice laws Phillips said lack accountability.
On the second day of school at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School last week, two students were arrested after assaulting the school safety monitor. Phillips described the scene as a "melee."
Phillips said three sheriff's deputies were spat on and the school safety monitor was taken to the hospital. Two boys, ages 14 and 15, were arrested following the incident.
The 15-year-old boy, Jaheem Mortaz Brown, was released to his step-father's custody. Three days later, the Brown allegedly shot his step-father in the face. The extent of the step-father's injuries has not been disclosed.
In addition, Phillips said Cambridge police received a call this weekend that juveniles around 11 years old were shoplifting from the Wawa on Sunburst Highway.
"They're shoplifting because they know they (the juvenile system) can't do nothing with them," Phillips said.
Phillips said the problem of juvenile crime will continue until the "broken juvenile justice system" is changed.
"The juvenile justice system in the state of Maryland is broken; it's not working," he said. "We're not holding anybody accountable."
The former Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, Vincent Schiraldi received intense backlash from Mid-Shore sheriffs, including Phillips. The Maryland Sheriffs Association sent a letter to Gov. Wes Moore calling for Schiraldi's immediate resignation last year. Schiraldi stepped down from the position in June.
"Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes," the letter states, "only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes."
After an in-person community meeting with the secretary around two years ago, Phillips said "He had the audacity to tell us, 'The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" Phillips recalled. "And our reply to that was, 'Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.'"
In 2022, the Maryland General Assembly passed a juvenile justice reform bill stressing rehabilitation rather than punishment in addressing juvenile behavioral issues, according to its proponents. The reform took effect in 2024.
In August, the Cambridge Police Department presented its quarterly report, which revealed that overall crime decreased, but there were concerns regarding homicides, robberies and juvenile violence.
Homicides, assaults, larceny and motor vehicle theft all increased from the second quarter in 2024. The homicide rate rose 200%, with two homicides that both led to arrests. One of those homicides was committed by a juvenile.
Phillips said this level of violent crime in Cambridge is not normal.
"I mean, it's not normal anywhere, but I think the biggest contributing factor we had last week is the failure of our juvenile system," he said.
Last school year, students in Dorchester County saw 1,682 long- and short-term suspensions with 1,232 of those suspensions related to violence, according to Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson.
In an attempt to curb suspensions, Dorchester County Public Schools launched a violence prevention initiative course for students, teachers, parents and staff to ensure there is community participation. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on juvenile crime, sheriff statements, and law enforcement concerns, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, though it also touches on school-related issues (Education) and local officials (Local Government).

title: Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day

 September 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Fire crews initially dispatched for a fire alarm activation at Queen Anne's County High School discovered a small electrical fire around 7:13 p.m. Sept. 9.Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler said in a letter to the school community that the fire broke out in a special education room Tuesday evening. The sprinkler system activated, limiting fire damage to the room where it started.
According to the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal, the fire originated in a rear first-floor office. The preliminary cause was deemed accidental, the result of "an unspecified electrical event of a power surge protector."
The fire marshal estimated about $30,000 in structure and content damages. No injuries were reported.
A total of 36 firefighters responded, with Goodwill Volunteer Fire Company the primary agency in charge. The fire was brought under control in about 30 minutes, the fire marshal said.
The fire alarm company contacted 911, and the school custodian also discovered the fire after the alarm activation.
Water collected in a back hallway, one special education classroom, an office and a conference room as the sprinkler system ran for about 20 minutes, Kibler said.
Third-party contractors were brought in to evaluate and assist. Normal operations resumed Sept. 11, after the school was closed to students and non-essential personnel Wednesday to allow cleanup and assessment. Other Queen Anne's County Public Schools were not affected.
QACPS expressed gratitude to first responders, the Queen Anne's County Fire Marshal's Office, the Maryland State Deputy Fire Marshal, and its custodial and maintenance staff for their work in returning the building to use.
On its Facebook page, QACPS wrote: "We are thankful that there were no injuries, and our fire suppression system worked appropriately."
Questions should be directed to Principal Lou Sheppard, Kibler said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an electrical fire at a high school, focusing on fire response, safety measures, and damage assessment, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: A visit to a foreign country - the past
author: George F. Will
content:
A visit to a foreign country - the past

 September 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: George F. Will | Page: A7 | Section: Opinions 
 
 745
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - This nation is awash with heated and ungenerous judgments about its past and about Americans who lived before we ascended to today's sunny uplands of enlightenment.So, for your final summer read, try something tonally different: Drew Gilpin Faust's memoir "Necessary Trouble: Growing Up at Midcentury." It concerns not her presidency of Harvard from 2007 to 2018 but her coming of age in the 1950s and 1960s.She was a high-octane student activist, involved in dangerous civil rights campaigning in the Deep South before becoming hyper-active in agitating against U.S. involvement in Vietnam.She is, however, an accomplished historian, and her book is most interesting, and needed, as a mellow, humane acceptance of an enduring truth from a forgotten novel (by L.P. Hartley): "The past is a foreign country: they do things differently there." Faust has gone back to a foreign country - America when post-1945 conventions and complacencies began to crumble - and has returned with a needed gift for today's nation: an example of mature assessment.Faust was born into a prosperous family in the caste system of segregated Virginia, a society thick with "rules and roles" governing - actually, suffocating - young white women and all Black people. They were entrapped, in not altogether dissimilar ways, in the viscosity of a society defined by strict racial and gender expectations that were unarticulated because they were unquestioned.Six decades ago, two braided emancipations began, the emancipation of women, and of Blacks nearly a century after the Emancipation Proclamation.Faust's family rode to hounds and sent children north to tony prep schools and universities. But from an early age, Faust was intelligent, opinionated, inexhaustibly curious, a voracious reader - and disconcerting to her determinedly conventional mother.A high school counselor would write of "Mrs. Gilpin's bewilderment in connection with Drewdie's intellectual gifts." Drew's mother "is like a hen that has hatched a duckling and cannot understand having a daughter who is not going to be a 'Southern belle.'" Faust would not be - as that era expressed its aspiration - "well-adjusted." Least of all adjusted to a society in which the chivalric protection of women was, Faust writes, "inextricably tied to concessions of frailty and incapacity." Young Drew was immersed "in a man's world and a white world." She sensed the connection and set about causing what John Lewis, the civil rights leader and congressman, called "necessary trouble." In the decade when Black author Ralph Ellison published his great novel "Invisible Man" (1952), Life magazine reflected national perceptions and assumptions."With the exception of a butler serving a drink on a silver tray," everyone pictured in Life's 1950s advertisements was White, and working women - other than in Hollywood - also were mostly invisible.Faust relished rock music, which was saturated with sexuality - Pat Boone and Frankie Avalon elbowed aside by Elvis and Little Richard - but books were most catalyzing.The 36 volumes published before 1960 about an independent and resourceful 16-year-old, Nancy Drew, were formative also for Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Nancy Pelosi, Sandra Day O'Connor and others.Faust "had never, at least as far as I knew, met a Jewish person" when she met, through a diary, an adolescent who was "an avid reader and aspiring writer," Anne Frank.Scout, the 8-year-old daughter of Atticus Finch in "To Kill a Mockingbird," exemplified for Faust children "seeing clearly." Faust writes, "These girls who dared - Nancy, Anne, Scout - were daring me." So, she went to Mississippi in 1964 for Freedom Summer, to Selma and Birmingham in 1965, this daughter whose father's car once had a hood ornament of Robert E. Lee mounted on Traveller.Faust, an academic who perhaps has not spent enough time around people who disagree with her about important matters, is uncharacteristically intemperate when she denigrates Vice President Hubert Humphrey, the Democratic 1968 presidential nominee, as a "toady" because he did not "speak out" against the war.Faust was 10 months old when Humphrey, the 37-year-old mayor of Minneapolis, successfully provoked the Democrats' 1948 national convention to put a civil rights plank in the party's platform.By challenging the upholders of Jim Crow - Southern Democratic governors and legislators - Humphrey ignited necessary trouble, which Faust would later join.Faust usually judges the past without rancor, contempt or preening, giving empathetic depictions of social contexts inherited by the people who inhabited them.When, generations hence, historians judge how we inhabited our context, they will be depicting the foreign country to which we then will be confined: the past.Reach George Will at georgewill@washpost.com. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Drew Faust clasps hands with a graduate as she walks in the procession at Harvard's commencement ceremony in 2013 where she was university president. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses civil‑rights activism, racial and gender inequality, and the historical context of a prominent academic, making race and diversity the primary focus, with education as a secondary theme.

title: Frederick Douglass Day Parade, Events In Easton
content:
Frederick Douglass Day Parade, Events In Easton

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Frederick Douglass Day events will be held in Easton and Talbot County on Saturday, Sept. 23. The day commemorates the life and contributions of the abolitionist, social reformer and writer.Events are organized by the Frederick Douglass Honor Society along with the Talbot County Free Library, (TCFL) town of Easton and Talbot County.There will be a parade in downtown Easton on Saturday with bands from Easton High School and Easton Middle School, local dance groups and local dignitaries.The parade runs from Easton Elementary School to the Talbot County Court House.A welcome ceremony will feature music from the high school and middle school and hip ho artist Baba Bomani along with speakers and recitations.Easton Mayor Megan McLennan Cook,, Talbot County Councilwoman Keasha Haythe and Brenda Wooden, president, Frederick Douglass Honor Society are among the speakers.There will be a marketplace Children's Village with kids activities and events from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. in downtown Easton.The TCFLwill have a Frederick Douglass Room with artifacts, readings and Douglass paintings by artist Laura Era, who owns the Troika Gallery.The library will launch a Fredrick Douglass Reading Challenge on Sept. 23 that runs through Nov 1 for ages to 18. "Every time you read a Frederick Douglass biography, you fill out and turn in a raffle ticket which makes you eligible to win one of three $50 gift certificates from Target," the library said in an announcement.There will also be book signings related to Douglass - who was born into slavery in Talbot County and became a leading abolitionist voice.Dr. Robert Levine, author of "The Failed Promise: Reconstruction, Frederick Douglass, and the Impeachment of Andrew Johnson", will sign his books at Flying Cloud Booksellers at 11:30 a.m.Author and photographer Jeff McGuiness will sign copies of his book "Bear Me into Freedom: The Talbot County of Frederick Douglass" at Vintage Books & Fine Arts from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m.Dr. Derrick R. Spires - a John and Patricia Cochran Scholar of Inclusive Excellence and Associate Professor of English at the University of Delaware - will deliver a keynote address at 1 p.m.For information on the other speakers, music and other entertainment check out https://frederickdouglasshonorsociety.com/. 
 
 Caption: MD TOURISM
 
Talbot County native Frederick Douglass, one of the nation's most prominent figures in African-American, and US history.
 
An abolitionist, editor, orator, author, statesman, women's suffragist and reformer, Douglass was a firm believer in equality for all people.
