title: 'Her home was the council chamber of the free' - Lecture details the life and accomplishments of Anna Murray-Douglass
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
'Her home was the council chamber of the free' - Lecture details the life and accomplishments of Anna Murray-Douglass

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 750
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The Museum of Rural Life was abuzz with living history as Scottish professor Celeste-Marie Bernier gave a lecture on Anna Murray-Douglass, the wife Frederick Douglass.The event was put on by the Caroline County Historical Society on Wednesday, Nov, 29. Vicki Wilson, secretary of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, introduced Bernier."Celeste is the Professor and Chair of United States and Atlantic Studies at University Edinburgh in Scotland," Wilson said. "She is an author and world-renowned historian."Anna Murray was born free in Denton.Early in her relationship with Frederick Douglass, who was enslaved when Anna was free, she gave him all of her savings to run away to his freedom. He refused.When she told him she loved him and that he could return the money later, he finally agreed. He escaped and eventually returned the money. They got married in New York City in 1838."She lived her life by the conviction that her home was the council chamber of the free," said Bernier. Anna, working as an agent of the Underground Railroad, fed hundreds of people, day or night.She worked with Harriet Tubman on the Eastern Shore, said Bernier.In his writings, Frederick Douglass relates a story about a woman from Easton, who came to them for help."This poor woman's back and shoulders had been literally hacked to pieces," he said. "Three months ago, her cheek was branded with burning irons. We sat with her, and all she said was 'I want to get to Canada.'" Bernier, working from original source documents, delivered a lecture on Murray-Douglass with descriptions like, "freedom fighter," "revolutionary liberator" and "human rights philosopher."Anna did not just sit in her kitchen baking biscuits.According to Bernier, Anna was an expert cook and could whip up everything from dishes from the African diaspora to European styles of cuisine. There were a lot of hungry people to feed, and at times she had to ask her own family to sacrifice food and a warm bed for someone else.She was interested in how fashion could reflect a person's wholeness. She designed a silk plum colored wedding dress for herself in 1830 in New York City. Anna worked tirelessly to help newly emancipated slaves by feeding them and giving them dignified clothes.Anna knew the power of printing and publishing her own story. This control of her own representation was crucial. Her descendants knew this too and wrote to make the abolitionist cause manifest.Bernier called Anna an "egalitarian human rights philosopher." And she raised her five children to carry on this fight against white supremacy."They took that intergenerational pain, that intergenerational trauma, that inter-generations suffering, and they turned it into intergenerational liberation, intergenerational activism and a blueprint for what a world based on equal human rights would actually look like," Bernier said.Bernier said it is hard to estimate how many slaves Anna set free. One estimate is 1,200, but Bernier wonders if it is much higher.The historian painted a picture of Anna as Frederick's equal and protector.She said Frederick had a way with words, and Anna had a way with numbers.Anna was always on the move to avoid persecution and to keep her husband safe, but the cause of liberty echoed loudly in the Douglass' homes. Their final home was on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. They bought it with her money.When Anna dies in 1882, 3,000 people attended her funeral.After Bernier's lecture, there was time for questions and mingling with coffee.The historian signed copies of her book "If I Survive," which was also authored by Andrew Taylor.Bernier opened her laptop to share images of the Douglass family with some of the abolitionists' living relatives, who came to the lecture.One descendent, Thelma Nichols of Denton, is a spry 97. She shared stories that her father had told her."It is exciting to know that I am a relative of someone as important as Anna," said Deborah Murray-Dates of Cambridge, Anna's greatniece."Incredible."The Douglasses had five children. Rosetta Douglass Sprague, Lewis Henry Douglass, Frederick Douglass Jr., Charles Remond Douglass and Annie Douglass. 
 
 Caption: From right: Debbie Bennett of the Caroline County Public Library introduces Professor Celeste-Marie Bernier as Dr. Willie Woods and Thelma Nichols await the lecture on abolitionist Anna Murray Douglass.
 
Lecturer Celeste-Marie Bernier, with red tie, shares pictures of the Douglass family with two living relatives of the abolitionists, Thelma Nichols, right, and Deborah Marray-Dates.
 
Anna Murray Douglass was famous abolitionist Frederick Douglass' wife. They were partners in pursuit of "the cause" of abolition. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Anna Murray-Douglass, an abolitionist and African‑American historical figure, highlighting her role in the fight against slavery and white supremacy. It discusses her contributions to civil rights and features a lecture by a historian, making the primary focus race and diversity rather than sports, business, or other categories.

title: King's granddaughter carrying forward his legacy
author: JESSICA A. JOHNSON
content:
King's granddaughter carrying forward his legacy

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JESSICA A. JOHNSON | Section: Columns 
 
 673
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I happened to catch the recent "CBS Mornings" news interview of Yolanda Renee King, the only grandchild of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Coretta Scott King. While promoting her new children's book honoring her grandparents titled "We Dream a World," Yolanda gave a profound answer when asked what she would say to them if they were alive today. "I think I would first start off with an apology," she said, which was surprising to CBS host Nate Burleson, who immediately asked the young activist what she meant by her response. Yolanda continued, "An apology to where we are right now, as a nation and really as a world."Yolanda is only 15 years old, and it is evident that she has a deep understanding of what her grandparents fought for as leaders of the civil rights movement. In August of last year, during the 60th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, Yolanda boldly declared that her generation would "be defined by action, not apathy."
As Yolanda is growing up before our eyes, she has the youthful exuberance of her grandfather's resolve and displays the dignified grace of her grandmother. Yolanda saying she would apologize to her grandparents for our nation not yet reaching the potential they believed in should make us thoughtfully reflect on how Dr. King also warned about becoming apathetic.
Apathy is a brutal paralyzer of life. It can cause us to be ensnared in a dangerous mode of stagnation emotionally, spiritually, and sometimes physically. Apathy also triggers entitled disinterest in our society. In 2021, Tom Nichols, an instructor at Harvard Extension School and the U.S. Naval War College, asserted in an interview with The Harvard Gazette that "narcissism and nihilism" are the primary threats to our country's democracy and societal relationships. Elaborating on the latter, Nichols said that many people ask why our society is "so mean and heartless and awful," but many of them do not contribute anything to make their communities better, or they will vote against policies that affect their well-being due to "narcissistic beefs."
"We have become surly villagers," Nichols maintained, "me, my family, my little plot of land, and everybody else can go to hell." This type of sullen attitude is what Yolanda is urging our country to overcome as she is an emerging voice on critical issues such as gun violence and homelessness.
As Yolanda continues to attentively study the Godly principles that enabled her grandfather to be that drum major for justice who changed the course of our nation, I am reminded of two of his sermons where he encouraged his followers to live with purpose and passion and to shower others with Christian love.
The first sermon is titled "But If Not," a 1967 message that King delivered at Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church. King expresses that the "ultimate test" of our faith is when we get to a "but if not" moment in life, a moment where we have to travel along an arduous journey with no other option but to lean on God's promises.
This passage stands out to avoid being gripped by apathy during a spiritual test: "... somewhere along the way [in life] you should discover something that's so dear, so precious to you, that is so eternally worthful, that you will never give it up." The second sermon is "Levels of Love," an Ebenezer address King gave in 1962. He implored the congregation to "rise to agape, to Christian love" because "[t]he greatness of it is that you love every man, not for your sake but for his sake. And you love every man because God loves him."
It is remarkable that Yolanda exemplifies the love and compassion her grandparents demonstrated as she diligently works to uplift others. She is blazing her own path, and it is truly inspiring to watch it unfold. She probably has not had a "but if not" moment yet in her young life thus far, but I have no doubt she is developing the character and strength to face the challenges she knows are coming. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Yolanda Renee King, the granddaughter of civil rights leaders, discussing her activism, legacy of the civil rights movement, and issues of social justice, which aligns most closely with the Race & Diversity topic.

title: Mid-Shore native appointed to Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Mid-Shore native appointed to Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 715
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Jaelon Terrele Moaney has been appointed as a commissioner by Gov. Wes Moore to be on the Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture. His term is from 2023 to 2027.According to MCAAH website, the purpose of the "the commission is to identify and preserve buildings, communities and sites of historical and cultural importance to the African American experience in Maryland. This competitive program, offered once per year, is supported through an annual appropriation from the Maryland General Assembly and is administered as a joint partnership of the Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture and The Maryland Historical Trust."
They give away $5 million a year, and Moaney works with his commission to find suitable candidates who are either architecturally or culturally preserving Black history and identity.
"It is the first ever ethnic commission in the United States. It is something that our colleagues across the country look to as an example. I feel humble to join the group as the youngest. The commission, in general, documents, collects African American heritage across the state," said Moaney.
He covers Delmarva for the commission and currently lives in Cambridge with his wife. Moaney is a product of Talbot County Public Schools, where he played football. He went to Williams College in Massachusetts.
Moaney said he hopes to energize the commission.
"I am trying to expand notions of Blackness that center on joy, that center freedom, agency and maybe push and highlight elements of our culture here on the Shore that often get overlooked. I think we have to reinforce accurate portrayals of Black life as well as ones that normalize our culture," he said.
He takes a long historical look at how Black people have suffered in America.
"Our country is really trying to reconcile with wounds that haven't fully healed or even the past few weeks, some that are opening up scars that are deeper than we could imagine. Like the people of Haiti, who have a large population in Salisbury now, or the people who were elected in Federalsburg for the first time in centuries — have the space to give it justice," he said.
Moaney will bring the commission to Chestertown for a public meeting in April. That meeting will be in the Bethel AME Church, where the Freedom Riders came and stayed in 1962.
"We have regular commission meetings that will happen all over the state. It is a beauty to be at the sites we are trying to preserve. Some are trying to be restored, some have been restored, some are receiving grants," Moaney said.
"I was assigned two committees. One was African American Heritage Preservation Program. The funding for that just got raised by the assembly from $1 million to $5 million. Close to 50% of the awardees were on the Eastern Shore. It is a collaboration with the Maryland Historical Trust which is in the Department of Planning," he said.
Among the grants awarded by the commission through the Historical Preservation Program for fiscal year 2024 are:
$250,000 for the American Legion Mannie Scott Post 193 Building in Denton.
$138,000 to Alpha Genesis Community Development Corporation in Cambridge.
$200,000 to Kent County Public Library.
$250,000 to Bryan's United Methodist Church in Grasonville.
$250,000 to the Mid-Shore Community Foundation in Royal Oak.
The grants will offer assistance to organizations and private citizens in their sponsorship of projects involving the acquisition, construction, or improvement of sites related to African American heritage, according to a press release from the governor's office.
Moaney's other appointment is to the Inaugural Statewide Book Drive. "The best part are the oral histories. There are so many discoveries. It's a privilege to be there," he said.
Outside of his work on the commission, Moaney is the founder of literacy group called the Needle's Eye Academy.
"If you are familiar with Gil Scott-Heron. He was arguably the soundtrack to the Black power movement as a poet and a musician and an oralist. The song 'Needles Eye' is where the Academy's name emanates from. From the 1972 album 'Pieces of the Man,'" he said.
"They have been asking, 'Are there any college age students who will speak to high schoolers and maybe even start a book club. We donated our old book sales into Berkshire County Public Schools (Massachusetts). In August of 2020 we started online in Talbot County Public Schools with three wonderful students." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the appointment to a state commission focused on African American history and culture, highlighting heritage preservation, grants, and community outreach, which aligns most closely with the Race & Diversity topic.

title: 'In Pursuit of Freedom' lecture at Kennard on Feb. 25
author: Staff Writer
content:
'In Pursuit of Freedom' lecture at Kennard on Feb. 25

 February 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 199
 Words 

 Read News Document

 St. Paul's Episcopal Church will present a Black History Month lecture at the Kennard African American Heritage Center in Centreville at 4 p.m. on Sunday, Feb. 25. The lecture, entitled "In Pursuit of Freedom" will be given by noted local historian Chris Pupke, a member of Kennard's Advisory Board and St. Paul's Church.The program will focus on the many ways that enslaved people in Queen Anne's County sought and fought for their freedom, including then use of the Underground Railroad, the taking up of arms, and litigation in the courts. There will be a question and answer period after the lecture.
Earlier, on the same day, noted baritone Thomas Beard will be singing two songs associated with the observance of Black History Month at the 10 a.m. service at St. Paul's. Included will be "Come Sunday" by Duke Ellington along with a classical selection.
Beard has performed at the White House and in the Washington National Opera's Young Artist Program, where he was the only African American personally chosen by maestro Placido Domingo to take part in the program. He also sung with many opera companies across the U.S.
St. Paul's Church is located at 301 S. Liberty Street in Centreville. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Unknown history: Black History Month offers opportunity to recognize ‘the people’
author: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Unknown history: Black History Month offers opportunity to recognize ‘the people’

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 211
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This month, in community centers, libraries, schools and churches like Bethel AME Church in Centreville, when citizens gather to honor the nation's greatest champions for freedom, justice and equal rights, they also honor the people.In 1915, the historian Dr. Carter G. Woodson founded what is now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. The following year, he began publishing what is now The Journal of African American History, a publication of history, research and book reviews.
In 1926, Woodson founded "Negro History Week" to honor the history, culture and contributions of African Americans. He chose February to coincide with the birthdays of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln. In 1976, President Gerald Ford extended the observation to a month, now known as Black History Month.
Woodson believed that history was "made by the people, not simply or primarily by great men."
Local writer, Niambi Davis had the opportunity to contribute to the Black History display at Bethel AME. The subjects, Davis said, "are important and more than just the usual Douglass and Tubman stories; they're the unknown local, national and international folks."
The display is open to the congregation and anyone wishing to attend services. Service begins at 11 a.m. Sunday mornings. The church is located on Washington Road in Centreville. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Black History Month, highlighting African American history, cultural contributions, and the importance of recognizing diverse individuals, which aligns directly with the Race & Diversity topic.

title: Lawmakers propose task force to probe long-term inequities facing Black women
author: TORRENCE BANKS Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers propose task force to probe long-term inequities facing Black women

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TORRENCE BANKS Capital News Service | Section: National 
 
 817
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The persistence of economic, educational and legal disparities in the lives of Black women and girls would be the target of a federal task force recently proposed by a group of House members."Simply acknowledging our country's history of targeted discrimination, harassment and violence against Black women and girls will not correct years of systemic racism and sexism," Rep. Robin Kelly (D-Illinois) said in a statement after the legislation creating the task force was introduced earlier this month.
"We must leverage the full weight of the federal government to seek justice for Black women and girls who deserve an equal opportunity for a full, happy, healthy life," Kelly said.
Kelly is co-chair of the Caucus on Black Women and Girls, along with Reps. Yvette Clarke of New York and Bonnie Watson Coleman of New Jersey, who also sponsored the measure. Reps. Jennifer McClellan (D-Virginia), Valerie Foushee (D-North Carolina) and Brian Fitzpatrick (R-Pennsylvania) also have signed on to the bill, called the "Protect Black Women and Girls Act."
The bill would establish a task force to examine several aspects of the lives of Black women and girls, including education, healthcare, economic development, housing and civil rights. The task force would look at the effectiveness of programs and policies at the state, federal and local levels and make recommendations for changes.
Kelly said that the bill would help governments be more proactive in ensuring that Black women receive equal opportunities.
The task force would be led by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Justice. Both would then share information with the United States Commission on Civil Rights (USCCR).
The civil rights commission also would conduct a study and collect data about the social justice, economic and health effects of discrimination and inequities on Black women and girls. The bill was originally introduced in 2021 with 15 co-sponsors. However, Congress took no action on it.
Maryland Del. Jheanelle Wilkins, a Democrat, said the legislation would allow the state's government to look at the results from the research and craft more equitable policies.
"We know that signs point to black women being disproportionately impacted by many things whether it's maternal health — and in Maryland, Black women are four times as likely to die as a result of childbirth," said Wilkins, who also serves as the chair of the state's Legislative Black Caucus.
In 2021, the maternal mortality rate of non-Hispanic Black women was 69.9 births per 100,000 live births, according to the Centers for Disease Control. That was more than two times the rate for non-Hispanic white women.
"We are the caregivers for our community, we're the matriarchs of our home, but also of the Black community," said Kelli Richardson Lawson, founder of the mental health nonprofit organization The SonRise Project, based in Bethesda, Maryland. "So we've always had to take care of everybody else before we take care of ourselves."
Lawson said that the passage of the legislation is crucial because of the socioeconomic challenges that Black women have faced.
Thirty-nine percent of white women earn a bachelor's or associate degree by the age of 29, compared to 21% of Black women, according to the American Association of University Women.
"Based on what I've seen, this bill would help mitigate some of the issues that we see involving Black women and girls in a variety of areas," said Lawson, whose non-profit serves as a safe space for Black parents to discuss issues involving teen mental health.
Black girls also face disadvantages in education. A 2020-2021 school discipline report from the U.S. Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights found that "Black girls were nearly two times more likely to receive one or more in-school suspensions, one or more out-of-school suspensions, and expulsions than White girls."
In addition, Black school-aged girls are four times more likely to be arrested in school than white girls, according to research discussed on Kelly's web page.
John Berkley, coordinator for the National Pan-Hellenic Council in Maryland, Virginia and several other states, said that Maryland has many organizations working to help Black women. Knowing that Congress is backing them up with legislation would be a huge boost, he said.
"Now they could say that It's not only a community effort but also a national policy that we now have some teeth behind," Berkley said. "And maybe with that, that will bring more awareness to what's going on with Black females in our various raised communities."
Berkley said that he plans to travel with his fraternity to Annapolis in a couple of weeks to talk to his legislators to see what they're doing to help Congress move the bill along.
Lawson said the task force could lead to the creation of more programs and organizations like hers, where Black women are free to focus on themselves and have vulnerable conversations.
"Changing the narrative, so that we can take off that cape, we can take a deep breath and exhale, and we can start to focus on ourselves," Lawson said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on systemic racial and gender inequities affecting Black women and girls, discussing a federal task force to address disparities in health, education, economics, and civil rights, making Race & Diversity the most fitting category.

title: Local documentary is 'going places'
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Local documentary is 'going places'

 March 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1002
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The trip started out by collecting soil on Cross Street in Chestertown. The location where James Taylor, a 23-year-old Black man, was lynched in 1892.That soil would find its way more than 800 miles south in a powerful message to remember a bleak chapter in history.
That journey was followed in the documentary film "Get on the Bus."
Forty-two Kent County youths and adults made the trek, traveling to Civil Rights era landmarks in Alabama and Georgia, including the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham; the King Center in Atlanta, Edmund Pettus Bridge and the National Voting Rights Museum in Selma and the Equal Justice Initiative's Community Remembrance Project in Montgomery.
Directed by Justinian Dispenza of Andover Media, the film debuted on Valentine's Day at the Decker Theatre in Washington College with almost 200 people in attendance. it was also shown the at Ocean City Film Festival earlier this month.
After its debut, the powerful emotions it invoked resulted in people interested in screening it.
For Dispenza, it's uplifting to see his work yielding these results.
"That's what we're all aiming to do as filmmakers. To make a change in people's lives. It was an incredible experience," he said.
As people left the theatre, Dispenza reflected on the process of creating "Get on the Bus" in slight awe.
Because it did not start out as being a film.
The idea initially came from Program Director of Minary's Dream Alliance Paul Tue III and Co-Chair of the James Taylor Justice Coalition Philip Dutton, to take a trip, educating people about the past, to the roots of the Civil Rights Movement, Alabama.
What started as a field trip where Dispenza was brought on to take pictures became something else.
Dispenza, no stranger to films about social issues, was eager.
Except there were obstacles.
Before they left, he was diagnosed with Lyme's Disease. Forced to take antibiotics on the road, he was told by his doctor to avoid the sun.
"That's kinda tough to do, July in the Deep South," Dispenza said, laughing.
It was five days in that sweltering heat with cameras rolling 24-7, no cloud in sight.
While he and Lead Editor Tanner Presswood filmed, Dispenza used long sleeves like protective gear and a floppy hat to ward off the sun.
Perhaps if he didn't feel a strong sense of purpose, he would have thought of his discomfort more than three times in the trip. But seeing through the lens of time how racism was a way of life for many, which seemed like a different universe to him, busied him in a beneficial way.
They went to sites like the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, where on Sunday, September 15, 1963, at 10:22 a.m., the church became known around the world when a bomb exploded, killing four young girls attending Sunday School.
Eastern Shore girls the age of those victims read that and marveled.
"How can someone hate someone so much that they could hurt them and have no consideration in their heart?" Love Jackson asked.
As they ascended the steps to the upper part of the church they witnessed a reenactment of Reverend Martin Luther King Jr.
Overcome by the strong feelings standing where King stood, Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Chestertown Joel Tolbert opened up.
"I sit in the pulpit every Sunday. But I tried to stand in that pulpit...it's a hard space," he acknowledged.
The emotions would heighten.
Just down the road there were statues of attack dogs, replicas of what Black people faced in 1963. There was a statue of children against the wall in a firing line and statues of enslaved people in chains, heads down in despair.
Broadcasted at the The National Memorial for Peace and Justice were some of the reasons they were lynched, horrific in their simplicity and ignorance.
One was lynched for not tipping his hat to the police officer.
Another to yield a better return in the sharecropping business.
There was one, where, since a man could not be found, his 2-year-old daughter was lynched in his place.
The group journeyed to Selma. At the Edmund Pettus Bridge, they crossed as others did in 1965, knowing that beatings, dogs and water hoses waited for them on the other side.
Founder of Minary's Dream Alliance, Doncella Wilson, felt that weight. Crossing the same bridge that 600 Civil Rights marchers crossed, she had to stop in the middle and reflect, before walking on., head high.
The camera captured the moment.
Inside the Equal Justice Initiative Museum while delivering the soil as an addition to the Legacy Museum, Dispenza broke down himself.
He sat on the floor and cried, having taken some ownership of the atrocities committed. But through that pain and despair, the tears and sorrow, shone hope.
"People were not afraid to be vulnerable," Dispenza said. "It led to healing."
They were receptive to the filming process too, seeing it as a tool to do good. "It was a tough film but a beautiful film," Dispenza said.
And the results of the film did not leave people in despair.
One resident leaving Decker Theatre told him the film "had given him a peace and hope he's never had before."
Throughout the film there were positive messages to the youth. Wilson told a group of children the activists they have read about and heard were no older than they were. Tue told the youths they don't know how powerful they are.
Dispenza's film echoed with its audience as well. After the debut, it has been featured at the Bill Johnson Film Festival in Indiana.
Tue, who was with them through the entire trip, was amazed at how the footage was compiled altogether.
He told Dispenza, "My God, this is going places!"
With eight or nine screenings already having taken place, he was certainly not wrong.
Dispenza sees this as an urgent message to spread. "This conversation needs to be had as school districts try to suppress Critical Race Theory," he said.
It is a topic debated among educational groups. Dispenza is more than happy to pursue these challenges and encouraged those who have great story ideas to reach out to him at Andover Media.
For more of his projects, visit his Imdb page at imdb.com/name/nm14340956/ as well. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a documentary about civil‑rights history, lynching, and ongoing discussions of Critical Race Theory, making race and diversity the primary focus, with secondary relevance to arts/culture (the film) and education (school debates).

title: Calvert County middle schoolers in Calvert County face hate crime charges
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Calvert County middle schoolers in Calvert County face hate crime charges

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to the Calvert County State's Attorney's Office, three 13-year-old students at Plum Point Middle School in Huntingtown have been charged as juveniles with harassment and violations of Maryland's hate crimes statutes. The state's attorney's office released the information Friday afternoon.According to charging documents filed by the Maryland State Police, the students displayed swastikas, made Nazi salutes and directed offensive comments to a classmate because of the classmate's religious beliefs.
The state's attorney's office press release stated the behavior began last December and "continued over several months despite repeated requests to stop."
The matter was reported to the state police, who investigated and filed the charges against the juveniles. The press release does not report the names or genders of the charged students.
The charges will be forwarded to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services for appropriate action. That entity has the discretion to refer the charges to the Calvert County Circuit Court for a hearing. The state's attorney's office then would be required to prove the allegations beyond a reasonable doubt.
"Calvert County Public Schools is committed to providing students and staff with an environment that is safe, welcoming and free from all forms of discrimination," Susan Johnson, chief academic officer and spokesperson for the school system, said in a statement released Monday. "The civil rights of all individuals will be protected. All complaints are investigated promptly. Upon completion of an investigation, students and school personnel may be subject to disciplinary action or consequences for discriminatory behaviors."
Calvert County State's Attorney Robert Harvey (R) issued a statement last Friday.
"Maryland was founded on the principle of religious toleration," Harvey said in the statement. "It is frankly astonishing that nearly 400 years later some people continue to persecute others based upon their religion. I call upon parents, educators and community and faith leaders to make sure that our children know that religious persecution has no place in our society."
On Tuesday, Commissioner President Earl F. "Buddy" Hance (R) stated, "We will not tolerate hate speech. That's not who we are. I hope they [juveniles] get the counseling that they need." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a hate‑crime incident targeting a student for religious beliefs, highlighting discrimination and bias, which aligns most closely with the Race & Diversity topic.
